DOC.HEAD: Gas Company Dropping Bill For Quayle Visit
DOC.TEXT: Columbia Gas is dropping its request to make natural-gas customers pay for costs associated with a visit by Vice President Dan Quayle last year. Columbia Gas had sought customer reimbursement for $703,000 in costs related to the promotion of a bus powered by natural gas. Quayle unveiled the bus during a visit to Ohio on Sept. 8. The change in the company's position came Friday, a day after Quayle's press secretary said the vice president was sending a letter to Columbia Gas asking that the cost be dropped from a $42 million rate-increase request pending before state utility regulators. Quayle said the company's attempt to recover the costs was ``outrageous.'' Columbia Gas spokesman Alan Crockett said the company's decision to withdraw its request for the reimbursement ``had nothing to do with the vice president.'' The company said in a statement: ``Certainly, we want to assure that the many benefits of clean air technologies such as the natural gas bus are kept in proper focus. The attention that now surrounds our request to recover these costs has shifted the focus of our original intent in developing this important new technology.'' Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith, said the vice president had no idea the bus costs might be passed to gas customers. Beckwith said Quayle assumed the utility would absorb the costs. ``The use of my visit to Columbus as an excuse to soak the ratepayers is outrageous,'' Beckwith quoted Quayle as saying. Of the $703,000 reimbursement, Ohio customers were asked to pick up $428,839 of the bill, with the remainder spread among customers in Kentucky, Maryland, New York and Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: The Planet Venus at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Galileo-Venus, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts, figures and theories about Venus, the planet visited early today by the Jupiter-bound Galileo spacecraft: DIAMETER: About 7,520 miles, or 95 percent as wide as Earth, and sixth largest of the solar system's nine known planets. MASS: Venus weighs about 82 percent as much as Earth. ATMOSPHERE: About 96 percent carbon dioxide and most of the rest nitrogen, but with thick clouds of sulfuric acid and water vapor. The atmosphere traps heat in a runaway ``greenhouse effect'' that scientists believe evaporated liquid water long ago. SURFACE CONDITIONS: Temperature about 900 degrees Fahrenheit. Crushing atmospheric pressure 90 times that on Earth. DAY LENGTH: Venus rotates on its axis very slowly, so one day on Venus equals 243 Earth days. Its rotation is retrograde, so the sun rises in the west and sets in the east. YEAR LENGTH: Venus orbits the sun once every 225 Earth days. DISTANCE FROM THE SUN: Venus is the second planet from the sun, orbiting at a distance of 67.2 million miles. It is closer to Earth than any other planet. Other than the sun and moon, Venus is the brightest object in Earth's skies. MOONS: None. GEOLOGY: Earth-based and spacecraft radar revealed hundreds of thousands of volcanoes on the Venusian lowlands, although scientists don't yet know if any are active. Venus also has meteorite impact craters and continent-like highlands with towering peaks that dwarf Earth's tallest mountains. Scientists suspect giant plates of rock may move in Venus' crust in a process vaguely like continental drift on Earth. GRAVITY: About 89 percent as strong as on Earth.

DOC.HEAD: A List of Events During NASA's Galileo Mission to Jupiter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Galileo-Venus Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key events for the Galileo spacecraft's looping, six-year trip to Jupiter, the solar system's largest planet: Oct. 18, 1989 _ Galileo is released from the cargo bay of space shuttle Atlantis, then an Inertial Upper Stage booster launches the spacecraft on its long voyage. Nov. 9-11, 1989 _ Controllers order multiple firings of Galileo's thrusters for the first of about 30 course correction maneuvers. Dec. 22, 1989 _ Thrusters fire again for second course correction. Feb. 9, 1990 _ Galileo swoops near Venus for its first ``gravity assist'' maneuver, using the planet's gravity to increase the spacecraft's speed to help it reach Jupiter. Galileo makes photos and measurements of Venus, storing them on an onboard recorder. Late October 1990 _ Galileo plays back to Earth the photos and measurements it made near Venus. Dec. 8, 1990 _ Galileo passes within 600 miles of Earth, making photos and measurements during its second ``gravity assist'' maneuver, which will help aim it toward Jupiter. Oct. 29, 1991 _ The spacecraft swoops within 600 miles of asteroid Gaspra, taking pictures and measurements. Dec. 8, 1992 _ Galileo zooms about 185 miles above Earth's surface in the third and final ``gravity assist'' maneuver needed to hurl it toward Jupiter. Aug. 28, 1993 _ If Galileo has adequate propellant supplies, it passes 600 miles from asteroid Ida for photos and measurements. July 1995 _ The spacecraft separates into a 760-pound Galileo probe and a 4,890-pound Galileo orbiter. Both continue toward Jupiter. Dec. 7, 1995 _ The probe and orbiter arrive at Jupiter. The probe plunges into the planet's atmosphere, relaying measurements to the orbiter, then is destroyed by intense atmospheric pressure. The orbiter speeds about 600 miles from the moon Io and its sulfur-spewing volcanoes and geysers, then goes into orbit around Jupiter. December 1995-October 1997 _ The orbiter circles Jupiter, making photos and measurements of the giant planet and the moons Europa, Ganymede and Callisto.

DOC.HEAD: $1,800 Suits _ And He Works For Arc Plumbing
With PM-Gotti Trial, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: To his lawyer, he's Johnny; to the media, the Dapper Don; to authorities, the Gambino crime family boss. Call him what you like, but John Joseph Gotti Jr. has captured the public imagination like no gangster since Capone. His acquittal Friday of conspiracy and assault in the shooting of a union official only added to his growing aura of invincibility, which started when predecessor Paul Castellano was gunned down in December 1985. Since that slaying, Gotti's beaten a pair of government cases while allegedly running the nation's most powerful mob organization. And he has become America's best-known crime figure. His penchant for $1,800 suits, silk shirts and diamond pinkie rings have contributed to his image as a throwback to the mobsters of old. Despite continual FBI surveillance, Gotti keeps a high profile, making daily trips to hangouts like the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club in the borough of Queens and the Ravenite Social Club in Manhattan. He dines out frequently and enjoys Italian food, as his stocky 5-foot-10 build attests. Phone taps have revealed Gotti to be hot-tempered, with a taste for gambling. Many of his friends and reputed crime associates date to his childhood; one of them is actor Ray Sharkey, who portrayed mob boss Sonny Steelgrave on the television show ``Wiseguy.'' Sharkey and Gotti grew up in the same Brooklyn neighborhood. They ate together at a restaurant recently after they hugged and kissed in court. ``What do you think _ (defense lawyer) Bruce Cutler is my only friend?'' Gotti told reporters who expressed surprise. Gotti, who turns 50 in October, lives with his wife of 29 years, Victoria. All agree he is a devoted family man, though law enforcement officials say the family to whom he is devoted is the Gambino organization. In 1979, Gotti suffered a family tragedy _ the death of his 12-year-old son Frank, who was riding a motorbike when he was struck by a neighbor's car. The accident was a tragedy for the neighbor, too: He disappeared four months later and has never been found. Authorities say another death _ no accident _ vaulted Gotti into the position of capo di tutti capi: the bold executions of Castellano and bodyguard Thomas Bilotti outside a Manhattan steak house on Dec. 16, 1985. No one has ever been charged with his murder. But within days of the Castellano hit, police detectives reported seeing 100 organized crime figures paying their respects to Gotti. Since then, his lifestyle has been consistent with the stereotypical image of a Mafia don. He travels in a black stretch Mercedes, and he wears his expensive suits with matching ties and handkerchiefs. Yet Gotti claims he is a salesman for the Arc Plumbing & Heating Co. of Queens. His attorney, Cutler, says Gotti is ``nothing more than an upfront guy who doesn't fit into their preconceptions of a nine-to-fiver.'' ``So he didn't go to Harvard. So he gambled a little. That makes him a mob leader?'' asked Cutler. ``The government is very, very resentful of his popularity, jealous of him.'' There is no questioning Gotti's popularity in his Queens neighborhood. He returned like a conquering hero after his acquittal on racketeering charges in 1987; during the carpenters union assault trial, local merchants strung a banner across 101st Street wishing him luck. Every year, he funds a Fourth of July street party in Queens; hordes of police have tried to stop the fireworks there, to no avail. Gotti reputedly earned his mob stripes with the 1973 slaying of James McBratney in a Staten Island bar. He did two years in jail for the slaying after pleading guilty to attempted manslaughter in a plea-bargaining agreement. During the 1960s, Gotti was jailed twice: one year for grand larceny and 3{ years for hijacking. But lately, his legal luck has changed. His only convictions in the past five years are traffic violations; with Cutler's help, he beat a massive federal racketeering and conspiracy case. The Dapper Don also beat an assault charge when the alleged victim _ after finding out who Gotti was _ testified he was unable to identify his attackers. ``I Forgotti!'' headlined the New York Post after the 1986 trial. The victories apparently convinced Gotti he had become the Teflon Don, untouchable by the authorities. Gotti never even flinched when dozens of law enforcement officers swooped down to arrest him last year for the union shooting. An unflustered Gotti surveyed the situation and said: ``Three-to-one odds I beat this.'' Once again, he was right.

DOC.HEAD: International Reform Leaders Exchange Strategies
DOC.TEXT: The democratic uprisings that have swept three continents stunned the world with their apparent suddenness, but reform leaders say those impressions are misleading. ``The struggle for democratic freedoms is always long and never easy,'' said Li Lu, a Chinese student leader who is on his country's most wanted list and was forced to flee after the massacre of protesters in Beijing last spring. Non-violent reform was the focus Friday as about 180 political leaders, scholars and journalists from around the world met for the first time to discuss the dramatic changes in recent months from the Berlin Wall to Soweto. ``Everyone here is representative of different movements that are constantly in the headlines,'' said Roger Powers of the Cambridge-based Albert Einstein Institution, sponsor of the three-day conference. ``Our contention is that you can't understand international politics today without understanding nonviolent methods because those methods are behind the changes going on everywhere around the world,'' he said. Leaders and scholars of democratic movements in China, South Africa, the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and elsewhere spent the day exchanging strategies and stories of reform. ``One of the principles of non-violence is to weigh down the opponent until you outlast the resistance,'' said Patrick Lekota, a leader of the United Democratic Front of South Africa. ``Each campaign is a springboard for advance.'' In South Africa, he said, boycotts, strikes and external political, economic and moral pressure have taken the democratic movement a long way toward fundamental reforms. President F.W. de Klerk made history last week by announcing the most sweeping reforms since the country's apartheid system was put in place in 1948. But Lekota said those changes were set in motion long before de Klerk announced his dramatic initiatives, which include the planned release of jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and the lifting of a ban on more than 20 outlawed anti-apartheid groups. ``De Klerk did not just wake up one day with a heart of gold,'' he said. ``It was our steady pressure that took us to the point where he could no longer ignore us.'' Lu, who is studying at Columbia University, said the story in China has been somewhat different but the movement's impact cannot be overlooked and must not be misunderstood. ``The goal of the students was to make the people aware of their situation,'' Lu said. ``... The next step is real, practical change.'' Such changes could also be spurred by the recent popular uprisings across the Soviet bloc and radical changes in the Soviet Union, where this week the Communists voted to end one-party rule, Lu said. ``We have a very conservative dictatorship in China,'' he said. ``But they no longer have anywhere to hide. The changes are everywhere around them.'' Among the other panelists participating in Friday's session were Raymundas Rayatskas, one of the founders of Lithuanian Popular Front, and U Tin Maung Win, a leader of the Committee for the Restoration of Democracy in Burma. Activists said the roads had been long and pitted for non-violent movements that stretch back to the Chinese Cultural Revolution of the 1960s, the Prague Spring of 1968 or the Soweto riots of 1976. Political transformation is seldom swift, but the boycotts, rallies and marches are fired by necessity, experts said. ``When people are poor, their stomachs empty and their minds oppressed, they have no choice but to use non-violence as a weapon,'' said Mubarak Awad of the Palestinian Center for the Study of Nonviolence.

DOC.HEAD: Rooney Alleges An Organized Campaign Against Him
DOC.TEXT: Andy Rooney, the humorist suspended from CBS News, says his troubles came about because ``gays decided to charge me with racism.'' Rooney said in a column distributed Friday that he was uncertain about damage done to him by racial comments attributed to him in a gay magazine. Rooney, who earlier was defended by former CBS news anchor Walter Cronkite, also received support Friday from Fred W. Friendly, a former president of CBS News. Rooney was interviewed by Chris Bull, a reporter with The Advocate, a biweekly magazine based in Los Angeles. He was quoted as saying that ``most people are born with equal intelligence, but blacks have watered down their genes because the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most children. They drop out of school early, do drugs and get pregnant.'' ``I not only deny the quote attributed to me, I say the quotation was made up by a young reporter who couldn't take notes,'' Rooney wrote in his column. Bull, the reporter, said earlier this week that his quotations of Rooney, taken down during a phone interview three weeks ago, were accurate. He did not tape the interview. Rooney planned to continue writing his twice-weekly syndicated humor column, which he said is distributed to about 260 newspapers. Rooney has worked in news and entertainment at CBS for 40 years and has been the resident humorist at ``60 Minutes'' since 1978. He previously got in hot water with gay groups with a remark he made in a Dec. 28 CBS special, ``A Year With Andy Rooney: 1989.'' In that show, he said that, ``many of the ills which kill us are self-induced,'' and then cited ``too much alcohol, too much food, homosexual unions, cigarettes.'' In his column distributed Friday, Rooney wrote, ``It is not clear yet to me whether I have been destroyed or not, but I know that a denial from anyone does not carry anywhere near the same weight as an accusation. The accusation against me came from an angry gay organization which had decided that, while the media might be relatively indifferent to the complaint of gays that they has been wronged, it is difficult for any news organization to stand up against a charge of racism. So, in their organized campaign against me _ hundreds of letters were addressed to ``CBS National News'' _ gays decided to charge me with racism. ``Now they're angry because the race issue got me and the homosexual issue did not. ``For all the hurt to me, I am even sorrier for the hurt to gays, blacks and CBS News. None of them needs more trouble.'' Friendly, now director of the Columbia University Seminars on Media and Society, said in defending Rooney, ``Some of us who have known Andy Rooney for 50 years _ 48 in my case _ know that Andy is blunt in talking the truth. If Andy Rooney said he never said that, I would believe it.''

DOC.HEAD: Traditional Women's Costume Reappears in Vietnamese Schools
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen years after the Communist takeover, the ao dai, a traditional costume, is making a comeback in Vietnamese schools, the Vietnam News Agency reported. Increasing numbers of schoolgirls in Ho Chi Minh City have been wearing the long, flowing white garment, which was the traditional school uniform until 1975, the agency reported. Until that year, Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, was the capital of the U.S.-backed government of South Vietnam. A modified version of the ao dai has reappeared as a school uniform for girls since last year, according to the report, monitored in Bangkok. The re-adoption of the ao dai in schools comes under an effort by authorities in Ho Chi Minh City to restore and develop national identity, the report said. The agency quoted a 17-year-old student, Duong Thi Thanh Thanh, as saying she ``saw in the white robe the symbol of both the physical beauty and the finest virtues of Vietnamese women.''

DOC.HEAD: Hunger, Snipers Target Beirut Residents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also ran in Saturday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: A wizened old man brandishing a plastic bag containing six half-baked loaves of bread shouts ``1,000 pounds! Who pays higher?'' ``1,200,'' said a hungry resident of the Christian enclave, lunging at the bag. The $2.50 price tag, five times the regular amount, enrages the other four men bidding for the scarce commodity and they chase the auctioneer away with shouts of ``Thief! Thief!'' Shelves in the few grocery stories that were open in the Furn el-Shubbak and neighboring Ein Rummaneh residential areas, hard-hit by fighting between rival Christian forces, were nearly empty Friday. Hunger drove some residents to brave the sniper fire at the crossing point between the Christian enclave and the city's Moslem sector, and dozens of pushcart fruit and vegetable vendors did a roaring business in the area. Since fighting broke out Jan. 30, at least 418 people have been killed, most of them non-combatants. Almost 1,700 have been wounded in the worst intra-Christian fighting in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. The new confrontation lines between renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's 19,000 troops and Christian warlord Samir Geagea's 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces militia have kept food distributors off the streets. The troops are battling for control of the Christian enclave north and northeast of Beirut. Tree branches, pieces of corrugated tin, shrapnel and glass shards cover mines planted by the Lebanese Forces at entrances to Furn el-Shubbak and Ein Rummaneh to block a possible tank thrust by Aoun's troops. The camouflage is to protect those living in the area from inadvertently stepping on a mine, while blowing up any tank trying to venture forward. No cars can enter these areas. Pedestrians wave hysterically at civilians driving toward the mined strip: ``Don't drive any closer and when you walk keep your eyes on the ground. Watch out for suspicious-looking objects.'' Lebanese Forces militiamen lurking on street corners and toting Soviet-made AK-47 assault rifles prevent reporters and photographers from taking pictures without a visit to their Kassardjian barracks in Ein Rummaneh ``for a permit.'' The base withstood dozens of tank charges in the past 11 days. These assaults caused colossal damage in Ein Rummaneh and Furn el-Shubbak because tanks pounded every building that their crewmen suspected of harboring militiamen. ``Tell the general he will have to roll his tanks over our dead bodies before he can get into Ein Rummaneh,'' one Lebanese Forces official said. Militiamen driving a reporter through the area kept the windows rolled down but swerved and zigzagged like madmen ``because Aoun's men are lurking there, only a few meters away.'' The two areas look as if a hurricane raged through their streets. Nearly every boutique has been gutted. Clothes lie in shreds on pockmarked streets covered with soot, debris and metal bars. The facades of apartment buildings are marred with gaping holes ringed with black soot. They line narrow, nearly deserted alleys filled with bullet-riddled cars. Dejected civilians in Ein Rummaneh's Ghannoum Street, a confrontation line with Aoun's troops, were mopping up water that flooded their 12-square-yard shelter when a shell burst the water tanks. ``We had to sleep on soggy mattresses and the already-cold shelter grew colder,'' Francis Yahshoushi said. ``We didn't have any water left except in a few cannisters. For drinking water we boiled the water we had stored on kerosene stoves. We nearly choked on the kerosene fumes,'' he added. A day after the loss of the precious water, Yahshoushi said, a shell hit the first floor of the building, causing a fire that spread to the entrance of the building. ``Had it not been for the rain, all 57 of us would have suffocated,'' he said. ``We placed pieces of cloth soaked with water on the faces of the children.''

DOC.HEAD: Quake Hits Chinese Coastal Area
DOC.TEXT: A moderately strong earthquake hit coastal China north of Shanghai early today, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, the official Xinhua News Agency said. The quake, measuring 5.1 on the Richter scale, was centered east of Changshu City in Jiangsu province, about 56 miles northwest of Shanghai. It was felt in Shanghai, the provincial capital of Nanjing and the cities of Wuxi and Nantong. China is one of the world's most quake-prone lands. Among recent tremors, three were killed in November when the southwest province of Sichuan was hit by quakes measuring up to 5.4 on the Richter scale, and at least 29 died in a series of heavy tremors registering up to 6.1 in northern China's Shanxi province in October. The Richter scale gauges the energy released by an earthquake measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 5 can cause considerable damage in a populated area. One measuring 6 can cause severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Low Gray Whale Numbers Puzzle Authorities
DOC.TEXT: Mexican authorities say they are trying to figure out why fewer gray whales than usual are showing up in Baja California waters to give birth this year. ``It will have to be researched,'' said Graciela de la Garza, head of conservation for the Department of Ecology and Urban Development. Marine mammal experts said 2,000 whales could be expected to enter the lagoons during a normal calving season, but Mexican authorities interviewed Thursday and Friday said only 12 to 20 whales have been spotted. A U.S. group said Friday that 40 to 60 whales were spotted in recent days at San Ignacio, one of four bays the whales use for breeding. De la Garza said it was the first time such low numbers had been observed so late in the season. However, Anelio Aguayo, a marine mammal expert at the National University in Mexico City, cautioned that there are frequently ``transitory'' variations in the numbers of whales in the different lagoons. ``We need to wait for the end of the season and then see what the outcome is,'' he said. The whales use the Vizcaino Biosphere Reserve, a 6-million-acre protected zone, because high salt content helps pregnant females float and give birth, said Jorge Hernandez, a marine biologist for a committee that oversees the reserve. They calve in the bays of San Ignacio, Guerrero Negro, Magdalena and Ojo de Liebre, or Eye of the Hare, known to whale fans in the United States as Scammon's Lagoon. The whales usually begin arriving in the first week of November. By April, most have left for Alaskan waters, Hernandez said. But the few that arrived this year didn't start appearing until mid-December, said Ulises Cesena Montano, the reserve's interagency coordinator. ``We don't know the reasons. There are only hypotheses,'' he said. The Group of 100, an ecological group of Mexican artists and intellectuals, has suggested that an industrial salt plant in the reserve's buffer zone may be damaging water quality or that the whales may have been affected by the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaskan waters last year. But de la Garza and Cesena discounted those ideas. Cesena said the prevailing theory is that an unusual cold current is keeping the whales away from their accustomed warm-water haunts. In places the current is less than a mile from land, he said. The temperature, strength and exact route of the current, dubbed the Corriente de la Nina, are still being studied, and an aerial search is being conducted for whales in the Pacific, Hernandez said. ``Once the cold water is past, maybe the whales will appear,'' Cesena said. He said only 20 whales have been spotted so far; de la Garza said the number could be as low as 12. But Mark Palmer, conservation director of Ocean Alliance, based in Oakland, Calif., said in a telephone interview that a group of whalewatchers sponsored by Oceanic Society Expeditions has observed 40 to 60 gray whales in the San Ignacio lagoon in recent days. De la Garza said the variations are not necessarily cause for alarm. ``There can be delays in any species' migration,'' she said. The species was hunted to the verge of extinction, but recovered substantially after hunting was prohibited following World War I. Palmer said the gray whale population is estimated at 17,000 to 20,000 from studies conducted over several years. He said the varying figures suggest a need for a better survey. ``In one part of the lagoons they probably don't have a good overall picture,'' Palmer said.

DOC.HEAD: After Years of Bannings, Activists Are Free at Last
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Since 1956, the government has charged Helen Joseph with treason, detained her repeatedly, placed her under house arrest and made it a crime to quote her. But the 84-year-old white anti-apartheid activist survived 34 years of bannings and on Feb. 2 became one of nearly 500 people, living and dead, whose restrictions were lifted by President F.W. de Klerk. ``I didn't think I'd see this day,'' Mrs. Joseph said, adding that she was a bit disappointed the government no longer considered her a threat. ``I'm a stubborn old bag and I wasn't expecting things to change.'' Police restrictions have been a way of life for many anti-apartheid activists. Hundreds detained without charge during the 3{-year-old state of emergency were released but then placed under virtual house arrest. The restrictions varied, but often prohibited the activists from leaving their neighborhoods, required them to be home each night, prevented them from attending meetings or participating in politics, and often made it impossible to hold a job. Zwelakhe Sisulu, son of recently released African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu, was freed from prison in December 1988 after two years in detention. But he had to report daily to police and was unable to resume his job as editor of the New Nation newspaper until de Klerk rescinded his restriction order. Few have endured as much as Mrs. Joseph, a former social worker and union official now confined to a wheelchair much of the time. The government charged Mrs. Joseph, ANC leader Nelson Mandela and more than 150 others with treason in 1956 for their anti-apartheid activities. All were acquitted in a trial that lasted until 1961. However, Mrs. Joseph, a divorcee with no children, remained under a banning order and in 1962 became the first South African placed under house arrest. For the next nine years, police were the only visitors allowed to enter her comfortable white house with a red roof and a flower-filled garden in a Johannesburg suburb. Her house arrest ended in 1971 while she was undergoing a cancer operation, but until Feb. 2 she remained a ``listed'' person, meaning she could not be quoted in South Africa. She has been arrested numerous times, most recently in 1983 when she sang a freedom song and gave a clenched-fist, black power salute while attending a treason trial. As part of his reform program, de Klerk lifted the police orders on 374 people who had been restricted after their release from detention. He also removed the names of all 110 people who had been ``listed'' and could not be quoted. Many of the listed people are either dead or have left South Africa. They include: _Most of the African National Congress leadership, such as President Oliver Tambo, who is recovering from a stroke in Sweden. _Donald Woods, whose book ``Biko,'' about the life and death of black activist Steve Biko was made into a movie ``Cry Freedom'' three years ago. Woods now lives in London. _Numerous whites, including Anne Heymann, who died of pneumonia Feb. 3 at the age of 66, and her husband, Isaac Heymann, who died of cancer four days later at the age of 79. The Heymanns, both listed since the 1960s, lived only a few blocks from Mrs. Joseph and often visited her at her front gate during the years when she wasn't allowed guests inside her home. ``So many people suffered for so many years,'' Mrs. Joseph said. ``I'm not grateful (for the lifting of the restrictions). It was not an act of compassion. It never should have been done in the first place.'' Despite failing health, she occasionally travels to anti-government protests, such as an ANC rally last October in the township of Soweto, where she received a rousing cheer from the mostly black crowd of 70,000. Mrs. Joseph, whose requests to visit Mandela were repeatedly denied, finally was granted permission and the two met last Dec. 21 for the first time in 28 years. ``He looked different after so many years, but then so did I,'' Mrs. Joseph said. ``He was in very good form, full of jokes, full of laughter.'' Four days later, Mrs. Joseph had Christmas dinner with Walter Sisulu and dozens of other activists at the home of a friend. After her house arrest was lifted, she began a tradition of making a toast at noon on Christmas to remember all the anti-apartheid activists who were in exile, in prison or had died. Word of the tradition had spread to exiles and prisoners, and Sisulu told Mrs. Joseph it was observed during his years in jail. She hopes one day all the activists will be able to hold a Christmas toast together in South Africa, but she doubts she'll be around to take part. ``I don't think I'll see the end of apartheid, but I'll see it diminish,'' she said. ``You can't wash away 300 years of cruelty and injustice overnight.''

DOC.HEAD: Junior High Student Honored for Stand Against Gangs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Norvell Smith is a 14-year-old freedom fighter in her own neighborhood. Approached by tough gang recuiters at age 12, she decided to resist _ a decision that has won her top honors at school. Norvell travels mean streets to and from John Hope Community Academy, streets where wearing the wrong color, or just walking home, can be a fatal mistake. In January, a 13-year-old classmate was killed in after-school crossfire between rival gangs, the second student slain while going to or from the public junior high school in the past six years. ``I lived in a gang environment all my life,'' Norvell, the youngest of seven children raised by a single mother, said Friday. ``My momma told us to stay away from all those bad ideas and get an education _ and that's what we're doing.'' Last week the school, with the help of a drug- and gang-prevention program called Project Serve, held a ``Drug and Gang Awareness Super Bowl'' to honor students who are working to end the violence. And seventh-grader Norvell was the show-stopper at an assembly of the school's 950 students. ``You could hear almost a pin drop _ that's how good it was,'' eighth-grade teacher Jacqueline Cooney said of the girl's award-winning speech. In the speech, Norvell told her classmates: ``I'm sick and tired of these people coming into our neighborhoods, frightening our friends and families and putting ideas into our little brothers' and sisters' minds that gangs are cool. ``I say, the only thing that you can get out of being in a gang is a hole in your head or 6 feet under _ take your choice.'' John Hope Community Academy, in the city's South Side Englewood neighborhood, straddles an invisible line dividing the turf of two gangs. The rules for survival along that boundary are sometimes deceptively simple, students say. ``You don't go to that side of the boulevard, and if you do, you can't wear blue and black _ you have to wear red and black and wear caps to the left,'' explains 12-year-old Kinisha Gaston. Assistant Principal Jim Murray acknowledged that when students leave school property, they face harassment by gang recruiters _ often high school students. But Murray said the school is making some inroads with the help of programs like Project Serve, in which off-duty law-enforcement officials work to educate students about the dangers of drugs and gangs. ``Our students _ the vast majority of them _ do not get involved in the gang community,'' he said. ``The children tune in to what is being said and they respond positively.'' Norvell said Friday that students who join gangs do so ``because they have low self esteem (and) want to belong.'' She said she was approached two years ago, on a day when she missed her bus, by a group of threatening girl recruiters. ``I didn't want to be in a gang,'' Norvell said. ``I was thinking, `If I do this, I'm going to be ruined for life _ I'll miss out on everything.''' She told the girls she wouldn't join the gang, a vow she has repeated many times since. Since winning the ``Super Bowl'' this week, she said several gang members have told her they are thinking about her speech. Most students, Norvell said simply, ``don't want to join a gang and go to an early grave.''

DOC.HEAD: East Bloc Filmmakers Lack Ideas and Money Since Communists Fell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Since their Communist governments started crumbling, Eastern European filmmakers have found it harder to come up with story ideas. They don't have their leaders to kick around anymore, say filmmakers and distributors at the Miami Film Festival. ``Every good film in Eastern Europe was an anti-Communist idea,'' said Adrian Sarbu, chief of the Bureau of Cinema and Television for Romania's governing National Salvation Front. ``We have good filmmakers ... now we have to find the ideas.'' The fall of the Berlin Wall and the revolutions against hard-line Communism throughout the region have resulted in a vacuum for ideas, said Sarbu, who is attending the film festival, which opened Feb. 2 and ends Sunday. ``Before, we were kicking the Communists because it was popular. Now who are you going to kick?'' asked John Gluski of the American Institute of Polish Culture in Miami and a distributor of Polish films. ``Before, they didn't have good scripts because of censorship. Now there is no censorship and there are no scripts,'' Gluski, a native of Poland, said Thursday. The Soviet Union has been an exception, said Andrel Zinca, a native of Romania now with David Productions in Miami. After perestroika and glasnost _ Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies of restructuring and openness _ Soviet filmmakers produced some of the best films coming out of Europe, Zinca said. This year's Polish feature film at the Miami festival has a familiar anti-government theme, but it was completed prior to Solidarity's strong showing during free elections in June that forced the Communists out of power. ``The Last Ferry,'' set in the year 1981, is about a Solidarity activist carrying important documents to the West aboard a ship. When martial law is declared by the Communists, the ferry heads back to Poland, but the passengers jump overboard. The film won the grand prize at the National Film Festival in Gdansk, Poland. Another East bloc film at Miami's festival was ``The Rise and Fall of the Ceausescu Dynasty,'' Romania's first and only film released since the fall of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's regime in December. The film graphically depicts the violence from the popular and military overthrow. With the trial and execution of Ceausescu and his wife, the film nears its end with, ``These animals are, no longer.'' The irony is that Romania's first film since the revolution features the person Romanians would least like to see, Sarbu said. Romanians were exposed almost exclusively to Ceausescu and his propaganda for about two hours a day on their nation's only television station for the last seven years. Sarbu said the films censored by Ceausescu will eventually be released. He expects new films to follow one theme: ``We have to do politics in all of Eastern Europe.'' That will require artist in the East bloc to restructure their language, phraseology and thinking, he said. ``We must reinvent the language in all forms of art,'' Sarbu said Thursday. East bloc countries are not only short of ideas, but also money. Polish filmmakers can no longer rely on government subsidies, Gluski said. Like other East bloc counties, financing will have to come from their fledgling free markets. ``There is no money. You have to look for private financing,'' Gluski said. Gluski said a $5 million U.S.-produced film would cost $500,000 in Poland simply because of cheaper labor and other costs. ``There are people with talent. They have equipment. They have the artists. But they need the financial help to produce it,'' Gluski said.

DOC.HEAD: Singer-Songwriter Del Shannon an Apparent Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Del Shannon, who wrote and sang anguished rock songs in the 1960s, including the hits ``Runaway'' and ``Keep Searchin','' died from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 55. Shannon's wife, ``Bonnie'' LeAnne, found her husband's body Thursday night in the den of their home 35 miles northwest of Los Angeles, sheriff's Deputy Roger Hom said Friday. Hom said the death was being investigated as a possible suicide. Los Angeles County coroner's spokesman Bob Dambacher said an autopsy would be performed over the weekend. He said Shannon died from a .22-caliber bullet wound in the head. ``It had to be impulsive,'' said his lifelong friend and personal manager Dan Bourgoise. ``In the end, he must have felt alone. All the paranoid things that made him write those songs he wrote, like `Runaway,' _ I think he just ended up being that lonely guy.'' He said Shannon was nearing completion on a new album with Tom Petty's group, the Heartbreakers. ``I'm very saddened to have lost a friend,'' Petty said in a statement. ``Del was one of the true greats.'' Bourgoise said Shannon had been depressed recently. ``He was disoriented and he was sick and he started to do all kinds of worse-case scenarios in his head,'' Bourgoise said. ``He was lonelier than he should have been, with all the friends around him,'' Bourgoise said. He said his friend had fought drugs, depression and alcoholism as his career faltered, but had been sober since 1976. Singer Bobby Vee said he talked with Shannon last weekend before the two performed in Fargo, N.D., at an annual Buddy Holly memorial concert. Vee also said Shannon was despondent about going on a British tour and his recent move into a new house. ``I didn't realize the extent of his pain,'' Vee said. It had been years since Shannon, who was born Charles Westover in Coopersville, Mich., on Dec. 30, 1934, had a hit song or whirled around in the popularity frenzy that surrounded him in the 1960s. In Petty's recent hit ``Runnin' Down A Dream,'' he writes about listening to the radio while on a drive: ``Me and Del were singin' little `Runaway.' I was flyin'.'' In the movie ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Tom Cruise's character sings a bit of ``Runaway'' along with Shannon's recording in a bar. Shannon learned to play guitar at 13, entertained in high school and, after a two-year stint in the Army, began playing clubs in his home state of Michigan. An Ann Arbor disc jockey who heard him set up an audition and Shannon flew to New York to record ``Runaway'' for Big Top records. It was his strong falsetto choruses on his hits, including ``Hats Off To Larry,'' that became Shannon's trademark during the height of his career. With the late Roy Orbison, Shannon set a groove for American rock in the early 1960s with country-influenced pop ballads, and like Orbison he was swept aside by the British music invasion. Ironically, it was the British who most admired the talent of Shannon, who had an appearance with the Beatles at the Royal Albert Hall and was voted by several polls as the most popular male singer in Britain in 1962 and 1963. His other Top 20 singles included ``Hats Off to Larry,'' ``Little Town Flirt'' and ``Keep Searchin'.'' Shannon and his wife of 27 years, Shirley, divorced and he married the former ``Bonnie'' LeAnne Gutierrez in 1987. He leaves three grown children by his first wife _ son Craig and daughters Kym and Jody, Bourgoise said.

DOC.HEAD: Board Plans 10 Most Wanted Safety Rules
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board plans to produce its own ``10 most wanted'' recommendations in an effort to get government and industry to take more actions to protect travelers. The list will include the top proposals of the board for saving lives in air, land and sea transportation, newly confirmed board Chairman James L. Kolstad said Friday. He said too many board recommendations are ignored. Kolstad, in an interview, acknowledged the five-member board's image has been ``somewhat tarnished'' in recent years and promised a firm but non-confrontational approach to public safety. The NTSB, which investigates all plane crashes and other major transportation accidents but cannot enforce its recommendations, has been plagued by a lack of trained investigators, a tight budget, low staff morale and bickering over leadership. Kolstad's confirmation by the Senate late Thursday ended 17 months of uncertainty for the board. Kolstad, who has been acting board chairman since August 1988 while he and former chairman Jim Burnett vied for the permanent post, said he expects his confirmation to end friction on the board. The chairman said he would work to improve the timeliness, quality and efficiency of board efforts to ensure safety of the nation's transportation systems, focusing much of its efforts on what he said are the nation's most pressing safety problems. ``Instead of shoveling out hundreds of recommendations a year and treating all of them the same, at least we would have 10 that Congress, the public and industry know are the ones the NTSB feels are the most important,'' he said. Kolstad finally moved into Burnett's office this week, while Burnett remains on the five-seat board. The Senate also confirmed former Federal Railroad Administration deputy Susan Coughlin as the newest board member, replacing Lee Dickinson. One seat, which belonged to the late Joseph T. Nall, awaits a presidential nomination. The other board member is John Lauber. The board has not added a new staff position in 4{ years. President Bush's requested $30.9 million budget for fiscal 1991 would add 22 posts, but the independent agency now has fewer employees than it had in the late 1970s when there were fewer accidents. Still, transportation safety has improved over the years, Kolstad said, and there are more accidents now because people are traveling more. He defended his leadership style, which has been contrasted with that of the tough-talking Burnett, who failed to win Senate approval when former President Reagan nominated him for a fourth term as chairman. ``My style is to ensure that both the government and the industry understand the reason for our recommendations. ... I've never felt that it's effective to do this through a confrontational style,'' Kolstad said. ``I want to see our recommendations become more realistic, and I think we can do that with a two-way communication with all segments of the transportation industry,'' he said. But Kolstad said he would criticize the Federal Aviation Administration or other agencies if necessary and would continue to send teams to investigate any safety lapses. ``We're still going to continue to have a firm oversight and we're going to call the shots as we see them,'' he said, adding, ``Watch what we do more than what I say.''

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Official's Resignation Raises Doubts on Federal Bailout
LaserPhoto NY74
DOC.TEXT: The resignation of a key official in President Bush's beleaguered savings and loan bureaucracy is worsening fears the government may be botching the selling of failed thrifts and their repossessed real estate. Daniel P. Kearney, chief staff officer of the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board, quit Friday after complaining the board wasn't giving him the authority he needed to do his job. The resignation is ``more evidence of the growing disarray in the Bush administration,'' said Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee. He predicted delay in dealing with failed S&Ls would increase the taxpayer cost of the bailout. Economist Paul Getman of Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said bureaucratic infighting is also heightening concern that an overhang of government-owned real estate will depress property prices in some areas. ``It means that if they're not selling much (real estate) now, when they finally get around to selling, the glut may be worse than people feared,'' he said. The board said late Friday that it was naming William Taylor to replace Kearney on an acting basis. The brief statement gave no reason for Kearney's departure, saying only that Taylor, who is head of the Federal Reserve Board's banking regulation division, would take over immediately at the RTC. The oversight board, created to set policy for government thrift rescues, is composed of three officials: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who serves as chairman; Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan; and Jack Kemp, secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The board has a small staff under Kearney. However, the work of the bailout is performed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., an independent regulatory agency. ``What's happened, in a nutshell, is that Congress has set up an organization with responsibilities, overnight, far larger than Citicorp,'' the nation's largest bank, said Rep. Jim Leach of Iowa, the senior Republican on the banking committee. Recent congressional hearings have focused on the tension between the oversight board and the FDIC, but Kearney's resignation underscores reported infighting between the Treasury Department and the oversight board staff, ``It's an awkward structure. ... On top of that, Treasury has played a particularly assertive role of the three institutions represented on the board,'' Leach said. Kearney did not directly respond to those reports in his statement, but said his job ``does not currently afford me the authority that I believe is essential to be effective.'' The resignation likely will add momentum to a proposal by Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., to disband the oversight board. ``Kearney .... faced bureaucratic hurdles that no one could overcome,'' said Vento, who heads a House task force monitoring the bailout. ``His resignation only serves to confirm (that) ... the oversight board should be abolished.'' Kearney, who served at HUD and the Office of Management and Budget during the Ford and Nixon administrations, was hired as oversight board president in October. His last job was pension fund adviser for Aldrich, Eastman & Waltch Inc. in Boston. Art Siddon, a Treasury spokesman, had no immediate comment on the resignation. ``The RTC has accomplished nothing, and has cost taxpayers millions of dollars. Perhaps that is why Mr. Kearney quit,'' said Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill. ``The taxpayers would like to quit also, but unfortunately, that is not possible.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Promised US Support
DOC.TEXT: A leader of Angola's anti-communist rebels says the U.S. is assuring his forces will get continued American diplomatic and material support. Jeremias Chitunda, vice president of the UNITA rebels, met with Under Secretary of State Robert Kimmitt on Friday as the group is facing perhaps its severest battlefield test in 15 years of fighting. The U.S.-backed UNITA has been battling a government offensive in an area of southeast Angola that has been in rebel hands for years. Most of the fighting has been centered on the town of Mavinga. ``We appreciate very much the sensitivity, the understanding that is manifest here towards the urgency and the seriousness of the intensity of the offensive,'' Chitunda said in an interview. He was not specific about the nature of the assistance he was promised. The State Department had no immediate comment on the meeting. On Tuesday, Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos claimed victory in the battle for Mavinga but Chitunda said that statement was not true. U.S. officials have said that government forces control the airport but that most of the surrounding area continues to be held by UNITA. Angola is one conflict that has not been affected by the recent improvement in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. Kremlin military aid is believed to be in the range of $600 million to $800 million, according to officials, and U.S. arms aid to UNITA totals about $50 million. Thirteen senators sent a message to Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Moscow earlier this week demanding he ``object strongly'' to the Soviet role in the seven-week-old military offensive. Chitunda said he was told the Bush administration would make a serious effort to promote a cease-fire in Angola and to get peace talks under way. He said Cuban forces have become more involved than before in the offensive by assisting in the delivery of supplies to government combatants. The battle for Mavinga is the first major conventional military confrontation since South Africa agreed in December 1988 to halt support for UNITA and Cuba began a withdrawal of its troops backing government forces. UNITA wants a settlement based on direct negotiations leading to national elections. The government proposed an amnesty for the UNITA forces that would lead to their reintegration into Angolan society.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Filmmaker Francis Ford Coppola was ordered to pay $4.8 million in interest on a long-disputed debt to a financier, bringing his costs in the case to nearly $8 million. Coppola, the maker of ``The Cotton Club,'' ``Apocalypse Now'' and other films already is in bankruptcy proceedings he said were brought on by the debt dispute. Coppola was in Rome directing the third in his ``Godfather'' series about the Corleone crime family, and a spokesman here declined to comment. The dispute involves Jack Singer, a Canadian real estate developer who came to Coppola's rescue with a $3 million loan to help him complete ``One From the Heart,'' an expensive flop, in 1981. Robert Chapman, a lawyer for Singer who won the $4.8 million interest judgment in Superior Court Wednesday, said he also expects to ask for attorney's fees.

Susan Eisenhower, a granddaughter of the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower, married a Soviet space scientist and political reformer in a ceremony at the U.S. ambassador's residence. Tass, the only news agency admitted to the ceremony Friday, described it as a ``sensation.'' The bride, 38, wed Roald Sagdeev, 57, former head of the Space Research Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Sagdeev is a member of the Congress of People's Deputies, the Soviet parliament, and was an associate of Soviet human rights champion Andrei D. Sakharov. Sakharov's widow, Elena Bonner, attended the wedding, others who were present said. Eisenhower and Sagdeev met at a conference in the United States in 1987. The bride, who has her own consulting company, was married twice before and has three school-age children. Sagdeev has two grown children.

Former tennis pro Chris Evert, accepting an award in a White House ceremony, said she wants President Bush to stress physical education in schools. Bush on Friday awarded the Flo Hyman Award for excellence in sports to Evert on behalf of the Women and Girls in Sports Foundation. The award is given in memory of the Olympic volleyball star who died suddenly in 1986. Bush said the winner of 18 Grand Slam tournaments had ``represented not just the game of tennis, but your country. And you've done it so very well and with grace, dignity and good sportsmanship.'' Evert said she wanted to stress the importance of physical education in schools and sought the president's help in pushing that point as part of his education package.

The drunken-driving case against former fashion model Hazel Diane Moore, who helped the FBI arrest Washington Mayor Marion Barry, has been continued as lawyers try to make a deal. Ms. Moore, 38, also known as Rasheeda Moore, was to be arraigned March 2 in Van Nuys Municipal Court, under an order issued Friday by court Commissioner Mitchell Block. Ms. Moore, who did not appear in court, was arrested Jan. 1 for investigation of driving under the influence. Her blood alcohol level was 0.12 percent, over the legal limit of 0.08 percent, police said. Ms. Moore, a friend of Barry's, worked as an undercover informant for the FBI, calling Barry to a Washington hotel room where he was arrested Jan. 18 on cocaine charges. Ms. Moore's attorney, Ronald J. Lewis, said she probably will plead no contest at her arraignment, depending on the outcome of discussions with the city attorney's office.
DOC.NOTE: EDS: A version of the following item moved on sports wire
DOC.TEXT: Lisa Stawberry, wife of New York Mets outfielder Darryl Strawberry, met with prosecutors to discuss the domestic dispute that led to his arrest for allegedly threatening her with a gun. No decision about whether to file misdemeanor charges against Strawberry will be made until prosecutors can meet with him. He entered an alcohol rehabilitation program last weekend. City attorney's spokesman Mike Qualls said Lisa Strawberry, accompanied by her mother, spent about an hour in the informal hearing Friday at the Van Nuys branch of the Los Angeles City Attorney's office.

Two weeks ago Arnold Kephart was an Army deserter earning a meager living as a truck driver in East Germany. Now, his attorney says, he is under siege _ and camera lights _ in his own country. Reporters, talk-show producers, and movie-production companies want the life story of the man arrested here on a 30-year-old warrant for desertion after crashing a military truck, said James Martin Davis, Kephart's attorney. Kephart was arrested after returning here Jan. 30 with his East German-born, 12-year-old son, Frankie. He was held by the Army for a week, given a less-than-honorable discharge and released to a long-awaited reunion with relatives. Kephart's return to Omaha was on all three television network morning shows the day after his release. A London newspaper and a West German news magazine paid for interviews at undisclosed prices. Davis also heard from four production companies about movie deals. Kephart is taking all of the attention in stride, said Davis. ``He's just so happy to be back in the U.S.,'' Davis said. ``He's more impressed with popcorn than he is the newspapers.''

DOC.HEAD: Duggan to Bring Panel to Full Strength
DOC.TEXT: Ervin S. Duggan will fill the final vacant seat at the Federal Communications Commission, marking the first time in nearly three years that the agency has been at full strength. Duggan, 50, will be sworn in to the Democratic seat vacated last year by Patricia Diaz Dennis. His five-year term, which will be retroactive to last July, will expire in June 1994. Duggan, a Washington communications consultant and former speechwriter for President Lyndon Johnson, was confirmed by the Senate on a voice vote late Thursday. FCC spokeswoman Maureen Peratino said Duggan expects to resume his new office in early March. That will bring the commission up to full strength, five members, for the first time since April 1987. Senate Commerce Committee Chairman Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., had held up nominations to the commission during ideological tugs-of-war with two Reagan-era FCC chairmen, Dennis Patrick and Mark Fowler. Duggan described himself during the confirmation process as a ``family values candidate.'' Initial fears apparently waned that Duggan, who is national chairman of Presbyterians for Democracy and Religious Freedom, would be a tool of religious fundamentalists at the commission. Duggan told the Commerce Committee he was not a believer in ``heavy-handed regulation.'' ``I am well aware of the virtue of the free market and of robust competition,'' he said. ``But I do believe that government has a legitimate role to play in defense of the public's interest.''

DOC.HEAD: 73 Senators Oppose Cuts in Aid to Israel, Egypt
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-three senators say they will oppose any cuts in aid for Israel and Egypt, the largest recipients of U.S. assistance. ``In the Middle East, we should reaffirm the support of the United States for upholding our foreign assistance commitments to Israel and Egypt,'' the senators said in a letter organized by Sens. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., and Carl Levin, D-Mich. The senators' letter, delivered to the White House on Wednesday but not publicly released until Friday, was written in reaction to proposals _ first advanced by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. _ to trim aid to Israel, Egypt, Turkey, the Philippines and Pakistan. Those countries received about 80 percent of the total U.S. foreign aid budget. Dole said reducing money for the five countries by 5 percent would generate more money for other countries, namely those in Eastern Europe. The underlying proposal to redistribute aid has been supported by Sens. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, and Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations. Bush administration officials have called for more flexibility in dividing up the foreign-aid pie. The Bush budget for fiscal 1991 totals about $14 billion. Traditionally, Israel receives about $3 billion annually from the United States, with Egypt receiving about $2.3 billion. The 73 senators said they want to see the United States ``reinforce the democratic trends in the nations of Eastern Europe.'' ``Budgetary realities force us to make difficult choices, but retrenching on our commitment to assistance to Israel and Egypt would not be a wise choice,'' they wrote.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Jupiter-Bound Galileo Spacecraft Swings Past Venus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with spacecraft making closest approach to Venus; picks up 4th graf, `That started ...' Stands for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY86
DOC.TEXT: The Galileo spaceship swooped past Venus early Saturday, and the cloud-shrouded planet acted as a gravity slingshot to help hurl the craft toward its 1995 rendezvous with Jupiter. Engineers at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory received a radio signal confirming that the 2.8-ton spacecraft made its closest approach to Venus at 12:59 a.m. EST, cruising 10,028 miles above the planet's hellishly hot surface. ``We have just flown through our closest approach point to Venus,'' said Bill O'Neil, science and mission design manager. ``The greatest challenge of getting Galileo to Jupiter has been met.'' Four hours before the close encounter, radio signals received on Earth confirmed the spacecraft computer ordered Galileo's infrared light sensor to start observing Venus. The instrument was looking for the glow of the hot lower atmosphere backlighting cooler clouds overhead, O'Neil said. That started an eight-hour period of intensive photography and measurements, including a photographic search for lightning. Earlier Friday, Galileo studied dust particles and magnetic fields in space, and measured Venusian atmospheric temperatures. ``The Venus encounter is our first major milestone in the mission,'' said Galileo project scientist Torrence Johnson. ``After the encounter, we have gained enough energy out of this celestial billiard shot to get the energy we need to make it all the way to Jupiter.'' The power the spacecraft gains in the flyby is triple the energy of its propellant supply, said mission director Neal Ausman. The $1.35 billion mission will let Galileo examine Earth, its moon and one or two asteroids before the spacecraft separates into an orbiter and a small probe in July 1995. In December 1995, they arrive at Jupiter, the solar system's largest planet, after a 2.4-billion-mile trip, including 182 million miles to reach Venus. Galileo was deployed from the space shuttle Atlantis last Oct. 18. Venus circles the sun between the orbits of Earth and Mercury, the closest planet to the sun. Acid-laden clouds extend 40 miles above the surface, trapping heat in a runaway ``greenhouse effect'' that raised surface temperatures to 900 degrees Fahrenheit. Atmospheric pressure is 90 times that on Earth. Venus is about 95 percent as wide as Earth. Scientists suspect it may have active volcanoes and shifting plates on its crust. The Venus flyby was designed purely to give Galileo a boost for its trip to Jupiter by increasing its speed from 83,750 mph to 88,740 mph. In two other ``gravity assist'' maneuvers, the spacecraft will use the Earth as a slingshot next Dec. 8 and again on Dec. 8, 1992, so it will be properly aimed toward Jupiter, Ausman said. Scientists decided to take advantage of the Venus encounter by having Galileo's camera and instruments make photographs and measurements of Venus starting Thursday night and continuing for a week. But almost all the pictures and data _ stored on three tracks of Galileo's four-track tape recorder _ won't be sent back to Earth until October, when the spacecraft is close enough to transmit the material with its low-gain antenna. That antenna now can be used only for communications to keep Galileo operating. Galileo's main umbrella-shaped antenna must remain furled to protect it from sunlight until after the craft makes its first flight past Earth. Galileo was programmed to photograph Venus and study the planet with its ultraviolet, infrared and visible light sensors to look for lightning, study the makeup of the carbon dioxide atmosphere, examine cloud and wind patterns, map cloudtop temperatures and peer at the lower atmosphere. Sensors that detect particles and magnetic fields were programmed to study how solar wind interacts with Venus' atmosphere. At the same time, NASA arranged for the Pioneer Venus Orbiter, circling Venus since 1978, to make similar measurements closer to the planet, Johnson said. While nearly 20 other U.S. and Soviet spacecraft have visited Venus, ``we think we're going to get some real good stuff,'' he said. But scientists won't know for months unless engineers meet success next week when they try to have Galileo send back a small amount of data, Johnson added. Studies from Earth and previous spacecraft indicate Venus has continent-sized highlands with peaks dwarfing Mount Everest and hundreds of thousands of volcanoes stretching across lowland plains. NASA's Magellan spacecraft, launched from Atlantis last May 4, will go into orbit around Venus in August. It will use radar to peer through the clouds and map at least 70 percent of Venus' surface during a $550 million mission. When the Galileo probe and orbiter reach Jupiter, the probe will parachute into the atmosphere and make measurements until intense heat and pressure vaporize it. The orbiter will photograph and study Jupiter and its major moons until late 1997, circling the planet instead of flying past it like the Pioneer and Voyager spacecraft. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration originally planned to send Galileo on a two-year trip to Jupiter by launching it with a Centaur rocket after it was released from a shuttle. But the 1986 explosion that destroyed Challenger and killed seven crew members raised safety concerns. NASA decided against using the volatile, liquid-fueled Centaur. So Galileo was launched with a much weaker Inertial Upper Stage booster after it was deployed by Atlantis' crew. The weaker rocket required NASA to redesign Galileo's route so the craft could utilize gravity from Venus and Earth for a much longer, looping trip to Jupiter. Environmentalists failed in court to stop NASA from having a shuttle carry Galileo into space. They feared a Challenger-like explosion could contaminate Florida with plutonium in Galileo's nuclear batteries, which are not reactors but generate electricity using heat from the radioactive decay of plutonium. NASA said the risk was minimal. Galileo is named for the Italian Renaissance astronomer who discovered Jupiter's major moons.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Ambassador Says U.S. Needs Troops in Europe
RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator.
With PM-Baker-Soviet Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers are complaining they are having a hard time explaining to constituents why deeper cuts can't be made in U.S. troop strength in Europe. ``The logic of all this is getting very hard to explain to taxpayers,'' Sen. Larry Pressler, R-S.D., told William H. Taft IV, U.S. ambassador to NATO, on Friday. President Bush's proposed 1991 ``defense budget does not recognize anything that has happened in the world in the past six months,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. ``We must be creative and responsive, and I don't think at this point we are either.'' Taft told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that American forces in Europe's central zone will not be reduced below 195,000, even if the Soviets pull back every soldier they have in the region. Even without a direct and immediate Soviet threat, he said, U.S. troops are needed as a visible sign of continued American commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and European security. ``We have to have visible soldiers walking around?'' Pressler asked. ``That's going to be hard for me to sell in South Dakota.'' Pressler, echoing concerns of committee colleagues, said prosperous U.S. allies such as France and West Germany should shoulder a larger share of the defense burden, and the United States should be able to reap some defense savings because of Moscow's rapidly shrinking sphere of influence. Taft said it was clear that the threat to Western Europe has greatly diminished, both because of the changes in Eastern Europe and because of the new treaty limiting intermediate-range nuclear forces. But Taft said the 195,000-troop figure Bush proposed in his State of the Union speech last month is a rock-bottom number because it ``looks right to the president's military advisers.'' ``For the foreseeable future, NATO's strategy of deterrence for the prevention of war, based upon both nuclear and conventional forces, remains the best way to prevent war and protect our freedom,'' Taft said.

DOC.HEAD: United Germany Could Stay With NATO, But Special Status for East
DOC.TEXT: A united Germany could stay with the NATO alliance and still carve out a special military status for the present territory of East Germany, alliance officials and analysts say. The overriding concern for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is that a reunified Germany maintain its ties to the West. NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner, a West German, says there is ``no acceptable alternative to Germany remaining anchored in the Atlantic alliance.'' The New York Times today reported that U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III suggested a single Germany with less than full membership in NATO might be acceptable. ``We favor a continued membership in, or association with, NATO,'' the newspaper quoted Baker as saying in Moscow, where he was meeting with Soviet officials. He did not elaborate. East German Premier Hans Modrow has suggested that a combined nation be neutral. West Germany belongs to the 16-nation NATO, and East Germany is one of the seven countries in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. But U.S. and NATO officials have dismissed the idea of such a large neutral state in Europe. ``A drifting, neutral Germany cannot be a solution, given the country's geostrategic position and its political, economic and military potential,'' Woerner said in a recent speech in West Germany. Woerner and President Bush will discuss the German question and other NATO issues this weekend at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, West Germany's foreign minister, has sketched out another plan for a successor nation. It would remain part of NATO but only the territory of West Germany would be tied to its military structure. NATO would not extend its forces farther east. Baker has registered his support for Genscher's plan. A formula would have to be found for dealing with the large contingents of forces stationed in both Germanys. About 380,000 Soviet troops are stationed in East Germany. More than 200,000 American soldiers are based across the border in West Germany. Belgium, Britain, France and the Netherlands have an additional 100,000 or so troops there. Negotiators for NATO and the Warsaw Pact are bargaining in Vienna to cut forces, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. Bush recently suggested that Washington and Moscow set equal ceilings of 225,000 troops in all of Europe, with 195,000 troops in Central Europe, which would include both Germanys. On Friday, Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed a limit of 195,000 troops for both sides in all of Europe. Some have raised the possibility that to ease the Kremlin's fears about a united Germany, Soviet troops could remain in place in a ``Guantanamo'' fashion. That refers to the presence of U.S. naval forces in Guantanamo Bay in Communist Cuba. There are precedents for what some call ``a la carte'' membership in NATO. Spain and France are members of NATO but keep their forces outside the joint military structure. Spain also does not allow the storing of nuclear weapons on its soil. Norway, which shares a border with the Soviet Union, is a member of the integrated military structure but has set out certain peacetime limitations. No foreign troops are stationed on its soil. No alliance forces take part in military exercises in the extreme northern part of the country. Nuclear weapons also cannot be warehoused on its territory. Indeed, West Germany itself offers a special case. The Bonn government joined the Western alliance in 1955, becoming its 15th member. As part of membership, it had to put its military forces, except for a defensive territorial army, under the alliance command. It is the only country to have assigned to the joint structure in peacetime.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Says Mantilla to Stay as Interior Minister
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Luis Alberto Sanchez said the government ``will not accept'' the interior minister's offer to resign after police wounded a leftist presidential candidate during a campaign march. The statement Sanchez made to reporters Friday night in Congress was the first official word since Interior Minister Agustin Mantilla offered his ``irrevocable'' resignation to President Alan Garcia two days earlier. Marxist presidential candidate Henry Pease was slightly wounded in the leg by birdshot fired Wednesday afternoon by police who also used tear gas to break up a campaign march in downtown Lima near the presidential palace. Mantilla called the police action ``without justification.'' Also slightly wounded were two congressional candidates of Pease's United Left coalition, two newspaper photographers and one of Pease's bodyguards. One police commander was fired and another suspended following the incident, and the Interior Ministry said it was launching an investigation. Other candidates in the April 8 election are Alfonso Barrantes of the Socialist Left coalition, Luis Alva Castro of the governing center-left Aprista Party, and front-runner Mario Vargas Llosa of the center-right Democratic Front coalition. By law, Garcia cannot run for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Asks End of Duties on Some Caribbean, Central American Goods
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has asked Congress to remove import duties on clothing, shoes and other labor-intensive products from the Caribbean and Central America but says it opposes any tampering with sugar quotas imposed on the region. Endorsing an extension and expansion of President Reagan's 1983 Caribbean Basin Initiative, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Friday that lifting the present duties would ``mitigate the need for (foreign) aid and raise our own exports'' to the region. However, she said changing import quota formulas on sugar to assure the Caribbean a stable U.S. market to the possible detriment of other exporters, such as Australia and the Philippines, would violate international trade agreements. When asked at a Senate hearing if she would recommend that President Bush veto a bill that includes a guaranteed minimum for sugar imports from the Caribbean, Mrs. Hills said she didn't know. Congress is expected this year to make permanent the current program, now scheduled to expire in September 1995. But expanding it to include duty-free status on a wide variety of goods that compete with U.S. products is encountering widespread opposition.
DOC.HEAD: Accountant Says Collapsed Thrift was `Giving Its Money Away'
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings and Loan Association ``was manufacturing profits by giving its money away,'' says an accountant who examined Lincoln's books at the government's request. Roger Johnson testified Friday in U.S. District Court that the collapsed thrift, owned by Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating and seized by federal regulators last April, recorded $135 million in pre-tax gains on 15 land transactions in 1986 and 1987. But in reality, there was ``a net outflow of cash from Lincoln'' in each instance, said Johnson, a certified public accountant for Kenneth Leventhal & Co. The net cash expended by Lincoln to accomplish the sales totaled $217 million, according to a draft of a report prepared last July by Johnson's firm and introduced in court. Reading from the report, Johnson said the Irvine, Calif., thrift was ``made to function as an engine designed to funnel insured deposits'' to Keating's Phoenix holding company, the American Continental Corp. The cash outflow is ``precisely the opposite of what you would expect. ... The profits reported should have been reversed,'' Johnson told U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin. Lincoln is suing the government's Office of Thrift Supervision, seeking a court order to remove the conservatorship and receivership regulators imposed last year to seize control of the thrift. American Continental Corp. benefited from the 15 transactions under a tax-sharing agreement in which Lincoln made payments to its parent.
DOC.HEAD: Ex-Unisys Official Sentenced for Defrauding U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A former Unisys Corp. official has been sentenced to one year in prison for conspiring to make illegal campaign donations and obstructing the FBI's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud. John B.G. Roberts III, a former marketing manager for the defense contractor, was sentenced Friday on his guilty plea to charges of conspiracy to defraud the government and charges of obstruction of justice. Alexandria, Va., U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton also fined Roberts $10,000 and ordered him to serve a two-year term of supervised release after completing the prison term. Roberts could have received a 10-year prison term for his guilty plea. He admitted that he arranged for the submission of false claims to the Pentagon for consultants' services when the money was actually funneled to members of Congress who had influence over defense procurement. In pleading guilty Nov. 30, Roberts also admitted that he arranged for the filing of false statements with the Federal Election Commission to conceal illegal corporate donations to a number of lawmakers. Roberts admitted that he suggested to defense consultants working for Unisys how much money to donate to various lawmakers' campaign funds and prepared figures for the company's annual budget. Several Unisys consultants have pleaded guilty in connection with making illegal campaign contributions. Donations went to Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y.; the late Rep. Joseph D. Addabbo, D-N.Y., who chaired the House defense appropriations subcommittee; Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa.; Rep. Roy Dyson, D-Md.; Rep. Bill Young, D-Fla., and the late Rep. Bill Chappell, D-Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Govt Asks Paris Club To Allow Moratorium On Debt Payments
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has asked 17 creditor nations if his non-Communist government could halt payments on Poland's $40 billion foreign debt, officials said. Mazowiecki requested a suspension of payments because ``we are at the moment introducing a very difficult economic reform program,'' government spokesman Zbigniew Augustynowicz said in an interview. Mazowiecki made the request Friday in a letter sent to fellow government leaders in the Paris Club, which meets next week. The club, an informal grouping of representatives of Western creditor nations that gathers occasionally in Paris, was expected to take up Poland's debt problems Wednesday. About 65 percent, or $26 billion, of Poland's hard-currency debt is owed to 17 governments in the Club. Poland, which has had a non-Communist government since last summer, has been paying about $1.5 billion annually to service its Western debt, the largest such obligation in Eastern Europe. Those payments _ while falling far short of Poland's obligations _ consume nearly all of the country's net export earnings, leaving Poland little money to invest in rebuilding its dilapidated economy. However, major debt rescheduling with the Paris Club was refused until Poland's new Solidarity-led government and the International Monetary Fund could reach agreement on a tough adjustment program to reform Poland's economy. The plan took effect Jan. 1 and was formally approved by the IMF executive board last week. According to Augustynowicz, the letter asks specifically that the creditor governments: _ Permit Poland to suspend all Paris Club debt payments, including interest and principal, for 1989 and 1990. _ Consider freezing the country's Western debt at its current level of $40 billion. This would require the Paris Club governments to exert pressure on their countries' commercial banks, which hold most of the rest of the $40 billion debt. _ Seek a long-term solution to the Polish debt problem that would go in the direction of outright debt reduction. The Paris Club had been expected to offer Poland a ``magnanimous'' restructuring of the debt, allowing it to stretch out $5 billion in payments due the next two years over 10 years, a U.S. finance official, David C. Mulford, said last month. Most of the debt was accumulated during the 1970s by the Communist government under then-party leader Edward Gierek.
