In the 1970s, Communist authorities borrowed and spent Western money freely on ill-conceived investment projects and on food and consumer goods in an attempt to win public affection. Later Communist governments acknowledged that the money was wasted. When Poland's economy slumped at the end of the 1970s and the beginning of the 1980s, the country was no longer able to keep up payments, and mounting interest doubled the debt to the $40 billion level by this year.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf in 1st item to CLARIFY that legislator said one attraction for employers is low wages; picks up 5th graf, `State Rep. ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Missouri is the ``Show-Me State,'' New York the ``Empire State.'' And now, under a state legislator's proposal, the Land of Enchantment may become the ``Like-to-Work State.'' House Speaker Raymond Sanchez has proposed a $100,000 advertising campaign to promote what he called the state's ``relatively contented work force.'' John Dendahl, secretary of the Department of Economic Development and Tourism, agreed that New Mexico workers' low absenteeism and turnover rates could attract new business to the state. Dendahl said another attraction for companies is ``the fact that employers don't have to pay (workers) as much'' as in other states. State Rep. Robert Light told Sanchez he likes ``Like-to-Work,'' but he suggested something stronger: ``Have you thought of replacing the word `like' with `love?'''

DOC.HEAD: Hostage-Taking at Courthouse Ends in Murder-Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CLARIFY how brothers got gun, where the standoff occurred, when the arrests took place, deletes extraneous material; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Twin robbery suspects held the Richland County sheriff hostage in the county courthouse for four hours Friday night before one of the twins killed his brother and himself, authorities said. The sheriff was unharmed. Assistant County Prosecutor Jerry Ault said Brad Jordan killed his twin brother, Chad, with a single shot to the head, then turned the weapon on himself. The 18-year-old brothers had been brought from jail to the sheriff's detective bureau in the courthouse for questioning about a string of robberies they allegedly committed ten days before in three northeastern Ohio towns. The twins overcame Deputy Deb Strine and took her gun, then held her hostage until Sheriff Dale Shetler exchanged himself for Strine, said sheriff's officer Gregory Kemp. Ms. Strine was released about 6:20 p.m. Shetler was in the room when Jordan killed his brother and himself, Kemp said. The twins' mother, Sandra Teeters, and stepbrother, Kenneth Teeters, were outside the courthouse during the standoff. The Jordans were arrested Jan. 31 after a clerk at a convenience store in Belleville, just south of Mansville, triggered a silent alarm during a robbery there. They also were charged with robberies the same day in Mansville and Canton, 60 miles east of Mansville.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Policy Shift Would End Basic Strategic Doctrine
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: A Pentagon decision to shelve contingency plans for fighting a war with the Soviet Union in Iran eliminates a strategic doctrine that has guided U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf for four decades. During that time, U.S. military planners have prepared for a Soviet attack southward through Iran toward the gulf's vital oil fields. The Americans would block it in the rugged Zagros mountain range, which parallels much of Iran's gulf coastline. According to published accounts in Washington, the Pentagon's Defense Planning Guidance report for 1992-97, just approved by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, declares that neither a Soviet invasion of Iran nor the U.S. ability to counter it is now considered ``credible.'' According to reports, the Pentagon document directs military planners to formulate a new strategy that assumes Soviet military strength will be reduced through negotiations on conventional force levels in Europe and that future threats to the gulf would originate elsewhere. Although not named, potential adversaries evidently include Iran, which is hostile to Saudi Arabia and still technically at war with Iraq, despite their 1988 cease-fire. Iraq, stronger as a result of its military triumph in the eight-year Gulf war, is also mistrusted by some Arab states. The Zagros strategy, by some accounts, dates back to 1946, when then-Soviet leader Josef Stalin, hoping to gain access to the gulf's warm-water ports, tested his former World War II allies by attempting to annex territory in northern Iran. The effort was thwarted by U.S. and British diplomacy at the United Nations. American policy has recognized Moscow's interest in obtaining access to the gulf and perhaps dominating the oil-producing Arab states along its shores. From those days until now, according to foreign policy expert Gary Sick, U.S. leaders have seen Iran as the most likely place outside Europe where a U.S.-Soviet clash might escalate into another world war. The United States had the advantage until its close ally, Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, was overthrown in 1979. His Islamic fundamentalist successor, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, rejected ties with both Washington and Moscow, making Iran a hostile setting for both superpowers in the event of a showdown. The U.S. doctrine of blocking Soviet moves through Iran acquired new importance after Moscow invaded neighboring Afghanistan in 1979 and deployed warships near the gulf. Although undoubtedly influenced by the easing of East-West tensions, the shift toward a new Pentagon strategy for the gulf reflects thinking that predates the Soviet bloc upheavals by at least a year, U.S. sources say. As early as 1988, these sources have said, military analysts were giving less weight to the prospect of a U.S. counteroffensive in Iran in favor of direct defense of the gulf itself. This change, the sources said, was based partly on a belief that neither the Soviets nor the United States could long sustain major military operations in a country where both terrain and politics are hostile. The Zagros mountains have peaks of up to 18,000 feet. In December 1988, the retiring commander of U.S. Central Command, Marine Gen. George B. Crist, was quoted as saying he had proposed to the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff a new plan for deploying U.S. land, sea and air forces to defend key objectives from the northern gulf to the Strait of Hormuz, 600 miles to the southeast. Crist said new intelligence indicated the Soviets would try to seize such objectives rather than mount a major land thrust through Iran. Any new strategy would require at least prolonging the 40-year-old American naval presence in the gulf, soon to be cut from 10 to seven ships. In addition, a nine-ship carrier group is in the Arabian Sea. But how large additional forces could be maintained without land bases nearby is unclear. While privately welcoming the U.S. military presence, the politically sensitive gulf states refused during the Iran-Iraq war to allow U.S. bases on their territory.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Richard Pyle has covered the Persian Gulf for The Associated Press since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Journalism Club In America Closes Its Doors
LaserPhoto PX1
DOC.TEXT: The vanishing image of the hard-drinking, chain-smoking reporter has lost more of its varnish _ America's oldest press club has closed its doors. The 98-year-old Pen & Pencil Club survived the death of more than a dozen Philadelphia periodicals but now has fallen victim to the changing drinking habits of journalists and the high-crime neighborhood it moved to in 1986. More than a hundred people _ close to half the club's dwindling membership _ jammed the bar Friday night, threatening the beer supply. Stories were swapped _ about the card games in the 1950s that would bring police raids, the time a couple got caught in the restroom in an amorous clinch, the numerous ``raunchy'' parties. The club, chartered in 1892 and billed as America's oldest press club by local newspapers and the National Press Club, has seen a host of famous names cross its doorway. Red Smith and Damon Runyon were members. Guests included Mae West, William Jennings Bryan and former Mayor Frank Rizzo. U.S. Presidents Hoover, Coolidge and Taft imbibed at the club's bar _ according to club history, Taft skipped out on his tab. ``There were some wild times at the club,'' said Larry Fish, a reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer. ``There was a real `Front Page' atmosphere there.'' The journalist as hard-drinker was firmly entrenched in Americana after the premiere of ``The Front Page,'' a play of the 1920s that portrayed reporters as ``hoodlumesque half-drunken caballeros.'' Inquirer reporter Tom Belden said the changing drinking habits of reporters caused the club's demise. When he first began coming to the club in 1979, ``there were a dozen or so single men who would drop $20 to $50 a night. They kept the bar going themselves.'' But journalism is no longer dominated by single men, he said, and married people tend to stay home with their family more often. ``And drink more orange juice than liquor,'' he added. The National Press Club, based in Washington, D.C., estimated that 22 press clubs closed between 1982 and 1985. The Philadelphia club had been located above a diner about halfway between buildings housing the Inquirer and The Evening Bulletin. When the Bulletin folded in 1982, the club decided to move closer to the Inquirer building. That move was seen by many as the beginning of the end. ``We thought people getting off work in the afternoon would wander over for a drink,'' said Fish, who was on the club's board at the time. ``But every time I came over, there'd be nobody here.'' Members said the new location, on the edge of a poorer, high-crime neighborhood, caused many people to stay away. Several people Friday had stories of their cars being vandalized. Also gone were the scores of ``associate members,'' those not in the profession who would stop by the downtown location. Before voting to close the Pen & Pencil, club officials even considered holding aerobics classes and child-care groups _ moves the older reporters dismissed. The Pen & Pencil was losing $300 to $400 a week when the club's officers voted last month to close down. Jack Sherzer, a Harrisburg Patriot-News reporter, traveled two hours for Friday night's farewell. ``Journalists are a loner crowd and without a place like this, well,'' he said, shrugging, ``where are we going to go to meet?''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Paramilitary Squads Main Human Rights Threat
DOC.TEXT: Right-wing paramilitary groups funded by drug traffickers pose the biggest threat to human rights in Colombia and investigations of their crimes are often hindered by police, according to a U.N. report. The report published Friday urged Colombian authorities to dismiss anyone in the armed forces or police found to have cooperated with the death squads. The report by Amos Wako, to be presented to the U.N. Human Rights Comission, said that for many years murder had been the main cause of death among adults in Colombia. It called for an international fund be established to help protect judges and witnesses and more international to increase the number of police investigators and improve their training. In the first nine months of last year 2,337 people lost their lives as a result of political and military conflict, the report said. It said 603 victims were white-collar workers, most of them government employees killed in retaliation for the government's clampdown on drug traffickers. The report said another 456 victims were peasants who were labor activists or suspected of sympathizing with the various anti-government guerrilla groups. Most died at the hands of the estimated 140 paramilitary groups trained and financed by drug barons and operating closely with ``elements'' in the armed forces and police, it said. It said in some cases police ignored the crimes, hindered investigations or offered safe conduct passes to paramilitary members. Wako cited concerns by some private human rights groups in Colombia that existing foreign aid was mainly military in character and focused more on countering anti-government guerrillas rather than drug traffickers or paramilitary squads. The report also criticized violence and blackmail tactics used by left-wing guerrillas. It welcomed efforts by President Virgilio Barco's government to promote dialogue with the insurgency movements. Wako, a Kenyan, wrote the report following a 10-day U.N. mission to Colombia in October.

DOC.HEAD: Gotti Acquitted in Union Shooting
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: The acquittal of reputed mob boss John Gotti on charges he ordered the shooting of a union official brought cheers in court and a celebration in the Queens neighborhood where the ``Dapper Don'' is king. Gotti, the man authorities call America's No. 1 organized crime boss, won his third victory over government prosecutors Friday when a jury found him innocent of assault and conspiracy. His co-defendant, Anthony Guerrieri, was also acquitted. Gotti's supporters applauded loudly as the verdict was read, provoking Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin to threaten them with 30 days in jail if they didn't stop. Gotti, who favors $1,800 suits and pinkie rings, kissed his lawyer Bruce Cutler after the verdict and left the Manhattan courthouse without commenting A short time later, he arrived at a favorite hangout in Manhattan's Little Italy and was cheered wildly by people waiting for him on the street. Two women kissed him before he ducked inside. Later fireworks were set off. Near another Gotti hangout, the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club in the borough of Queens, residents decorated homes and stores with balloons and signs congratulating Gotti on his acquittal. ``We're happy he won. He's a good man to have on the avenue,'' said resident Phyllis Maccarelli. Gotti, 49, allegedly assumed control of the Gambino family after the December 1985 execution of ``Big Paul'' Castellano and his bodyguard outside a Manhattan restaurant. Since then, Gotti has been tried three times and won each case. He was cleared in 1986 of beating a man in a traffic dispute after the victim claimed he could not identify Gotti; he was acquitted the next year in a federal racketeering case. When he was arrested on the latest charge, Gotti said his odds of winning were 3 to 1. Gotti and Guerrieri were accused of commissioning the Westies, a Hell's Kitchen gang, to shoot John F. O'Connor on May 7, 1986. He was shot in the buttocks and survived. The prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky, said Gotti arranged the shooting because O'Connor ordered thugs to vandalize a mob-run restaurant being built with non-union labor. The government's case was damaged when O'Connor, in testimony, denied knowing who had ordered him shot. ``We think it was a fair trial, but we're disappointed,'' Cherkasky said after the verdict. Cutler, Gotti's lawyer, said, ``This verdict shows you can't put people in jail by calling them names, calling them gangsters and things like that.'' The defense lawyers ridiculed the prosecution's main evidence: the testimony of former Westie member James McElroy and scarcely audible tapes secretly recorded in 1986 in the Rikers Island jail visiting room and at the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club. Cutler and Shargel said a key tape on which Gotti allegedly says, ``We're gonna, gonna bust him up,'' is inaudible and that prosecutors transcribed it to suit their theory that Gotti had O'Connor shot. ``I did not hear anything in these tapes that would lead me to believe Mr. Gotti had a hand in this assault,'' juror Richard Silensky said. Another juror who wouldn't give his name said: ``There was nothing to connect Mr. Gotti to what happened. Zilch.'' The jurors were sequestered for security reasons throughout the three-week trial. McElroy, who testified that he was part of the group that shot O'Connor as a favor to Gotti, was portrayed by the defense as a liar who hoped to shorten the 60-year prison term he is serving and get better terms for his girlfriend in a drug case. O'Connor testified as a surprise witness for the defense. He admitted his union was plagued by internal troubles and acknowledged it was possible that a union rival could have arranged the shooting. The judge told the jurors they could convict the defendants only if the prosecution proved they arranged the shooting and not simply because they might be members of organized crime. Had he been convicted, Gotti could have faced 25 years to life in prison as a persistent felon because of convictions in 1969 and 1974. In the latter case, Gotti plea-bargained down to an attempted manslaughter charge in the slaying of a man in a Staten Island bar.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Free Last Political Prisoners From Somoza Era
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lede to add dropped word.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen days before the presidential election, the leftist government honored a pledge and freed nearly 1,000 Contra guerrillas and the last 39 jailed members of former President Anastasio Somoza's National Guard. President Daniel Ortega, who is running for re-election, proposed the pardon earlier this month. The pardon _ and the release Friday _ deprived his major opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, of a campaign issue for the Feb. 25 election. The release was witnessed by diplomats, four Contra commanders who have laid down their arms, international election observers and church and Red Cross representatives. The Sandinista government made the most of the ceremony, taking several busloads of reporters to the Juan Navarro Central Penitentiary, where the inmates stood in lines in front of the assembled dignitaries. Among the guardsmen were men accused of the most serious crimes committed during the rule of Somoza, who was toppled by the Sandinistas in 1979. ``As a soldier, I obeyed the orders of my superiors; I didn't do anything without orders,'' said former Maj. Hugo Torres, who admitted to being part of a secret squad accused of killing opponents of Somoza. Somoza was assassinated Sept. 17, 1980, in Asuncion, Paraguay, where he lived in exile. Many guardsmen imprisoned after summary trials in ``people's courts,'' like Torres, claim they have been held illegally and say they were tortured. ``I'm innocent; I fought with arms, like the others,'' said former Maj. Jose Enrique Mungia Barrios. He allegedly killed Carlos Fonseca, a hero of the revolution and a founder of the Sandinistas, in combat. Torres, 54, whipped off his baseball cap when the national anthem was played and stood at attention, holding it over his heart. ``I'm a professional soldier,'' he said. ``I'm proud to have been in the National Guard.'' Somoza's army is probably the most reviled symbol of his government in a country where the new governing party has tried to keep alive the passion of its revolution. Barricada, the Sandinista party newspaper, published photographs of former guardsmen running for various local offices on the opposition coalition's ticket. ``Would you vote for the Somoza guard?'' it asked. Sandinista officials have said the decision to free the last guardsmen and the Contras shows their humanity. The guerrillas were believed to be nearly all those left in prison. Ortega's government released more than 1,800 former guardsmen last year in an amnesty stipulated by a Central American peace agreement. Those released Friday were kept in prison either because of the seriousness of their crimes or their refusal to accept political re-education. They included ex-Col. Isaias Cuadra, 56, who allegedly tortured Interior Minister Tomas Borge while Somoza was in power; and former Maj. Orlando Felipe Hislop, 45, accused of torturing the woman who now heads the Sandinista police. Franco Montealegre, director of prisons, said earlier this week most of the Contras also had refused re-education. The pardon, approved earlier this week by the Sandinista-controlled National Assembly, covered 994 imprisoned members of the U.S.-supported rebel army. Diogenes Hernandez, a former Contra commander who attended the ceremony as a guest, said the pardon would help build a ``climate necessary for national reconciliation.''

DOC.HEAD: Biomedical Company Seeks U.S., Foreign Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for PM-Lung Implant Inventor in PM-Digest Advisory
DOC.TEXT: Larry Rigby gambled five years ago on a biomedical device that mimics the human lung. If it pays off, beating long odds, his tiny company could become a life-giving giant. Rigby, a venture capitalist, teamed up with Dr. J.D. Mortensen to found CardioPulmonics Inc., maker of the experimental lung device that was implanted in a teen-ager who died earlier in the week. The operation was the first time a person had received the IntraVascular Oxygenator, dubbed IVOX, which has been approved by federal regulators in patients who have little chance of survival. The device, which works like a lung, is a 20-inch bundle of hollow polypropylene fibers designed to handle as much as half the body's oxygen delivery and elimination of carbon dioxide. It was designed for patients suffering acute but reversible lung disease or injury. ``I think it's very promising technology,'' Rigby said ``We could be a $100 million company in five years if the technology is what we think it is.'' Rigby said he was pleased that the instrument functioned as expected during its first human trial, but sounded a cautionary note. ``This is research,'' he said. ``You just can't make leaping conclusions from one example.'' Under guidelines approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the IVOX will be tested in up to 10 people who require 100 percent oxygen to detect possible tissue damage. Suffering from respiratory distress syndrome, Melicia ``Mimi'' Harvey, 16, of Arthur City, Texas, died Wednesday of pulmonary failure at LDS Hospital four days after the implant. Tim Madden, a spokesman at the hospital, said there were no clinical complications from the device. If the device proves successful, up to 200,000 patients annually in the United States and more in Japan and Europe could be recipients, Rigby said. But the company, which employs 32 people, must overcome marrying high techology with sound business practices. ``Marketing is the tough chore. A lot of the smaller companies look for small speciality niches, where a large company wouldn't be interested in competing,'' said Bob Brewer of Utah Technology Finance Corp., an independent state agency that gave a small amount of seed money to CardioPulmonics. ``Some succeed, others have difficulties,'' he said. The company was founded in 1985 with money from the two co-founders and Mortensen's $550,000 grant from the federal Small Business Innovation program. By last year Rigby had secured $7.7 million from five investment companies that now own controlling stock in the privately held company. ``As a business opportunity, something like this is very long-range, and investors need very deep pockets, but the return in the end could be very substantial,'' he said. If the IVOX reaches the market, its external gas pressure regulator will sell for about $10,000, and the disposable oxygenator for about $2,500 each. IVOX offshoots, such as the coating that prevents blood clots on the fibrous bundle, also could be marketed to manufacturers of surgical instruments, Rigby said. He said CardioPulmonics has had inquiries from scores of domestic and foreign medical institutions and a few Japanese companies whose identities he won't reveal.

DOC.HEAD: Crematorium Operator to be Tried in Poisoning of Rival
DOC.TEXT: A former mortician serving a sentence for mutilating corpses was charged with murder in the poisoning death of a competitor in 1985, authorities said. The case against David Wayne Sconce, 33, of Pasadena is believed to be the nation's first prosecution of a death by oleander poisoning, said Deputy District Attorney Harvey Giss. Sconce, former operator of the Lamb Funeral Home, will be tried in Ventura County for the death of Timothy Raymond Waters, 24, who ran the Alpha Society cremation service in Burbank, Giss said. Sconce was charged Friday with first-degree murder with the special circumstances of murder by poison. A conviction under the special circumstances allegation could bring the death penalty. Arraignment was scheduled Feb. 26 in Ventura Municipal Court. Sconce was sentenced to five years in state prison last September after he pleaded guilty to mutilating corpses, conducting mass cremations and stealing dental gold from bodies. He also pleaded guilty to hiring thugs to beat up three competing morticians, including Waters, failure to bury the body of a baby girl, and car theft. It was during a preliminary hearing concerning the macabre charges involving the funeral home's operations that witnesses testified Sconce had bragged about poisoning Waters. The comments prompted authorities to re-open an investigation into Waters' death. Waters died April 8, 1985, at his parents' home in Camarillo. The Ventura County coroner's office initially determined the death stemmed from natural causes, but ruled it was murder after a second autopsy revealed traces of oleander poison in blood and tissue samples. Testimony in a preliminary hearing revealed Sconce possessed a book entitled, ``The Poor Man's James Bond,'' which featured a chapter on how to kill by oleander poisoning. Oleander is a poisonous evergreen shrub. Deaths from oleander poisoning are rare. Some cases are accidental as in a California case several years ago when a woman died after brewing an oleander tea from what she thought were harmless leaves.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Recalls Inventory After Tests Find Benzene in Some Bottles
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. inventory of Perrier mineral water is being recalled because laboratory tests found benzene in a small number of bottles. Chronic exposure to benzene has been found to cause adult leukemia, birth defects and other ailments. But Perrier's U.S. distributor said the Food and Drug Administration advised the company there is no serious health concern if it's consumed in small amounts. The Perrier Group of America Inc. announced the voluntary recall Friday. ``While experts tell us short-term consumption of the product poses no significant health risks to the general population, we're trying to act aggressively and responsibly in the interests of the public,'' said Ronald V. Davis, president of Perrier Group of America. The company is recalling stock still in its possession, and expects stores to follow suit, said Jane Lazgin, a Perrier spokeswoman. Benzene is a clear, flammable liquid used as a solvent and in making lacquers, varnishes and dyes. Perrier water is drawn from a natural underground mineral spring in Vergeze, France, and bottled only at the source, Lazgin said. The French Ministry of Health has certified that there is no contamination at the spring, the company said. The search for a possible cause of the chemical intrusion is focusing on the packaging and distribution process, Lazgin said. Perrier is conducting an internal investigation, and is also cooperating with federal and state authorities, who are testing the products. The Greenwich-based Perrier Group of America is an independent subsidiary of Source Perrier of France. It distributes and markets Perrier in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Libya is Making Poison Gas, Reports Say
DOC.TEXT: West German opposition politicians said a Libyan chemical plant allegedly built with West German help has begun to produce poison gas. Reinhard Kraemer, a spokesman for the environmentalist Greens party in Bonn, said Friday the Greens have received information from the government that the plant has produced enough poison gas for 1,000 artillery shells. The Libyan government denied the plant was making poison gas, and the West German government refused to comment. But U.S. officials said the plant had started producing chemicals, possibly for chemical weapons. The plant, 60 miles south of Tripoli in the town of Rabta, caused a huge scandal last year with U.S. allegations that West German firms helped build the plant. West Germany at first denied the allegations, but it ultimately launched its own investigation and accused the Imhausen-Chemie firm of helping build the Libyan plant. The investigation has not yet been concluded. A government spokesman in Bonn, when asked about the new report that production had begun at the plant, said: ``We cannot take a position at this time.'' A U.S. official in Washington said Friday that the Libyans have been producing ``very small'' amounts of chemicals, possibly for weapons use, for about a year. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the plant 60 miles south of Tripoli is producing nowhere near its design capacity and that the United States is monitoring the situation. The Libyan government of Col. Moammar Gadhafi has denied the Rabta plant was designed to produce poison gas, saying it is for the production of pharmaceuticals. Ali Sunni Muntasser, Libya's deputy representative to the United Nations, said Friday night, ``All these stories about manufacturing gases or chemicals or anything is untrue.'' However, Albrecht Mueller, a federal lawmaker with the main opposition Social Democratic Party, said he was told by a West German government official the Rabta plant is making poison gas. He said the information was released during a meeting Wednesday of the parliamentary Economics Committee. ``I gathered from the meeting the production started last year,'' Mueller said in a telephone interview. He said an Economics Ministry official identified the chemical name as ``Lost,'' which is a military term for dichlordiaethylsulphide, a poison gas used to disable enemy soldiers. Mueller said he did not recall the name of the official who released the information. The lawmaker said he had heard from other sources that the Rabta plant has produced more than 20 tons of the poison gas since last year. He would not identify the other sources. Other sources in Bonn, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the matter came up at closed-door meetings of the parliamentary Foreign Committee as well as the Economics Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Man With Amnesia Awaits Meeting People who Claim Him as Relative
DOC.TEXT: John Doe, a man who remembers only bits and pieces of his life prior to last October, says he doesn't know what to think about people claiming him as their lost relative. ``I don't know how to explain it. It's good, but I don't remember any of these people,'' he said Friday in a telephone interview. Doe said he last remembers being picked up by Topeka police as he was wandering through a motel parking lot in October. He had no identification and told police he did not know his name, address or anything else about his past. Since then, he's undergone extensive hypnotherapy and had his fingerprints sent to the FBI. But the search for his identity produced only tiny clues until Thursday night when Milwaukee television station WITI-TV aired a report on Doe by WIBW-TV in Topeka. People in Wisconsin who saw the program claimed to be Doe's relatives, according to Doe's therapist, Rick Selig. Selig said the presumed relatives say Doe is actually Melvin Wolf, a 53-year-old small appliance repairman from Angleton, Texas. They said Wolf left home Aug. 20 on a business trip, and never returned. Donna Caske, Wolf's sister from Angleton, is expected to arrive today in Topeka to determine whether Doe is actually Wolf, Selig said. ``Legally, we can't say that this individual is Melvin Wolf until we get confirmation with the fingerprints,'' said Selig, a clinical social worker at the Topeka Psychiatric Clinic. Selig has worked with Doe since he was found in October. But Selig and authorities said it's possible that Doe is Wolf. Selig said that about a month ago during hypnosis, Doe began to recall certain details of his life, such as a U.S. Army serial number, a farm scene, and the first names of his parents. He also spoke fluent German and stated that he served in Germany during World War II, Selig said. He recalled vivid details of Berlin, and remembered that he once owned a 1966 Dodge van. The serial number belonged to Melvin Wolf, Selig said, and all other information he gave under hypnosis had been corroborated Friday with Mrs. Caske and people in Wisconsin also claiming to be relatives. Topeka police Sgt. Greg Halford said authorities plan to check Doe's fingerprints with Wolf's and meet with Mrs. Caske and other relatives. ``We do not think this is a hoax,'' Halford said. Selig said Doe spoke Friday on the telephone with Mrs. Caske and others claiming to be relatives, but he did not remember them. Mrs. Caske said Wolf lived with her. ``Hopefully, (seeing them) will spark some memories for him,'' said Selig, who diagnosed Doe as suffering from psychogenic amnesia _ a total memory loss that can come from some ``extraordinarily stressful event, a very painful event. After a lengthy hospital stay, Doe has been living at a halfway house in Topeka. ``I don't know what to say,'' Doe said about today's meeting. ``I'm nervous, excited, scared _ everything you can say. ... I hope when I see them I remember.''

DOC.HEAD: Hostage-Taker Kills Self, Twin Brother
LaserPhoto MFD1
DOC.TEXT: Twin robbery suspects held a sheriff hostage in the county courthouse for four hours before one of the 18-year-olds killed his brother and himself, authorities said. The sheriff was unharmed. The standoff ended about 9:50 p.m. Friday when one of the identical twins, Brad Jordan, killed his brother, Chad, with a single shot to the head and then turned the weapon on himself, said Assistant County Prosecutor Jerry Ault. The Jordans had been brought from jail to the sheriff's courthouse office for questioning about a string of robberies they allegedly committed 10 days earlier in three northeastern Ohio towns. The twins overpowered Deputy Deb Strine and took her 9mm pistol, then held her hostage until Sheriff Dale Shetler, 43, exchanged himself for Strine, said sheriff's officer Gregory Kemp. Ms. Strine was released about 6:20 p.m. Shetler was in the room when Jordan killed his brother and himself, Kemp said. Sandra Teeters, mother of the twins, and other family members were helping police negotiate with the brothers when the shooting occurred. ``We gave both of them a chance, the mother and their brother. Both of them tried their damnedest but it didn't work,'' Ault said. Ms. Teeters said her sons had often been in trouble. ``Up to now, they've just been hyperactive,'' she said. ``Some stealing and robbing. I tried but I just couldn't control them.'' ``It should never have ended like this,'' said Ed Teeters, a stepbrother of the twins. ``They were attention grabbers; they always ached for attention.'' Autopsies were scheduled for today, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan to Give Video Deposition for Poindexter Trial
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS lead to delete extraneous apostrophe `s'
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan will give a videotaped deposition for John Poindexter's trial in his first in-depth questioning on the Iran-Contra affair since his two interviews with the Tower Commission. In those interviews conducted three years ago by the Reagan-appointed commission, Reagan said he couldn't remember when he had approved arm sales to Iran. Reagan on Friday consented to a videotaped deposition in which Poindexter's lawyers will ask him 154 questions, plus follow-up questions. The subject areas will include Reagan's knowledge of Oliver North's activities on behalf of the Contras and whether Reagan authorized written responses to Congress relating to the Nicaraguan rebels. Poindexter now faces felony charges in connection with those responses to Congress. Details on timing and other arrangements for the videotaped testimony will be worked out Monday in a hearing before U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene, who will preside at the Poindexter trial, scheduled to start Feb. 20. Reagan proposed to answer the questions Feb. 16 in Los Angeles. Reagan said in a court filing that he recognizes the courts have a responsibility to protect Poindexter's rights. But his lawyers also said Reagan retains the right to invoke executive privilege to specific questions during the deposition. Indicating they expect Bush administration representatives to be permitted to attend the deposition, Reagan's lawyers said they will ``defer to the incumbent president'' regarding issues of executive privilege on national security or foreign affairs. The former national security adviser is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. Greene will attend the deposition to rule on disputes. Claiming executive privilege to specific questions could result in halting the deposition in mid-stream and taking the matter through court appeals. Or, more likely, the deposition would continue while the specific questions at issue remain unanswered, pending appeals. The ``videotape deposition format will provide an appropriate mechanism ... to protect sensitive, classified national security information and confidential deliberations,'' Reagan's lawyers said. The edited videotape would be shown at Poindexter's trial. Reagan told the commission led by former Sen. John Tower, R-Texas, that he did not know the National Security Council staff was engaged in helping the Contras. The board said it was aware of no evidence to suggest Reagan was aware of North's activities on behalf of the Contras when North was an NSC aide. Poindexter, however, will ask Reagan whether he knew far more than he told the Tower Commission about North's activities. Poindexter also plans to ask Reagan if he approved responses to Congress inquiring into whether North was assisting the Contras. In the responses, Poindexter endorsed letters sent to Congress a year earlier by then-national security adviser Robert McFarlane denying North was raising money or providing military advice to the Contras. McFarlane in 1988 pleaded guilty to withholding information from Congress in connection with the letters. Reagan also would be asked about discussions with Poindexter regarding a chronology on the Iran arms sales that is involved in four of the five criminal charges against Poindexter. The chronology, prepared by others at Poindexter's direction, falsely states that no one in the U.S. government knew until January 1986 that a CIA-assisted November 1985 shipment from Israel to Iran contained Hawk missiles. When Reagan first met with the Tower Commission, he said he had approved the shipment of arms from Israel to Iran in August 1985. But he changed his statements in his second meeting, saying he hadn't approved the first shipment but authorized later ones. A week later, he wrote the Tower Board to saying simply, ``I cannot recall'' whether he approved an Israeli sale in advance.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives, Reformers Fight to Nominate Candidate
DOC.TEXT: In a fight that may set the pace of political reform, governing party factions are battling over the selection of a running mate for President Lee Teng-hui, who is expected to be nominated for re-election Sunday. The outcome of the struggle between conservatives and reformers may also help determine how long Chiang Kai-shek loyalists _ many in their 80s _ remain in their powerful positions. One conservative favorite for running mate is Chiang Wego, a former general and son of Chiang Kai-shek. His father lost the civil war to the Communists on the mainland and fled to Taiwan in 1949, where he led an authoritarian regime for four decades. The struggle for a presidential partner has been hard fought. Liu Kuo-tsai, speaker of the legislature, quoted the president today as saying he was ``exhausted mentally and physically'' over the choice. December elections gave urgency to the task of overhauling the Nationalist Party. The governing party lost several key local seats to the opposition and overall gained 58 percent of the vote, down from 70 percent in 1986. The elections were the first multiparty vote since the lifting of 38 years of martial law. Chang Chung-tung, a history professor of National Taiwan University, said: ``People want President Lee to establish a democratic insitution rather than becoming another dictator.'' In the Nationalist Party convention Sunday, 180 members of the party's Central Committee are widely expected to nominate Lee for another six years as president. The Central Committee includes many military and government officials who pledged allegiance to Lee after he succeeded another of Chiang Kai-shek's sons, President Chiang Ching-kuo. He died in office in 1988. Lee will then announce his running mate, and the committee will vote on his choice. Elderly members of the National Assembly, Taiwan's electoral college which will meet in March to elect the president and vice president, have lobbied for a conservative running mate as a counterweight to Lee. He is considered a political reformer. Many of the Old Guard, who gained their positions as Chiang Kai-shek loyalists, fear that if Lee picks a reformer like himself, they will quickly be forced out of power. Loss of power will mean a loss of salary and lucrative perks. Lee, the first native Taiwanese to head the Nationalist government and party, gave no hint of his choice of a running mate on the eve of the convention. His silence was an indication of his difficulties in finding a compromise. Lee reportedly would like to pick his running mate from reform-minded Cabinet ministers and officials such as James Soong, secretary-general of the Nationalist Party. But observers say Lee must also appease the assemblymen to prevent them from vetoing future reform bills. They occupy 658 of the 764 seats in the National Assembly, the remainder being held by Taiwan-elected members and Nationalist-appointed members from overseas Chinese. All of the elderly members were elected before 1949 to permanent office to support the Nationalist claim to be the sole legitimate rulers of all China. More than 200 elderly assemblymen, mostly retired military officials, have pledged support to Chiang Wego, a 74-year-old former army general who is secretary general of the National Security Council. Chiang has said he doesn't want the job, but he had not ruled it out if he is asked. Many elderly assemblymen also support 73-year-old Premier Lee Huan.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Selling Off Paintings, Tapestries
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England, faced with losses of more than $1 billion for 1989, has collected its paintings, Gobelin tapestries and other valuables and packed them off for sale. ``I don't know of any of our customers who do business with us because we have a couple of valuable pictures,'' said new Board Chairman H. Ridgely Bullock. The nine rare tapestries, named for a 15th century French family, once adorned palace walls. They had been hung in two of the bank's offices. The 50 paintings put up for sale from the Boston offices include several by Maxfield Parrish, George Innes and Robert Rauschenberg. There was no immediate estimate how much the sale of the art works will realize. The bank, which blames its red ink problems chiefly on bad real estate loans, already has sold off assets totaling more than $1.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Weather Belts Gulf Coast
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms were expected to continue today from the Gulf Coast into the Southeast, while mild weather was forecast over much of the Rockies to the Plains. Unseasonable warmth continued to prevail in much of the eastern and central United States, though a slow-moving cold front should start ushering in cooler temperatures. Ahead of the front, rain was expected along much of the East Coast, with flooding possible in parts of New England. Temperatures today from Montana to Oklahoma were expected to be 20 degrees above normal. Three tornadoes were reported Friday. One near Nacogdoches, Texas, and another near Fairview-Alpha, La., caused heavy damage to buildings, power lines and trees, authorities said. A third tornado near Ashport, Tenn., caused no damage or injuries. Afternoon thunderstorms produced large hail, up to the size of golf balls in Little Rock, Ark., and San Antonio, Texas, the National Weather Service reported. The hail knocked out windows in homes and cars. ``We've had rainfall across the area of 4 to 14 inches,'' said weather service forecaster Ernest Ethridge. ``The rain fell quickly. It's not that we have too much, but the ground is wet and the bayous are full.'' Thunderstorm wind gusts damaged about 30 homes east of Rosebud, Ark., and overturned a large truck and motor home near Osceola, Ark. In Calhoun, La., a woman died and her grandson was injured when a wind gust carried her trailer home almost 30 feet and flipped it over, Ouachita Parish sheriff's deputies said. Bad weather also caused problems in Ellensburg, Wash., where heavy snow kept Interstate 90 closed at Snoqualmie Pass. Other parts of the nation basked in unseasonbly warm temperatures. Record highs set Friday for the date included 72 degrees in Charleston, W.Va.; 66 in Baltimore; 63 in New York; 49 in Boston; 55 in Portland, Maine; 58 in Mansfield, Ohio; and 93 in Corpus Christi, Texas. High temperature for the Lower 48 states Friday was 94 degrees at Alice, Texas. Marie 25 snow; San Antonio 48 fair. _WEST: Albuquerque 34 fair; Anchorage 3 snow; Boise 37 cloudy; Casper 31 windy; Fairbanks -34 fair; Great Falls 44 windy; Honolulu 68 showery; Las Vegas 37 fair; Los Angeles 53 fair; Medford 43 cloudy; Pendleton 54 cloudy; Phoenix 50 fair; Portland, Ore., 50 rain; Reno 35 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 34 cloudy; San Diego 51 fair; San Francisco 49 partly cloudy; Seattle 49 rain; Spokane 39 windy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 34 fair; Montreal 36 rain; Ottawa 34 cloudy; Regina 05 cloudy; Toronto 34 cloudy; Winnipeg 07 fair; Mexico City 57 fair; Acapulco 77 partly cloudy.

U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III challenged the Soviet Union today to end military and financial support to Marxist Cuba and came under a blizzard of criticism from Soviet officials about U.S. arms spending and the invasion of Panama. Baker, in an unprecedented appearance before the Soviet legislature, lectured his hosts about the ``darkness at noon'' era of the past and said the American people and Congress cannot understand how the Soviet government can send billions of rubles of assistance to countries like Cuba and Nicaragua. Not only were those countries supporting subversion in the Western hemisphere, Baker said, but the Soviet aid ``is even less comprehensible when it happens at a time when your people clearly need those scarce resources put to good use at home.'' Baker spoke before the International Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet in an 18th century ceremonial hall with a marble bust of Lenin behind him. His appearance marked the first time a U.S. government official appeared in the legislative chamber, an event Baker attributed to reforms undertaken by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``For over 40 years, we have waged a Cold War against one other,'' Baker said. ``Now is the time to put the legacy of struggle behind us. ... Now is the time to build a new legacy. Now is the time to move beyond the Cold War.'' But while complimenting the steps taken under Gorbachev, including the historic decision this week to end the Communist party's monopoly on political power, Baker salted his speech with a thrust at Soviet support for Marxist countries. Three times in the course of replying to questions, Baker called Soviet support for Cuba intolerable. He complained about the shipment of new MiG jet fighter planes and questioned why Moscow was aiding President Fidel Castro when he is so critical of Gorbachev's policies. ``We remain especially disturbed by the military shipments your government continues to send to those seeking military solutions to conflicts in regions vital to us,'' he said. Several committee members challenged Baker on the invasion of Panama and on several arms control fronts, including U.S. refusal to join the Soviets in a moratorium on nuclear weapons testing or to consider naval disarmament. Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, a military adviser to Gorbachev, said the United States at the end of World War II had encircled the Soviet Union with military bases and had not retreated from that policy. Akhromeyev, a leading figure in U.S.-Soviet arms control accords, questioned why the U.S. administration only trimmed defense spending, while the Soviets were cutting their defense budget by 14 percent as East-West tensions ease.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0469 to fix overline
Eight Bombs Explode But No Casualties
DOC.TEXT: Eight bombs exploded today in the stronghold of Moslem militants seeking independence for the Himalayan valley of Kashmir, authorities said. No one was injured. Authorities said the blasts, at two banks, a post office and other shops and businesses, occurred hours after fire swept through a shopping complex in Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state. No one claimed responsibilty for the explosions. Police said they believe the blaze was an accident since it occurred before dawn while a curfew was still in force. But other officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, blamed the fire and the bombs on the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, the militant group leading the four-decade-old drive for the country's only Moslem majority state to secede from predominantly Hindu India. India routinely blames neighoring Pakistan of arming, training and supporting the militants. Pakistan denies the charge but says the Kashmiri people have a right to self-determination. At least 82 people have been killed since Jan. 20 in frequent street clashes between militants and security forces in Srinagar and adjoining areas. Most of the victims have been protesters shot while defying curfew imposed by government forces to stem rising violence. The curfew was relaxed during the day from 5 a.m. to 6 p.m., except in the areas where the explosions occurred. Kashmir, once a princely state, was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding areas of the valley became part of Jammu-Kashmir. Sixty-four percent of the state's 5 million people are Moslems, but Moslems make up 12 percent of the 880 million population nationwide. Kashmiri militants had earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, which claims Kashmir because of its predominant Moslem population, but the militants now demand independence and the status of a neutral country. India has fought two wars with Pakistan over Kashmir.

DOC.HEAD: Entertainer Hospitalized for Treatment of Throat Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Sammy Davis Jr. has suffered a recurrence of throat cancer, a hospital spokesman said. Davis, who was diagnosed with throat cancer in September 1989, was being treated for the recurrence at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, hospital spokesman Ron Wise said Friday. The 64-year-old singer's specific condition was not released. He was admitted to the hospital three weeks ago, said Arnold Lipsman, a publicist for Davis. Davis, a versatile singer-dancer, most recently appeared in the 1989 movie ``Tap,'' playing an old-time tap dancer, Little Mo.

DOC.HEAD: Patrols to Protect Migrating Whales
DOC.TEXT: Federal marine agents, concerned about reports that boaters are harassing migrating gray whales, have orders to write fines of up to $25,000 to anyone seen getting too close to the whales. Agent Ray Sautter of the National Marine Fisheries Service said Friday he called for the patrols today and Sunday after going on a whale-watching cruise off San Diego's Point Loma last weekend. The Coast Guard will assist the fisheries agents, he said. ``I don't think anybody starts out their day by saying, `Let's go harass some whales today.' I think they just want to get closer,'' Sautter said. ``But when you start seeing boats that are making course changes to pursue the whales and whales making course changes to evade the boats that is a violation.'' Sautter said he saw several pleasure boaters venturing too close to the whales last week. Vessels should keep at least 100 yards from the whales and aircraft must fly at a minimum altitude of 1,000 feet while within a 100-yard radius of the whales, he said. ``I don't want to scare people or blindside them,'' he said. ``We're just trying to get people to enjoy the whales, but to give them a little bit of room. ``If you were out in South Dakota and saw a buffalo in the middle of a field, you wouldn't drive your car out in the middle of it to see the animal,'' he said. ``But that's what some people are doing out in the water with the whales.'' The gray whales, which are protected under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, hug the Southern California coast on their journey from Alaska to their breeding grounds off Baja California.

DOC.HEAD: Tape By Reputed Mob Leader Played in Court Tells of Payoffs to Officials
DOC.TEXT: Politicians shrugged off remarks by a reputed mob leader in a secretly taped conversation that he had paid off local officials and influenced last year's mayoral race. Two of the officials implicated in the tape played Friday at a bond hearing, Cook County Sheriff James O'Grady and his former top aide, county GOP Chairman James Dvorak, called for the appointment of a special prosecutor. ``A full and impartial public hearing is the only way to answer these allegations,'' O'Grady said in a statement. ``These allegations are absolutely preposterous,'' said Dvorak. ``This is merely one mobster boasting to another.'' The statements, recorded in September, were made by reputed mob gambling boss Rocco Infelice, 67, of suburban River Forest, who was among 20 alleged mobsters whose indictments were announced Wednesday by U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. On the tape played at Friday's hearing, Infelice said $10,000 a month went to ``the sheriff,'' an apparent reference to O'Grady, who said the remarks were untrue. An Internal Revenue Service agent who testified Friday said mob officials identified Dvorak as the conduit through which money was paid to the sheriff's office _ Dvorak vehemently denied this. ``If I was concerned about it, I'd be in Argentina right now, not standing before you,'' Dvorak told reporters. On the tape, Infelice also said he had given Mayor Richard M. Daley ``a lot of ... help in this last election,'' mostly by not backing one of Daley's rivals, former Alderman Edward Vrdolyak, the Republican candidate. Daley called the claim ``b.s.'' ``What are they talking about?'' he said. ``We ran a good campaign. All of a sudden, people like them are going to start taking credit for my election?'' Acting U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson said that Daley was not a target of the federal investigation. He had no comment when he was asked about the other officials. The tape played at the bond hearing was recorded by William Jahoda, a bookmaker who agreed to cooperate with federal agents and wore a concealed recorder, according to testimony. Jahoda was among those indicted Wednesday. The terms of his agreement with prosecutors have not been disclosed. The government was attempting at the hearing before U.S. Magistrate Thomas Rosemond to block bonds for Infelice and four other defendants. The hearing was to continue Monday. The federal indictment charges Infelice with a variety of offenses, including murder, racketeering conspiracy, illegal gambling and tax cheating. Infelice's lawyer, Patrick Tuite, said he thought the allegations on the tape were ``just a lot of hot air.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Now is the time to build a new legacy. Now is the time to move beyond the Cold War.'' _ Secretary of State James Baker before the Soviet legislature in Moscow.

``The logic of all this is getting very hard to explain to taxpayers.'' _ Sen. Larry Pressler, R-S.D., complaining to the U.S. ambassador to NATO about the Bush administration's refusal to make deeper cuts in U.S. troop strength in Europe.

``We have gained enough energy out of this celestial billiard shot to get the energy we need to make it all the say to Jupiter.'' _ Torrence Johnson, project scientist on NASA's Galileo space probe, after the robot explorer zoomed around Venus.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Three Children who Attended Center Have Sexual Disease
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Three children who attended a day-care center owned by a man charged with having child pornography contracted a sexually transmitted disease, police said. Authorities said no evidence links the infections to the preschool or its owner. Examinations found gonorrhea infections in the throats of three of the dozens of children examined at Broward County's Sexual Assault Treatment Center. The tests came after the arrest of preschool owner John W. Shaver, 56, two weeks ago on five counts of possessing child pornography for magazines police found at his home, across the street from his Rainbow Learning Center. Police would not say whether the children who tested positive were male or female and did not release their ages. Police have said 20 children who attended Shaver's preschool were identified by their parents in hundreds of nude photographs found at Shaver's house. The pictures do not depict sex acts or sexual poses, but show the children at play, authorities said. ``This is an ongoing investigation, and we can't answer any questions about the investigation itself,'' police Capt. Bruce Smith said during a news conference late Friday. ``There is, however, no direct evidence linking the disease to the facility'' or Shaver, Smith said. Police would not say whether Shaver tested positive for the disease. He remained under treatment Friday at the Crisis Stabilization Center in Pembroke Pines after cutting his wrist last week in an apparent suicide attempt. Shaver has denied any wrongdoing during the widening police investigation, saying ``I have not behaved improperly to any child.'' Neither police nor Joanne Richter, director of the treatment center, could say how the children may have been infected. ``The most likely hypothesis is they were forced to perform oral sex with the infected adult, most likely a male,'' said Dr. Sally S. Atherton, assistant professor of microbiology and immunology at the University of Miami School of Medicine. ``It's not something you pass around. It's a bacteria; it requires contact.'' The children have been treated, police said. Most cases of gonorrhea can be cured with penicillin or other antibiotics, especially if the disease is diagnosed early. Shaver was released on $5,000 bond last week on the charges of possessing child pornography, a third-degree felony punishable by a maximum five-year prison sentence. Shaver has admitted owning the magazines but denies taking nude photographs of children. Although the photographs themselves are not pornographic under the law, they could lead to sexual exploitation accusations against Shaver if the evidence meets that criteria, police have said. Police said they were being careful with the information they release about the case to prevent hysteria. ``Our No. 1 concern is the children,'' Maj. Joe Donisi said. ``We don't want to traumatize the kids into thinking something has happened.'' Broward County officials shut down Shaver's day-care center last week, contending Shaver ``lacked good moral character.'' About 200 children have attended the center since Shaver opened it in 1985 for children ages 3 to 5.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Promise to Occupy Buildings Until Officials Meet Demands
DOC.TEXT: Protesters upset over incidents stemming from the dismissal of a black superintendent promised to occupy Selma High School and City Hall until the majority white school board meets their demands. Many protesters planned to march today from a Selma church to the Edmund Pettus bridge, a landmark in the civil rights movement of 25 years ago, and then spend a second night in the high school and city hall. Connie Tucker, a spokeswoman for the protests, said the march would draw university students from across Alabama. The Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, was expected to attend, she said. In 1965, state troopers attacked civil rights marchers on the bridge. The marchers were on their way to a Montgomery demonstration. A federal judge, citing the students' right to freedom of speech, turned down city attorneys Friday who asked for him to intervene and block further disruptions at the buildings, where the protests have been orderly. U.S. District Judge Charles Butler of Mobile told J.L. Chestnut, a lawyer for the protesters, he was reluctant for the federal courts to step in but that excesses would force him to do so. ``He told me he recognized constitutional rights to exercise free speech,'' Chestnut said. Chestnut said he told protest leaders of the judge's concerns and indicated the buildings may be cleared by Monday. The racial turmoil began when six white members of the school board voted not to extend the contract of Norward Roussell, the city's first black superintendent. The dismissal of Roussell last week ignited protests that led to the closing of two schools Tuesday, and all 11 of Selma's public schools Wednesday. Roussell was reinstated after the initial protests. But the students want the school board to extend his contract, which expires this year. Four blacks protesting the dismissal of Roussell were arrested Monday during a melee at the office of white Mayor Joe Smitherman, who held office during the turmoil of the 1960s. A preliminary city report said allegations of police brutality at the protest was unfounded. Protesters also have pushed for commitments for a better education system for blacks. State Sen. Hank Sanders said the main issue is not that schoolchildren missed days in the classroom. At stake, he said, ``is the quality of education for the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Flee to Safety During Lull in Fighting
With PM-Lebanon
LaserPhoto NIC1
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 500 refugees from Christian battles in Lebanon arrived by ferry today at this port, telling tales of dodging gunfire and of gunmen using civilians for cover. ``The Lebanese have done some futile things before, but this must be the most futile ever,'' said one passenger, a British official, of the fighting. The clashes between rival Christian forces have left more than 400 people dead since Jan. 30. Most victims have been civilians. The ferry Sunny Boat steamed into Larnaca on the south coast of Cyprus after a nine-hour, 100-mile overnight voyage from Jounieh, a Christian town 10 miles north of Beirut. It was the first ferry to reach Lebanon in a week. The boat sailed for Lebanon on Friday after a shaky cease-fire was declared between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the Lebanese Forces militia of Samir Geagea. Despite the truce, both sides clashed today. Many of the refugees came from Christian districts of east Beirut, which have been the scene of fierce battles. Many had huddled in basements and bomb shelters for days and used the cease-fire to make a run for Jounieh. ``It's been terrible with all the fighting that raged around us,'' said Hala Habash, a middle-aged Christian woman accompanied by two teen-age children. ``It was very dangerous during the fighting. Gunmen moved from house to house during the street fighting. They took no notice of the people living in the houses,'' said Nawaz Ephraim, 19, who was accompanying his mother and two younger sisters. ``Sometimes they used the presence of non-combatants in the houses as cover,'' he said. A young mother with a little girl on her lap sat crying softly as she waited at the Cypriot immigration desk for her passport to be stamped. She refused to speak. But a friend said she had been separated from her husband and a 10-day-old baby during the fighting. ``We don't know if they're alive or dead,'' the friend said. A distraught middle-aged woman with a heavily bandaged foot limped off the ferry and her husband, who declined to be identified, said she had been wounded in the fighting. The British official, one of two who said they were on official business at their embassy in Beirut, said the damage in Dbaye had been ``quite extraordinary.'' He was referring to a coastal town north of Beirut that Aoun's forces wrested from the Lebanese Forces in hand-to-hand fighting a week ago. He said he and a companion had to drive to Jounieh from Beirut by a circuitous route over the mountains because the main coastal highway has been cut by the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached on Phased Plan for Elimination of Chemical Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Soviet Union today announced preliminary agreement on an American plan for a phased elimination of the two sides' chemical weapons. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said at a news conference at the end of three days of talks with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III that the Soviets had accepted the U.S. proposal ``and as a result of negotiations have agreed on a mutually acceptable draft of a prospective agreement of principle.'' ``We believe such an agreement could be signed during President Gorbachev's visit to the United States,'' he added. The Soviet leader is scheduled to travel to Washington in June to meet with President Bush. The announcement had been expected after Baker's talks with Shevardnadze and Gorbachev. In a joint statement, the two sides pledged that after a multilateral treaty is reached in negotiations in Geneva, they will ``reduce their chemical weapons stocks to equal levels at a very small fraction of their present holdings over the first eight years of operation of the convention.'' ``All remaining chemical weapons stocks should be eliminated over the subsequent two years,'' the statement said. The statement pledged the two sides to work out the last details even while a conference on banning chemical weapons continues in Geneva. In a speech to the U.N. General Assembly last year, Bush proposed to keep 2 percent of U.S. stockpiles of weapons until all countries deemed capable of producing chemical weapons have signed an international treaty. About a dozen countries, including Libya and Iran, are thought to possess chemical weapons, although only the United States and Soviet Union admit having the deadly substances.

DOC.HEAD: Columnist Accuses PLO of Slack Response to Massacre
DOC.TEXT: A journalist closely tied to President Hosni Mubarak today criticized PLO chief Yasser Arafat for failing to condemn a terrorist massacre of nine Israelis on a bus in Egypt. The new criticism escalated a war of words over the attack between the Palestine Liberation Organization and Egypt, jeopardizing efforts to organize Israel-Palestinian peace talks. The article by editor Ibrahim Seda on the front page of the mass-circulation weekly Akhbar el-Yom's was the third article criticizing the PLO since the attack Sunday. But it was the first that blamed Arafat himself. All three articles appeared in state-owned newspapers and were written by their top editors, all known to be close to Mubarak. The media onslaught signaled strains in relations between Egypt and the PLO. Such tensions imperil American efforts to organize Palestinian-Israeli peace talks because Egypt has been relaying PLO positions to both the United States and Israel. Israel outrage over the attack has also made organizing such talks more difficult. Mubarak sent a message to Arafat this week that sources close to the government said was believed to have voiced displeasure over the PLO's reaction to the attack. The PLO said Monday in Tunisia that the incident should be placed in the context of the hundreds of Palestinians who died in the 26-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. In his article, Seda called the statement ``flimsy and silly'' for omitting a denunciation of the terrorist attack and comparing it to the violence in the occupied lands. The bus carrying 31 Israeli vacationers was attacked by two gunmen, who showered it with automatic fire and hand grenades on a desert highway between Cairo and the Suez Canal city of Ismailia. Newspapers have quoted security officials as saying the gunmen were Palestinians but that no arrests have been made. ``We expected Yasser Arafat to react by flying to Cairo immediately to declare to the world his personal and the Palestinian people's condemnation of this criminal act,'' Seda wrote in his weekly, which claims a circulation of more than 1 million. He said Arafat should at least have broadcast a statement ``in his own voice'' censuring the attack and vowing to ``help the Egyptian security apparatus uncover the Palestinian terrorist perpetrators.'' The PLO's Cairo representative, Saeed Kamal, told the Middle East News Agency today that his organization was cooperating with Egyptian security authorities, passing to them any information it had about the ambush. However, Kamal said he could not rule out the possibility of ``Israeli responsibility'' for the attack, aiming to obstruct peace talks. The chill in Egyptian-PLO relations was the worst since Mubarak shut down seven PLO offices in Egypt for seven months in 1987 after the Palestine National Council, the organization's parliament in exile, criticized Cairo's 1979 peace treaty with Israel. Another state-owned newspaper, Al-Ahram, today reported that the ambush was plotted inside Israel or the occupied territories. The newspaper quoted an unidentified Interior Ministry official for the report.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Bonn
Kohl Arrives in Moscow To Reassure Soviets on United Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl arriving in Moscow, remarks by Shevardnadze. Pickup 6th pvs, `The issue...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany arrived in Moscow today for talks aimed at reassuring the Soviets that a reunited Germany would not threaten their security. Kohl, accompanied by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, was to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in one of a series of high-level consultations planned in the East and West about German reunification. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told a news conference in Moscow before Kohl's arrival that one of the key issues to be discussed was the need for a German guarantee on stable borders. He also expressed support for a ``neutral, demilitarized'' Germany. The chancellor has argued that Soviet security interests would not be threatened if the two German states merged into a country of 80 million people in the heart of Europe. After returning from the weekend talks in Moscow, Kohl will meet in Bonn with East German Premier Hans Modrow, see French President Francois Mitterrand and meet President Bush in Camp David _ all in one week. The issue of unification has assumed urgency in recent days because of the instability of the East German economy. With Modrow, Kohl is expected to discuss plans to make the West German mark the currency in both states. Bonn hopes such a move would slow the exodus of people from East Germany who have lost faith in their country's future. Nearly 2,000 East Germans are leaving their country daily, crippling an economy already troubled by strikes and absenteeism. A high-ranking West German government official, briefing reporters on Kohl's trip to Moscow on the condition of anonymity, said East Germany could become insolvent in a matter of days. He also said free elections, already moved up from May to March 18, might have to be advanced further. The report was quickly denied by East German government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer and by Kohl's own spokesman, Hans Klein. Klein said the Bonn government did not think that East Germany's economy is in danger of collapsing in the next few days, but that some West German leaders believe that is the case. The official who briefed reporters said the grim assessment was provided by some East German officials. Lothar de Maiziere, leader of the East German Christian Democratic Party and one of Modrow's deputies in the Cabinet, was quoted by West Germany's mass-circulation newspaper Bild as saying the situation in the country could become critical in two or three weeks. Since the ouster of hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker in October and the opening of the Berlin Wall the following month, reunification has become an urgent issue. Some Europeans, recalling Nazi Germany's march through Europe in World War II, fear a united Germany could again become a military threat. Genscher has sought to allay European fears by saying that both nations should soon sign an agreement not to build nuclear weapons or encroach on the borders of neighboring countries. The superpowers worry that such a union could make their military alliances crumble. NATO has about 255,000 troops in West Germany, most of them Americans. More than 380,000 Soviet soldiers are stationed in East Germany, a key member of the Warsaw Pact. Modrow has proposed that a united Germany be neutral, but Western nations have uniformly rejected that stand. Officials in Bonn have proposed that what is now West Germany could remain with NATO and the territory that was East Germany could technically be neutral. Genscher also proposed that the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe meet in Berlin this fall to discuss new security arrangements for Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Harbor Pilots Call Launch Strike, Claim Unsafe Conditions
DOC.TEXT: Shipping pilots who steer oil tankers and freighters into Los Angeles Harbor struck today over what they call unsafe working conditions that could trigger another massive oil spill. At least one serious near-collision at the heavily traveled port was due to conditions that included understaffing, fatigue, stress and the hurried training of newcomers, said pilot Capt. Joe Silva, president of the Los Angeles Pilots Association. ``We could have a disaster,'' Silva said in a telephone interview today. ``It's totally unsafe to the public _ another Valdez waiting to happen.'' Port Capt. James C. Card ordered closure to the harbor of vessels without a local pilot aboard, the U.S. Coast Guard said. Nine vessels were scheduled to enter the harbor this morning, with two management pilot supervisors reportedly on hand to steer four of them to anchorages, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Carolyn Feldman. No immediate arrangements for the remaining five ships were made. Pilots voted Friday night to walk off the job at 3 a.m. today, said Wallace Knox, attorney for the Masters, Mates & Pilots Branch 68. Dock workers were expected to honor the strike, meaning the vessels brought into the harbor would be unable to berth, Ms. Feldman said. Telephone calls from The Associated Press to the Harbor Department seeking comment on the strike early today went unanswered. ``The Harbor Department has been ordering a number of unsafe acts in the past several weeks and has been ordering untrained pilots to bring vessels into the harbor,'' said Knox. He cited a near-collision Jan. 24 between an oil tanker and another ship inside Los Angeles Harbor. The ships passed within 8 feet of each other, forcing one pilot to drop anchor within the harbor channel, rupturing a fuel pipeline in the process, Silva said. ``Despite such near misses, the Harbor Department has persisted in irresponsible actions which raise serious safety concerns,'' Silva said. Silva said work weeks topping 84 hours were common, 10 pilots often handled jobs designed for a staff of 16, and hiring officials were slow to fill vacancies, prompting the rushed training of newcomers. He said the harbor department had assigned the moving of vessels ``to a completely untrained trainee.'' Pilots had filed an action over the safety violations with the Los Angeles Employee Relations Board, he said. Branch 68 operates only in Los Angeles and none of its members was involved in this week's Huntington Beach spill. Almost 300,000 gallons of Alaska crude spilled from the tanker American Trader on Wednesday, possibly after the tanker was gashed by its own anchor.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Riot in Protest of New Governing Party
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of radical students shouting anti-government and anti-U.S. slogans fought riot poice today with firebombs and rocks to protest the creation of a new conservative governing coalition. Shouting ``Crush the conservative dictatorship!'' 700 students rushed out of Seoul's Jooang University and pelted riot police with hundreds of firebombs and rocks. About 600 riot police stopped the students at the school's main gate, firing barrages of tear gas canisters. No police figures on injuries and arrests were immediately available. The fighting began after 1,000 riot troopers sealed off Korea University in eastern Seoul to stop a joint anti-government rally involving radical students from major schools in Seoul. Radical students and dissidents have stepped up violent protests against the merger of President Roh Tae-woo's governing party and two moderate opposition groups led by Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil. The new coalition, the Democratic Liberal Party, excluded the leftist opposition Party for Peace and Democracy, led by Kim Dae-jung. In leaflets scattered today, the students claimed the merger was instigated by the United States to establish a pro-U.S. government in South Kroea. They also demanded the immediate withdrwal of U.S. troops based under a mutual defense pact and shouted anti-U.S. slogans. The new party will hold at least 210 of the 299 seats in the National Assembly, enough to change the nation's constitution at will. The unicameral assembly had been controlled by the three opposition parties, led by Kim Dae-jung's party. On Friday, delegates from the three parties formally endorsed their merger and ratified the new party's platform, constitution and basic policies. The new governing party was formed with the goal of bringing stability to the nation's faction-ridden politics, in which the three opposition parties had been unable to settle their own feuds to pass legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Challenges Soviets to End Support for Cuba, Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES top 10 grafs with tentative agreement on chemical weapons, Shevardnadze comments, picking up 6th graf pvs, Three times ...; EDITS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III challenged the Soviet Union on Saturday to end military and financial support to Marxist Cuba and came under a blizzard of criticism from Soviet officials about U.S. arms spending and the invasion of Panama. The tough question-and-answer session in an unprecedented appearance before the Soviet legislature contrasted with upbeat statements by both Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on their three days of talks, and an agreement on a U.S. approach to banning chemical weapons. The two sides agreed on a 10-year phased elimination of their chemical weapons tied to an international agreement in Geneva negotiations. In an allusion to Arthur Koestler's novel about Stalinism, Baker lectured his hosts about the ``darkness at noon'' era of the past and said the American people and Congress cannot understand how the Soviet government can send billions of rubles of assistance to countries like Cuba and Nicaragua.
