Not only were those countries supporting subversion in the Western hemisphere, Baker said, the Soviet aid ``is even less comprehensible when it happens at a time when your people clearly need those scarce resources put to good use at home.'' Baker spoke in an 18th century ceremonial hall, with a marble bust of Lenin behind him. His audience was the International Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet. It was the first time a U.S. government official had appeared in the legislative chamber, an event Baker attributed to reforms undertaken by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``For over 40 years, we have waged a cold war against one other,`` Baker said. ``Now is the time to put the legacy of struggle behind us ... Now is the time to build a new legacy. Now is the time to move beyond the cold war.'' Shevardnadze, in a news conference, said a ``large measure of progress'' had been made in the talks on a variety of arms control issues and that an agreement on chemical weapons probably could be signed at the Washington summit in June. Gorbachev, in a nearly three-hour meeting with Baker on Friday, countered U.S. President George Bush's proposal for cutting the number of soldiers in Central Europe. He urged Bush to extend the plan to th entire continent, including 30,000 troops excluded by the U.S. plan. While complimenting the steps taken under Gorbachev, including the historic decision this week to end the Communist Party's monopoly on political power, Baker salted his speech with a thrust at Soviet support for Marxist countries. Three times Baker called Soviet support for Cuba intolerable. He complained about the shipment of new MiG jet fighter planes and questioned why Moscow was aiding President Fidel Castro when he is so critical of Gorbachev's policies. ``We remain especially disturbed by the military shipments your government continues to send to those seeking military solutions to conflicts in regions vital to us,'' he said. Several committee members challenged Baker on the invasion of Panama and on several arms control fronts, including U.S. refusal to join the Soviets in a moratorium on nuclear weapons testing or to consider naval disarmament. Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, a military adviser to Gorbachev, said the United States at the end of World War II had encircled the Soviet Union with military bases and had not retreated from that policy. Akhromeyev, a leading figure in U.S.-Soviet arms control accords, questioned why the U.S. administration only trimmed defense spending, while the Soviets were cutting their defense budget by 14 percent as East-West tensions ease. Yevgeny M. Primakov, chairman of the Soviet of the Union, one of the two chambers of the Supreme Soviet, challenged the Bush administration to join the Soviet Union in guaranteeing not to use force in Latin America. Baker also was pressed to explain why U.S. warships were exempt from arms control negotiations. In reply, Baker returned to the issue of Soviet support for Cuba and Nicaragua. He said the military action in Panama was unique and designed to remove Gen. Manual Noriega from power while restoring democracy. The secretary of state also said a strong navy was essential to the United States, which he described as sort of an island nation. The 90-minute session wound up Baker's four-day visit to Moscow, which was capped by a Gorbachev counterproposal to President Bush on troop reductions in Europe and headway toward arms control agreements. Baker then headed for Bulgaria, a Soviet ally in the midst of a rocky evolution away from hard-line communism. He will stop Sunday in Romania, which is undergoing an even rougher transition, before traveling to Ottawa, Canada, for a meeting with the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. Baker appeared before the committee after conducting marathon talks Friday with Gorbachev and other Soviet officials, during which he said progress was made toward agreements cutting long-range nuclear warheads and chemical weapons. Gorbachev urged the United States to remove 30,000 more U.S. troops from Europe by extending Bush's troop ceiling for Europe's central front to the entire continent. Among questions remaining after Baker's talks with Soviet leaders are the superpower differences over West and East Germany. The Soviet Union insists a unified Germany should be neutral; Baker pressed the U.S. position that a united Germany should continue an ``association with'' NATO. On arms control, Baker said the two sides settled the questions of access to missile data during flight tests, where to store non-deployed missiles and how many air-launched cruise missiles may be carried by bombers. But details about the range of those missiles remain unsettled, he added. The issues are part of negotiations on a treaty to slash long-range U.S. and Soviet nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines that Bush and Gorbachev would like to sign at their summit meeting in Washington in June.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcasting Chief Resigns; Opposition Steps Up to Bat in New Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with broadcasting chief resigning, quotes. Pickup 10th graf, `The first...'
DOC.TEXT: Romania's embattled chief of broadcasting said today he was resigning because of intensifying ``political conflicts'' over the freedom of state-run television. Opposition members have accused the revolutionary government of using TV as a political weapon. It has been one of the key issues as Romania prepares for its first free multiparty elections since World War II. Broadcasting chief Aurel Dragos Munteanu said his goal had been to promote freedom of information, and he worried that Romanians had been so poisoned by the legacy of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu that they looked for ``betrayal and hatred'' in every word, even those spoken sincerely. On Jan. 29, Munteanu resigned as chief spokesman of the ruling council of the National Salvation Front in response to criticism by the opposition. But almost daily demonstrations outside broadcasting headquarters since then also demanded his resignation as president of Romanian Radio and Television, saying he was too tied to the front, which had decided to contest the elections in May. Protesters demanded that the freedom won during December's revolution which toppled Ceausescu be transferred to the TV screen. Munteanu's letter of resignation, published today on the front page of major newspapers, drew bigger headlines than Friday's first meeting of the new Council of National Unity which will run Romania until elections. In what was billed as perhaps the first democratically made decision in 40 years, the new Council of National Unity agreed to expand from 180 to 259 members to provide a broad base for the new interim government. The outgoing National Salvation Front agreed to the coalition government after protests of its decision to field candidates in the election. The front, which included many Communist Party veterans, had ruled without opposition participation. The consensus to increase the new body's membership came after more than four hours of debate at the former National Assembly building. Interim President Ion Iliescu, who led the outgoing front's ruling council, presided over the meeting. Election of the new council president was apparently put off, with Iliescu a strong favorite. ``This first meeting, which was quite heated, led to consensus and a final list of council members,'' Iliescu said at the end of the 7{-hour session. An earlier decision to increase the council to 241 members was expanded to give even greater representation. The assembly building is being used for the first time since the uprising against Ceausescu, who was overthrown Dec. 22 and executed three days later. The council agreed to meet again Tuesday. The first four hours of debate Friday centered on whether nine new parties registered in the last week should be given seats and on questions regarding the seating of ethnic groups. In the expanded council, 114 seats went to 38 parties, 27 seats to nine organizations representing ethnic minorities, three seats will be filled by former political prisoners, and 114 seats go to prominent Romanians from all walks of life who were part of the National Salvation Front. The president is to fill the remaining seat. Before Friday's session, the legality of the decree creating the council was challenged by the National Peasants Party, which opposed granting a large number of seats to former National Front members. It later dropped its challenge. In another development, a colonel awaiting trial on charges of complicity in genocide during the revolution committed suicide by hanging himself with his belt in a jail cell in Timosoara, the daily Romania Libera reported Friday. Before his suicide, Col. Petre Moraru told journalists of details of a clandestine operation to transfer the bodies of people killed in the first days of the revolt from Timisoara to Bucharest to be cremated. Also Friday, Silviu Brucan, who resigned from the front leadership last month, confirmed that some of Ceausescu's hated Securitate secret police remained at large.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Rebels Open New Offensive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Eritrean official saying peace talks will be held. Pickup 8th pvs, `In a...'
DOC.TEXT: Secessionist rebels in the northern province of Eritrea have launched a major new offensive, threatening government access to a vital port and food shipments to millions of drought victims. The offensive, which the rebels said began Thursday along a 120-mile front, ended a nearly yearlong lull in fighting in the region and plunged all four of Ethiopia's northern provinces back into civil war. The government confirmed the new fighting Friday night, and a government radio station in Asmara, the capital of Eritrea, said battles were raging today. In a statement, the Ethiopian government said the renewed fighting ``has now dimmed the prospects of resolving the Eritrean problem through the stalled peace talks'' and accused the rebels of ``using the peace talks as a subterfuge to prepare extensively for this destructive war.'' But a senior Eritrean official said today in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, that the rebels will meet Ethiopian government envoys in the North Yemen capital of San'a on Feb. 15 in a new bid to resolve their 28-year-old conflict. Saleh Ahmed Ayai, deputy chairman of the Eritrean Liberation Front-Unified Organization, told The Associated Press the talks were in response to a mediation effort by North Yemen's President, Ali Abdullah Saleh. The meeting had earlier been tentatively set for Feb. 1, but it was postponed when Saleh visited the United States. Former President Jimmy Carter sponsored similar peace talks between another Eritrean faction, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, and the Addis Ababa government late last year in Atlanta and in Nairobi, Kenya. The Eritreans' secessionist campaign is Africa's longest-running conflict. The new offensive also has jeopardized plans by the United Nations to provide food in the next few months for an estimated 4 million drought victims in northern Ethiopia, mostly in the provinces of Eritrea and Tigre. The attack by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front came as the government appeared to be containing another offensive farther south by the Tigre People's Liberation Front, a separate insurgent group. The government said the Eritrean rebels' main objective appeared to be the capture of Massawa, the largest of only two ports on Ethiopia's Red Sea coast. The other is at Asab, near the country's border with Djibouti. In a clandestine radio broadcast, the rebels said they had taken control of the road from Asmara to Massawa, 40 miles northeast of the provincial capital, in what they described as ``a crushing offensive.'' ``The operation was very broad and and swift and the victory very great,'' said the Voice of the Broad Masses of Eritrea. It claimed rebel forces had scattered the government army deployed along the road. The Eritrean rebels have been fighting for independence for their province, once an Italian colony, since 1961 in what has become Africa's oldest war. The Tigrean rebels, based in the province just south of Eritrea, launched their own offensive in August, pushing government troops out of their last remaining strongholds in Tigre and sweeping south and east into the provinces of Wollo and Gondor. The government declared a mass mobilization in September. In a counteroffensive in January, it recaptured some of the towns and garrisons taken earlier by the Tigrean insurgents. Although their aims are different, the Eritrean and Tigrean rebels have coordinated attacks against the government in the past. The Tigreans, unlike the Eritreans, seek the complete overthrow of the Marxist regime of President Mengistu Haile Marian and its replacement with what they describe as a government modeled after that of Albania, the last hard-line communist government in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christians Battle Despite Cease-Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE casualties, reported mutiny. Pickup 6th graf, ``The situation...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces clashed with artillery and machine guns today in violation of a cease-fire in their 12-day-old power struggle. Frightened rescuers left corpses to rot in Beirut's streets. By police count, at least 433 people have been killed and 1,684 wounded, most of them civilians, since the battle for leadership of an estimated 1 million Christians broke out Jan. 30. The fighters have not given rescuers guarantees to remove bodies that have been in the streets for days. Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the Lebanese Forces militia, commanded by Samir Geagea, appeared to be gearing up for more savage attacks. An anti-Aoun Christian radio station reported a mutiny among his 19,000 troops, one week after 1,000 soldiers defected to the Lebanese Forces or to a Moslem commander in west Beirut. Today's report could not be immediately verified. The two sides clashed during the night and early morning with machine guns in several districts of Christian east Beirut. Snipers dueled constantly. Three people were killed and four wounded during heavy shelling, police said. ``The situation does not indicate that the cease-fire's going to hold,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations. Aoun's gunners bombarded a militia unit that blew up the Daraya bridge northeast of Beirut. Geagea's gunners responded with heavy shelling to cover the unit's withdrawal, the police spokesman said. He said Geagea's artillery also shelled Aoun's howitzer emplacements in the Bekfaya region north of Beirut. Geagea's headquarters said in a communique that Aoun's artillery was shelling ``population centers'' in northern Kesrouan province. This month's fighting has been the bloodiest between Christian forces since Lebanon's civil war began in 1975. The police spokesman said several decomposing corpses remained in streets that form a no-man's land between Geagea's men and Aoun's troops in east Beirut. ``Civil defense teams haven't been able to obtain guarantees from both sides that they won't shoot at them while evacuating the corpses,'' the spokesman said. ``Civil defense officials believe some of the corpses are booby-trapped, and that's why the combatants want to keep them there,'' he added. The police spokesman reported no progress in efforts to put into effect a truce worked out Friday by representatives of both sides. Aoun has accused Geagea of trying to enforce an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the nation's civil war. The October accord, worked out by Lebanese legislators in Saudi Arabia, led to the formation of a government under President Elias Hrawi, also a Christian. Aoun attacked the pact because it set no date for withdrawal of the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon. Aoun, who was appointed last year to head an interim cabinet, has refused to acknowledge Hrawi's government or obey his orders to quit his army post. The Syrian soldiers, who control most of the country, were deployed in Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League mandate to quell fighting between Moslems and Christians. However, Aoun says they violated their peacekeeping mandate by siding with the Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: White Extremists Demonstrate Against Government Reforms
With PM-Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of white extremists, some screaming ``Hang Mandela!'' staged a boisterous demonstration today against government race reforms and demanded a return to strict apartheid. In Johannesburg, police used tear gas and batons to disperse about 100 people protesting the presence of a boycott-breaking English cricket team. About 500 members of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, many in khaki uniforms and armed with truncheons, gathered in downtown Pretoria to march on government buildings. The organization, led by the charismatic Eugene TerreBlanche, favors a strengthening of segregation laws, opposes the government's decision to free black leader Nelson Mandela, and views President F.W. de Klerk's reforms as capitulation to the black majority. The movement, which seeks a whites-only homeland, has threatened to take up arms against the government if white privilege is threatened. Before the march began, some members of the movement began shouting ``Hang Mandela!'' De Klerk on Friday warned that conservative whites who have criticized the concessions could ignite a racial war in South Africa. De Klerk has promised to release Mandela, the country's best known black leader. Mandela, 71, has been imprisoned since 1962 for helping to plan the start of the African National Congress' sabotage campaign. A lawyer for Mandela's family said Mandela could be released today. Outside Wanderers cricket stadium in Johannesburg, police dispersed about 100 demonstrators protesting the rebel cricket tour. Although a magistrate had banned any marches to the stadium, the protesters were allowed to make their way several blocks through a residential neighborhood to Wanderers. Some white spectators in the stadium jeered at the protesters, and a few threw beer at them. As the protesters began to march away from the stadium, police ordered the crowd to disperse. After a few moments, police charged into the marchers, spraying tear gas and hitting people with batons.

DOC.HEAD: Workers, Volunteers Tackle Oil-Fouled Beaches
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of workers and volunteers sopped up oily goo tarnishing miles of scenic beaches and boats skimmed crude from the water as the expanding slick from a ruptured tanker drifted northward. The cleanup effort Friday seemed no match for the spill of up to 300,000 gallons from the 811-foot American Trader. Methods to soak up the slippery, viscous goo were inefficient, some said. ``This is a small oil spill,'' said filmmaker Jean-Michel Cousteau, son of renowned oceanographer Jacques Cousteau. ``We don't know how to pick it up. We do not have the technology. We are not prepared.'' The midweek spill from the British Petroleum-operated tanker left oily globules along 18 miles of coastline, from Seal Beach to Newport Beach, where a dark brown tide marred the city's beaches. Officials there declared a state of emergency. By morning, southerly winds had blown the oil slick northward over two more miles of ocean, lengthening it to 12 miles long. ``Medium concentrations'' of frothy, wind-whipped oil washed ashore along three miles of Huntington Beach, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Dennis Hall. Winds turned offshore by sunrise, sending fingers of the slick reaching westward, expanding its width to 3{ miles, according to updated overflight charts. Hall said the slick reached northward to the Long Beach breakwater near Anaheim Bay, he said. Long Beach is a major ocean port adjacent to Los Angeles Harbor, another heavily traveled sea port. A long breakwater protects both. Meanwhile, Los Angeles harbor pilots struck today to protest what they called unsafe working conditions caused by fatigue and untrained pilots. Those pilots were not involved in the spill to the south in Huntington Beach. Two management pilot supervisors planned to steer four of nine scheduled tankers into port today but the ships would have to wait at offshore anchorages because dock workers honored the pilots strike, the Coast Guard said. Several hundred workers hired by the oil shipper and an equal number of volunteers worked around the clock to soak up the goo at Newport Beach. They filled hundreds of trash bags with towels, fouled sand and oil. ``Are we out of the woods? No, not yet,'' said Charles Webster, crisis manager for British Petroleum. ``But we're working to stay ahead of the curve.'' Workers in yellow waterproof gear combed the muck overnight near the Huntington Beach Pier with a backhoe, blotted oil with absorbent pads and dragged blue plastic pompons across the beach to soaked up oily pools. Residents scoured the sand with brooms and dust pans and carried oil-soaked sea birds to an emergency station. But cleanup officials, worried about chemical hazards and liability, urged them to leave the job to hired crews. British Petroleum said 390 cleanup workers were cleaning a 20-mile coastal stretch from Bolsa Chica to Laguna Beach. Nine skimmers were at work on the slick a mile offshore and others were en route. Fifty-four oil-soaked birds, including 11 dead, were reported Friday by Susan Rimerman, spokeswoman for International Bird Rescue and Research, a group hired by the state Fish and Game department. Department biologist John Grant said 12 birds had died. There were no reports of oil entering the wildlife habitats of the Bolsa Chica Wetlands, the Santa Ana River mouth and upper Newport Bay, where booms blocked their entrances. But there was concern the slick might drift south to Laguna Beach, the scenic art colony fronted by rocky tide pools teeming with marine life. Webster said a cleanup company was placed on call there. The Coast Guard pumped out 1 million gallons of oil still inside the forward hold of the tanker. Officials said the American Trader, which carried 21 million gallons of crude, may have been gashed by its own anchor on Wednesday as it tried to moor near a pipeline. Cousteau, who flew over the slick early Friday, said the skimming equipment aboard the boats was not working. ``You look at skimmers. Everybody is working very hard,'' Cousteau said. ``It goes right under the boom. ... I mean I filmed it there. We are not being efficient and we do not have the technology to be efficient.'' John Turner, director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, said good weather had kept the slick offshore and available resources had helped cleanup efforts. ``To date we've been lucky,'' Turner said. But he warned that ``there's a lot of oil that could come ashore.'' He said chemical dispersants would not be used due to the slick's proximity to shore and the potential danger of toxicity to animals. Fines and penalties were under consideration because of the dead and injured birds, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quotations from Nelson Mandela
With PM-Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from some of the few public statements by Nelson Mandela since he was jailed in 1962: _April 20, 1964, at his trial before he was convicted of sabotage and sentenced to life in prison: ``A time comes in the life of any nation where there remains only two choices _ submit or fight. That time has now come to South Africa. We shall not submit and we have no choice but to hit back by all the means in our power in defense of our people, our future, our freedom. ``During my lifetime, I have dedicated myself to this struggle of the African people. I have fought against white domination and I have fought against black domination. ... ``I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. ... ``It is an ideal which I hope to live for and achieve, but if need be an ideal for which I am prepared to die.''

_January, 1985, to Samuel Dash, American law professor and chief counsel for the Senate Watergate Committee: ``Unlike white people anywhere else in Africa, whites in South Africa belong here _ this is their home. We want them to live here with us and to share power with us.''

Feb. 10, 1985, rejecting President P.W. Botha's offer of conditional release, in statement read by his daughter, Zinzi: ``Let him (Botha) renounce violence. ``Let him say that he will dismantle apartheid. ... Let him free all who have been imprisoned, banished or exiled for their opposition to apartheid. Let him guarantee free political activity so that the people may decide who will govern them. ... ``I cherish my own freedom dearly but I care even more for your freedom. Too many have died since I went to prison. Too many have suffered for the love of freedom. ... I cannot sell my birthright nor am I prepared to sell the birthright of the people to be free. ``Only free men can negotiate. ... I cannot and will not give any undertaking at a time when I and you the people are not free. Your freedom and mine cannot be separated. I shall return.''

_January, 1989, to Lord Nicholas Bethell, a British member of the European Parliament: ``I am a socialist and I believe in a classless society. ``The armed struggle was forced on us. ... We go for hard targets only, military installations and the symbols of apartheid. Civilians must not be touched. ... ``'All this can end as soon as talks begin. It would be humiliating, though, for us simply to lay down our arms unconditionally.''
DOC.HEAD: What others have said about Mandela:
DOC.TEXT: _Zulu leader Mangosothu Buthelezi, a prominent black moderate and critic of the ANC: ``Nothing the South African government can do will gain credibility while it treats Dr. Mandela as a dangerous enemy. Black South Africa will not rest until he is free. ``I believe he would come out of jail to thump anybody ... who set black brother against black brother on the eve of a final victory over apartheid.''
_Dr. Nthato Motlana, an anti-apartheid activist from Soweto: ``He is the one man who, assuming he is willing, could lead us out of this mess.''

_Helen Suzman, anti-apartheid member of Parliament, who has visited Mandela several times: ``He's a man who has got surprisingly moderate views after all these years. He's not embittered. ... I believe he would genuinely attempt to negotiate some peaceful solution to South Africa's problems.''

_Samuel Dash, after meeting Mandela in 1985: ``He appeared vigorous and healthy, with a calm, confident manner and dignified bearing that seemed incongruous in our prison surroundings. ... I felt that I was in the presence not of a guerrilla fighter or radical ideologue, but of a head of state.''

_The Commonwealth's Eminent Persons Group, which met Mandela in 1986 during an unsuccessful attempt to promote dialogue aimed at ending apartheid: ``He is an isolated and lonely figure, bearing his incarceration with courage and fortitude, anxious to be reunited with his wife and family but determined that this can only be under circumstances which allow for his unconditional release.'' ``His freedom is a key component in any hope of a peaceful resolution to a conflict which otherwise will prove all-consuming.''

_President P.W. Botha, in January 1985: ``The government is willing to consider Mr. Mandela's release ... on condition that Mr. Mandela gives a commitment that he will not make himself guilty of planning, instigating or committing acts of violence. ... It is therefore not the South African government which now stands in the way of Mr. Mandela's freedom. It is he himself.''

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela, South African Black Nationalist
With PM-Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, given a life sentence for plotting to overthrow the South African government, became the world's most influential prisoner during what he described as ``long, lonely, wasted years.'' Mandela was unheard and unseen by the public since 1962, but nevertheless he came to be the most admired leader among South African blacks, who consider him the embodiment of their quest for political freedom. He rejected the government's repeated offers to release him if he would renounce violence or live in a tribal homeland. He said the government should renounce violence, end apartheid and lift the ban on his movement _ the African National Congress. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC and 60 other organizations on Feb. 2, and announced Mandela would be freed soon, although apartheid and restrictive security laws remained in place. In the meantime, Mandela had met regularly with government officials during the past year and issued statements saying he wanted to work for peace. Today, de Klerk announced that Mandela, 71, would be released unconditionally Sunday. After his historic meeting on July 5, 1989 with President P.W. Botha, a statement by Mandela was released by the Prisons Service and broadcast on government-run radio and television. He said he had not deviated ``from the position I have taken over the past 28 years, namely that dialogue with the mass democratic movement and, in particular, with the African National Congress, is the only way of ending violence and bringing peace to our country. ``I only would like to contribute to the creation of a climate which would promote peace in South Africa,'' Mandela said. De Klerk replaced Botha in August 1989, and met with Mandela at his Cape Town office on Dec. 13, 1989 amid intense expectations that the prisoner would be freed in the new year. Mandela regularly entertained his family and streams of friends in a comfortable house at the Victor Verster prison farm in the wine-growing region of Paarl. He had been transferred there on Dec. 6, 1988 after recovering from tuberculosis contracted at Pollsmoor Prison in Cape Town in August. Expectations of his release had been raised before, but each time the government balked at freeing the man many blacks believed should be their president. Former Information Minister Stoffel van der Merwe said in July 1988 that Mandela had served enough time to pay for his crimes and that the only thing keeping him in prison was the government's uncertainty about the effect he would have on politics and national security. It was a tacit admission of what Botha had denied for years _ that Mandela was a political prisoner. In 1985, Botha allowed Zindzi Mandela to read her father's response to the latest offer of conditional release before a crowd in Soweto, the township outside Johannesburg where Mandela had rented a home since the 1940s. ``Only free men can negotiate. Prisoners cannot enter into contracts,'' Mandela said. ``I cherish my own freedom dearly but I care even more for your freedom. Too many have died since I went to prison. Too many have suffered for the love of freedom. Not only I have suffered during these long, lonely, wasted years.'' During his imprisonment Mandela was regarded as the leader of the African National Congress, although the highest office he held before it was banned in 1960 was deputy president-general. He was the first commander of its military wing, ``Spear of the Nation,'' which he helped form in 1961 to engage in a program of sabotage. He subsequently toured Africa, receiving military training and explaining the ANC's cause. He was arrested after his return, in 1962, and sentenced to five years' hard labor for leaving the country illegally and inciting blacks to violate the law by striking. Mandela told the court that when his sentence was ended he would ``take up again, as best I can, the struggle for the removal of those injustices until they are finally abolished once and for all.'' ``I have no doubt that posterity will pronounce that I was innocent, and that the criminals that should have been brought before this court are the members of the ... government,'' he said. In July 1963, while Mandela was at the Robben Island maximum-security prison near Cape Town, police uncovered the ANC's underground headquarters on a farm near Johannesburg and seized documents outlining plans for the guerrilla campaign, including Mandela's diary. In June 1964, he and seven co-defendants were sentenced to life in prison. ``I do not deny that I planned sabotage,'' he said in his statement from the dock. ``I did not plan it in a spirit of recklessness, nor because I have any love of violence. I planned it as a result of a calm and sober assessment of the political situation that had arisen after years of tyranny, exploitation and oppression of my people by whites.'' He said he ``cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. ... It is an ideal which I hope to live for and achieve, but if need be an ideal for which I am prepared to die.'' His wife, Winnie, jailed or banished through much of his imprisonment, said, ``In each and every single letter he has written over the past 20 years and in each and every visit, he has always been confident that he will come out and lead his people to liberation.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa:
DOC.TEXT: During most of his 18 years on Robben Island, Mandela endured substandard food, deprivation of news and reading material, and hard labor that included gathering seaweed and smashing rock. Yet he often wrote his wife that the hardest thing to endure was the treatment she received. He wrote that he sometimes wondered ``whether any kind of commitment can ever be sufficient excuse for abandoning a young and inexperienced woman in a pitiless desert.'' In April 1982, Mandela and five colleagues were transferred to Pollsmoor Prison in a white suburb outside Cape Town. They shared a large cell where Mandela cultivated a vegetable garden and complained about the conditions. He was allowed to pursue his studies for an advanced law degree, which he received in early 1989, and eventually began receiving uncensored newspapers and radio reports. Mandela's communications with his wife and family were restricted to 40-minute visits and one 500-word letter per month, monitored to make sure only family matters were discussed. On May 12, 1984, Mandela and his wife were allowed to embrace for the first time in 22 years. Mandela was born July 18, 1918, the son of a tribal chief, and received a relatively privileged upbringing in Transkei, a Xhosa homeland the government has declared an independent republic. He attended Methodist schools and was admitted to the black University of Fort Hare in 1938, but was expelled in 1940 for leading a student strike with Oliver Tambo, now the ANC's exiled president. To avoid an arranged tribal marriage, Mandela fled to Johannesburg, where he worked as a policeman at a gold mine, as a law clerk, and for a real estate agency run by Walter Sisulu, later to be imprisoned with him. Mandela boxed as a heavyweight and studied law at the predominantly white University of the Witwatersrand. He married a nurse, Evelyn Mase, who bore him two daughters and two sons. One daughter died in infancy and one son was killed in a car crash in 1970. The couple divorced in 1957. Mandela, Tambo and Sisulu formed the ANC Youth League in 1944, and Mandela became its president in 1950. He was chief organizer of the ANC's Defiance Campaign in 1952, encouraging people to break South Africa's racial separation laws. He and Tambo formed the first black law partnership in the country and were charged in December 1952 under the Suppression of Communism Act for their part in the civil disobedience campaign. He received the first of many banning orders, restricting his activities. He continued to work secretly and was charged in December 1956 with treason, along with 155 other South Africans of all races who had supported the Freedom Charter, calling for a non-racial democracy and a socialist-based economy. While on trial, he married social worker Winnie Nomzamo Madizekela, who bore him two daughters, Zenani and Zindzi. He helped conduct the defense in the treason trial, which ended in 1960 with acquittals for all defendants. Mandela immediately went underground for fear he would be rearrested and spent the next 17 months as a fugitive. After a planned two-day nationwide strike was crushed by police, he and a small group of ANC colleagues decided on military action. ``All opportunities for peaceful agitation and struggle have been closed to us,'' he said. ``Africans no longer have the freedom to even stay peacefully in their houses in protest against the oppressive policies of the government.''

DOC.HEAD: After a Year Under Death Threat, Salman Rushdie Fights Back
DOC.TEXT: One year after he was driven into hiding by an Islamic death sentence, Salman Rushdie has begun to fight back. With a long interview and an essay in a Sunday newspaper, plus a lecture written from hiding, the 42-year-old author is mounting a vigorous, unapologetic defense of ``The Satanic Verses'' and shows no inclination to bow to pressure to back down. That pressure is manifesting itself in a heated debate about whether ``The Satanic Verses'' should be published in paperback. Yes, says Rushdie. No, say those who fear it will lead to Moslem unrest. The opponents include lawmakers, writers and relatives of British hostages in Lebanon. Free speech has its limits, they say, and a paperback edition would only worsen a conflict that has already damaged Anglo-Moslem relations and led to deadly rioting. Some of Rushdie's supporters worry that the furor that greeted the death sentence imposed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran last Feb. 14 is dissipating. ``There has been this gradual shift ... into considering Rushdie as a criminal, from someone to be supported, here's someone who caused disquiet, unrest,'' said Frances D'Souza, head of the International Committee for the Defense of Salman Rushdie and his Publishers. The issue has domestic political implications too. The opposition Labor Party, which Rushdie always supported, is torn between the principle of free speech and the fear of losing Moslem votes. Rushdie acknowledges his book has caused pain but appeals to moderate Moslems to reconsider their campaign. The Bombay-born Briton says he renounced Islam in his youth, and therefore cannot be accused of blasphemy or reneging on his faith. If the uproar represents the conflict between Islamic fundamentalism and Western libertarianism, Rushdie is firmly on the side of the West. His lecture at the Institute of Contemporary Art, delivered by playwright Harold Pinter and attended by a host of literary heavyweights, cited an array of writers through the ages to defend free speech and decry religious absolutism. ``The True Believer knows that he is simply right, and you are wrong. He will seek to convert you, even by force (or)... despise you for your unbelief,'' he wrote. Within days of the publication of ``The Satanic Verses'' in September 1988, Moslems were claiming it insulted the Prophet Mohammed by associating him with prostitutes, and the Koran, their holy book, by suggesting it was man's work, not Allah's. The worldwide protests and book-burnings, and the deadly riots in Pakistan and India, culminated in Iran promising a multimillion-dollar reward for anyone who killed Rushdie. Khomeini died in June, but the edict stands. Rushdie was at his north London home last Valentine's Day, when the British Broadcasting Corp. told him of Khomeini's edict. The same day, Rushdie dropped out of sight with his wife, American novelist Marianne Wiggins. Since then he has been under round-the-clock armed guard at a series of houses operated by Special Branch security police and MI5, the domestic intelligence agency. Ms. Wiggins moved out in August. She denies there were marital difficulties. Rushdie confined himself to publishing occasional book reviews but stayed out of the debate on his book, saying he felt his silence would be more eloquent. ``The Satanic Verses'' has sold more than 1 million copies in English, almost three-quarters of those in the United States, and has been on the Sunday Times of London bestseller list for 49 weeks. It has been translated into 15 other languages and been banned in more than 20 countries. Writers and commentators initially rallied to Rushdie's defense, with 2,500 worldwide signing a petition. But in recent weeks, spy writer John le Carre and liberal political columnist Hugo Young have openly pressed Rushdie to abandon the paperback edition. Rushdie maintains the paperback is essential if his book is to last for posterity. Without a paperback, ``in a few years the book simply won't be there for anyone who wants to read it,'' he told The Independent on Sunday. ``It will, in all practical terms, have been suppressed.'' But writing in the left-leaning Guardian newspaper, le Carre said, ``Nobody has a God-given right to insult a great religion and be published with impunity.'' Young, a Guardian columnist, urged Rushdie to renounce the paperback ``on the deeply considered grounds that it could do more harm than good.'' Relatives of British hostages issued a statement saying paperback publication would be ``misconceived and irresponsible'' and could make conditions worse for the captives, believed held by Moslem extremists. Viking Penguin says ``no firm date'' has been set for paperback publication. The publishers have reason to be evasive. Khomeini's death sentence extended to them too, and they have received 35,000 abusive or threatening letters and 45 bomb threats in Britain and the United States, says spokesman Bob Gregory. The company's British headquarters have been evacuated six times, and five incendiary devices have been found in its stores, two of which exploded. Worldwide security measures cost $3.4 million a year, Gregory said. In a 7,000-word essay for The Independent on Sunday, Rushdie touched on his lonely existence and the shock of being condemned by Moslems for what he thought was a sympathetic account of their plight as immigrants in the West. ``Do I feel regret? Of course I do: regret that such offense has been taken against my work when it was not intended ...,'' Rushdie wrote. ``Would I have written it differently If I had known what would happen? Truthfully, I don't know. Would I change any of the text now? I would not. It's too late.''

DOC.HEAD: A Year of Living Dangerously
With AM-Rushdie, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Watching American football on TV, telephoning friends, and writing a children's book are among the simple pleasures author Salman Rushdie is permitted in his seclusion. Browsing through bookstores, strolling down the street and going to movies are forbidden by the armed government guards who move him from one safe house to another to protect him from a year-old Iranian death sentence. Rushdie's whereabouts is unknown, even to his wife, American author Marianne Wiggins, who moved out in August. She says there are no marital problems and that she corresponds with husband each night. After months of virtual silence, Rushdie and his wife have been telling a few trusted interviewers something about their year. ``The things that are most difficult to take are not being able to walk down a street, not being able to browse in a bookshop, not being able to go to a movie _ those trivial sorts of things that you take for granted until you don't have them. What they add up to is life,'' Rushdie told The Independent on Sunday in an interview behind drawn curtains at a restaurant. His reading matter includes ``Moby Dick,'' ``Ulysses,'' and the great free-speech defenders of the 18th Century Enlightenment, Rousseau, Diderot and Voltaire. He watches ``Dallas,'' ``Dynasty,'' and ``thirtysomething,'' and confesses a new addiction to American football, a recent addition to British TV. Rushdie told the newspaper that at times he could not work, but now his writing is ``going well.'' He is finishing a children's book, is putting together a collection of essays and has completed the synopsis for a novel.

DOC.HEAD: Statements From Salman Rushdie
With AM-Rushdie, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: During his year in hiding, author Salman Rushdie has published a poem, several book reviews and a 7,000-word essay defending his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Here are some of the things he has said:

``I recognize that Moslems in many parts of the world are genuinely distressed by the publication of my novel. I profoundly regret the distress that publication has occasioned to sincere followers of Islam. Living as we do in a world of many faiths, this experience has served to remind us that we must all be conscious of the sensibilities of others.'' (Feb. 18, 1989, four days after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini imposed the death sentence).

``I do not accept the charge of blasphemy, because as somebody says in ``The Satanic Verses,'' ``where there is no belief, there is no blasphemy''... I am not a Moslem. It feels bizarre and wholly inappropriate to be described as some sort of heretic after having lived my life as a secular, pluralist, eclectic man.'' (Feb. 4, 1990, essay in The Independent on Sunday).

``The things that are most difficult to take are not being able to walk down a street, not being able to browse in a bookshop, not being able to go to a movie _ those trivial sorts of things that you take for granted until you don't have them. What they add up to is life.'' (Feb. 4, 1990, interview in The Independent on Sunday).

``It has always been a shock to me to meet people for whom books simply do not matter, and people who are scornful of the act of reading, let alone writing. It is perhaps always astonishing to learn that your beloved is not as attractive to others as she is to you.'' (Feb. 6, Herbert Read Memorial Lecture).
``It is an agony and a frustration not to be able to reenter my old life.''Feb. 6, Herbert Read Memorial Lecture).

DOC.HEAD: Release `Significant Step,' Bush Says
With PM-Mandela
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed the announcement today that black activist Nelson Mandela will be freed, praising South African President F.W. de Klerk for ``bold and imaginative leadership.'' ``I welcome this move and view it as another significant step on the road to the non-racial, democratic South Africa which we all desire,'' Bush said in a statement released from Camp David, Md., where he is spending the weekend at the presidential retreat. Bush reiterated his intention to invite Mandela and de Klerk to the White House in separate visits. Some critics on Capitol Hill have said de Klerk should not be welcomed as long as his nation retains its system of racial separation known as apartheid. ``President de Klerk has shown bold and imaginative leadership in recent days which has earned the admiration of many of us who hope for swift and peaceful evolution in South Africa,'' Bush said. He made no mention of whether the release of Mandela after years as a political prisoner would cause the administration to push for easing of U.S. sanctions against Pretoria.

DOC.HEAD: Covenant House Kids Still Support Father Bruce
DOC.TEXT: To John O'Donnell, the allegations of sexual misconduct against the Rev. Bruce Ritter are beside the point. The point, he says, is that Covenant House gives him a clean place to sleep each night. ``He feeds us, he clothes us and we're behind him 100 percent,'' said O'Donnell, 20, who found shelter at Covenant House two weeks ago after he and his mother were evicted. ``He's the nicest guy in the world, and I ain't even met him. But someday I will and I'm going to shake his hand.'' The day before, Ritter had stepped down as executive director of Covenant House pending an investigation by the Franciscans, the order of Roman Catholic priests to which Ritter belongs, of charges that he had had sexual relations with several youths who had sought his help. Ritter dismisses the allegations as ``garbage,'' and O'Donnell and many of his fellow Covenant House residents agree. Even those who think Ritter's accusers could be telling the truth say it doesn't diminish their gratitude for a man whose work changed their lives. ``Excuse my language, but regardless if he's a homosexual or not, he's doing the right thing for us,'' said Mitchell Dedes, 20, as he stood outside the Covenant House shelter a few blocks from Times Square and a block from the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Both are magnets for homeless youths. ``We get three meals a day,'' he said. ``My clothes have been washed clean. I was out on the streets about four weeks after I lost my job. Now I sleep in a room with a bed, where the sheets get changed.'' Covenant House began in 1968, when Ritter, now 62, put a few runaways up in his apartment. It now serves 25,000 youths annually at 17 shelters in the United States, Canada and Latin America. Nearly all of its $85 million-a-year budget is funded by private donations. In his letters to potential donors, Ritter details the lives of youths who leave abusive homes for a street life of drugs and prostitution, but finally find peace at Covenant House. Since the controversy began, contributions are said to have fallen off, as Ritter _ a man who is accustomed to laudatory coverage, who was celebrated by President Reagan as a hero _ makes headlines of a different sort. The charges against Ritter first arose in December, when the New York Post quoted a onetime male prostitute as saying he had had an affair with Ritter over several months last year. The young man's father defended Ritter, calling his son an emotionally troubled liar. Then, in January, the Village Voice, a New York weekly newspaper, said a second young man had claimed during a 1986 interview that he had had sex with Ritter. The interview was not published at that time. Last week, two other young men were quoted in published reports as saying they had had affairs with Ritter. On Tuesday, the Franciscans said they had instructed Ritter to step down temporarily from the Covenant House post while the allegations were investigated. And the Manhattan district attorney's office is investigating whether Covenant House funds were misused. ``I think the media has tried to exploit the negative,'' said Reginald Lewis, 22, who ran away from his Oakland, Calif., home at age 17 and spent nine months at Covenant House before recently getting a place of his own and a job as a computer operator. The accusations against Ritter, he added, are ``unimportant. The philosophy behind what Father Ritter has done is what's important.'' ``Why don't they talk about the good things he's done?'' complained Nina Spear, 19, who came to Covenant House 2{ months ago after living on the street for 2{ years. She left her home on Staten Island because, she said, her ``life was messed up _ drugs, family.'' At Covenant House, she said, ``They teach us discipline, self-respect, respect for others. Instead of sleeping on the subway, you sleep in a bed.'' Andrew Escalet, 21, who has been at Covenant House for more than a year and hopes to be on his own by May, said: ``I don't feel any disappointment. I feel it's irrelevant. There's people that do so much worse in this world.'' Escalet's family kicked him out of his house in the Bronx two years ago. ``I stayed with friends,'' he recalled. ``Several times I stayed out in the parks and slept in a box. Got to a time when I needed some sort of rescue. It wasn't nobody else but Covenant House.'' Escalet, now working for a piano-moving company and studying for his high-school diploma, said when he talks to Ritter about his problems, the priest ``exhibits a tremendous amount of understanding, caring. That's important. If he can have that much understanding for me, I can have that for him.'' With the voice of experience, he added: ``It only takes one time for you to mess up, but it takes many, many good things for them to realize you're good.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Tilted to Right in 1989, Liberal Group Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Issacs in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Congress edged rightward in 1989 despite ``flashes of courage'' on abortion, flag burning and capital gains taxes, the liberal Americans for Democratic Action says. A compilation of voting records on 20 key issues by the ADA showed an average 50 percent approval of the liberal position in the House, down from 52 percent in 1988, and a decline from 52 percent to 48 percent of liberal causes in the Senate. The organization's national director, Amy Issacs, said liberals ``rarely had the votes to pass even moderate legislation over President Bush's 10 `kinder, gentler' vetoes.'' In fact it passed none. ``The first session of the 101st Congress was often spent in wrangling, often ugly debate, on issues that had little to do with its real business _ passing laws,'' Ms. Issacs said. ``While all this made for wonderful newspaper copy, it did little to address the nation's business.'' With 100 percent ``right'' votes on the 20 issues, the group hailed Sens. Paul Simon, D-Ill., and Patrick Leahy, D-Vermont, as its ``liberal champions'' in the Senate. Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., who has enjoyed perfect pro-liberal ADA ratings since 1982, led a contingency of 25 House members with a 100 percent liberal voting records last year, as compiled by the ADA and released this week. All 25 are Democrats. Nine Senate Republicans and 39 GOP members in the House scored zero ratings. House Democrats had an average 73 percent pro-liberal voting record compared with 70 percent for their party colleagues in the Senate. Republicans compiled 15 percent right votes in both the House and Senate. Democratic party leaders were more liberal _ 93 percent in the House and 75 percent in the Senate _ than members of their party as a whole. GOP leaders were more conservative, with average rankings of 5 percent in the House and 8 percent in the Senate. House Democratic committee chairman were slightly more liberal _ 77 percent _ than their party colleagues. However, Senate Democratic committee chairmen were slightly more conservative with an average 66 percent rating. But ranking committee Republicans in both the House and Senate had much more liberal voting records _ a 22 percent average _ than the party's leaders and its members in Congress as a lot. Lawmakers from Massachusetts had the most liberal ratings, averaging 89 percent, followed by those from North Dakota at 80 percent; Connecticut, 74 percent; West Virginia, 73 percent; and Hawaii, 69 percent. State delegations with the lowest average liberal voting records were Wyoming at 5 percent, followed by Idaho, 11 percent; Alaska, 13 percent; New Hampshire; 15 percent; and Utah, 18 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Bombs Explode in Kashmir Capital
DOC.TEXT: Eight bombs exploded in Srinagar on Saturday, and Moslem separatists urged city residents to demonstrate in the streets to mark the sixth anniversary of the execution of a militant leader. Police increased security and said Srinagar would be under curfew throughout Sunday, the anniversary of Mohammad Maqbool Butt's death. Butt, the founder of the militant Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, was hanged in New Delhi's Tihar Jail on Feb. 11, 1984, for the 1965 murder of an intelligence agent in Kashmir. Butt was convicted in 1967, but he escaped from a Srinagar jail in 1968. He was rearrested in 1979 and remained in jail until his execution. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front is spearheading a violent campaign for secession of the Himalayan state of Jammu-Kashmir, the country's only Moslem majority state, from the predominantly Hindu India. The movement is centered in Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state and its largest city. Jammu region, south of Kashmir, is Hindu dominated. At least 82 people have died in the latest round of secessionist violence that flared Jan. 20 when Moslem militants took to the streets and clashed with security forces. Most victims were protesters shot for defying curfew. Curfew had been restricted to night hours since Jan. 26 because authorities said the situation had stabilized. But it was clamped on the city at 11 a.m. Saturday after the bomb blasts. Police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the blasts occurred outside two banks, a post office and other shops and businesses. They said no one was injured. No one claimed responsibility, but the officials blamed the separatists. Curfew was strictly enforced and streets remained deserted. Government officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the wall posters that exhorted people to mark Butt's execution were being removed. Some of the posters said: ``Come out and demonstrate in memory of martyr Maqbool Butt who laid down his life for the cause of liberation of Kashmir.'' Witnesses who spoke on condition of anonymity said dozens of army trucks carrying soldiers rolled into Srinagar late Friday, apparently to counter possible violence Sunday. The city of 1 million was virtually sealed. Troops with machine guns patrolled the outskirts. All vehicles entering the city were stopped and searched. All travelers were told to leave vehicles and stood in lines with their hands raised to be searched. ``We are on full alert and we will stand no nonsense,'' said Major P. Govindaswamy, in charge of the army checkpoint at Panbazar, five miles south of Srinagar. The army has been used often to control the violence in Kashmir, a strategic region bordering Pakistan. India accuses Pakistan of arming and training the Kashmiri militants. Pakistan denies the charge and says the Kashmiris have the right to self-determination. The countries have fought two wars over Kashmir. Pakistan's prime minister, Benazir Bhutto, appeared to issue a veiled threat Saturday in a speech to Parliament about the Kashmir situation. ``We want a peaceful solution, but at the same time Pakistan cannot be intimidated,'' Ms. Bhutto told Pakistani lawmakers. ``We know how to defend our freedom and independence,'' she said. Ms. Bhutto accused India of blaming Pakistan for the violence ``in an attempt to externalize and divert the issue.'' Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding areas of the valley became part of Jammu-Kashmir.
