The foreign minister and the secretary discussed developments in Soviet-U.S. relations since the Wyoming ministerial and the Malta meeting between Chairman Gorbachev and President Bush. They examined the prospects for the summit, with the particular aim of advancing the objectives and priorities defined by the two leaders in Malta. The foreign minister and the secretary noted with satisfaction the progress that is being made in Soviet-U.S. relations. While certain significant differences remain between the sides, their relationship is increasingly marked by understanding, cooperation and the search for mutual advantage. The foreign minister and the secretary believe that candid dialogue and continuing efforts at finding practical and concrete solutions will further the significant progress that has been recorded to date. In this context, the Moscow ministerial was a useful and important step in preparing the ground for a productive summit. The high-level discussions were complemented by experts working groups on arms control, regional, human rights, transnational and bilateral issues, as well as an informal group on economic questions. Specific agreements were reached in several areas of the agenda. The foreign minister and the secretary held a thorough exchange of views on arms control and disarmament issues. With respect to the treaty on the reduction and limitation of strategic offensive arms, they reaffirmed their common objective of resolving all major issues by the June summit in order to allow signature of the treaty by the end of the year. To further this goal, the sides reached agreement or exchanged new proposals in a number of areas. On air-launched cruise missiles, the sides made substantial progress on a package approach, agreeing on all remaining issues with the exception of the range threshold. The sides also made good progress on sea-launched cruise missiles. The sides agreed that such missiles would be dealt with by parallel, politically binding declarations for the duration of the START treaty. The foreign minister and the secretary agreed that the remaining issues involving SLCMs would be addressed at the negotiations in Geneva. The sides agreed that there would be numerical limits on non-deployed ballistic missiles and the warheads attributable to them for all ICBMs of a type that has been flight tested from a mobile launcher. Other non-deployed heavy bomber weapons will not be subject to numerical limits. The sides further agreed on a regime governing the location and movement of all non-deployed ballistic missiles. The sides reached agreement on major elements of a regime to ensure the non-denial of telemetry data during flight tests of START-accountable ballistic missiles. These provisions will be included in the START treaty, but will be implemented early, at the time of treaty signature, through an exchange of letters. The U.S. side presented new proposals on verification of mobile ICBMs, duration of the treaty, phasing of reductions, and attribution of warheads to future types of ballistic missiles. The Soviet side presented new proposals dealing with non-circumvention. The foreign minister and the secretary instructed their negotiators to discuss these new proposals and to expedite efforts on resolving remaining differences in the text of the treaty and its associated documents. The sides discussed the Vienna negotiations on conventional force reductions and reiterated their determination to conclude an agreement as soon as possible in 1990. The sides discussed President Bush's Jan. 31 proposal on manpower which was presented by NATO in Vienna on Feb. 8, as well as NATO's aircraft proposal presented on the same date. As a result of the discussions in Moscow, the differences on personnel were narrowed. The sides agreed to continuetheir discussions in the context of the negotiations in Vienna and at the ministers' meeting on open skies in Ottawa. The foreign minister and the secretary had extensive discussions on how to proceed toward their common goal of achieving, through the negotiations in Geneva, a global ban on the development, production, stockpiling and use of chemical weapons and of their destruction. The Soviet and U.S. delegations in Geneva were instructed to proceed with developing means of practical cooperation in the area of chemical weapons elimination. The sides issued a separate, more detailed statement on chemical weapons. In discussions on nuclear testing, the sides made progress on resolving the remaining issues. They believe that the task of completing the verification protocols to the 1974 and 1975 threshold limitation treaties for signing at the summit is realistic. The sides agreed on the right to simultaneous use of hydrodynamic and in-country seismic yield measurements. The sides also resolved several longstanding problems regarding the implementation of the hydrodynamic yield measurement method. The sides identified the three seismic stations in each country to be used for in-country seismic yield measurements. The sides reaffirmed their adherence to the agreement reached in September 1987 with regard to the negotiations on nuclear testing. The Foreign Minister and the Secretary expressed their hope that the Ottawa open skies conference _ which they will both attend _ would be a success and lead to early agreement They believe an open skies regime can make a genuine contribution to openness, transparency and stability. The foreign minister and the secretary noted the recent consultations between their experts on chemical weapons non-proliferation, missile technology control and nuclear non-proliferation. They agreed to prepare a document for consideration by their leaders covering both principles and concrete steps of cooperation in all areas of non-proliferation _ chemical, missile and nuclear. The sides conducted a discussion of the problem of non-proliferation of missiles and missile technology. They noted that they both adhere to the export guidelines of the existing regime relating to missiles, which applies to missiles capable of delivering at least 500 kilograms of payload to a range of at least 300 kilometers. They further agreed to continue joint discussions on this problem in the interim before the next ministerial.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Question and Answer Segment of De Klerk's News Conference
With AM-South Africa, Bjt and BC-Mandela-Text
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of the question and answer session of President F.W. de Klerk's news conference on Saturday announcing that black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela would be freed. The text was provided to The Associated Press by the president's office. QUESTION: Do you believe this now fulfills all the preconditions for the U.S.A. and other countries to lift sanctions against South Africa? DE KLERK: We are not working against checklists. We are doing what we sincerely believe to be in the best interests of South Africa. Obviously, there are still some of the preconditions which have been set by various sources which have not literally been met, but the most important stumbling blocks in the way of negotiation, in the way of positive developments to create a climate for negotiation, have now been addressed to my mind. QUESTION: Mr. President, will the state lend security personnel and apparatus to ensure Mr. Mandela's safety, and secondly, do you expect that he will depart tomorrow for his home in Soweto? DE KLERK: The question of security and the actual process of release is that which is being discussed now with interested parties by officials of the government. The state will secure the position of Mr. Mandela while he is in custody of the state. As regards the rest of your question, when Mr. Mandela is released he becomes a free man and he does not owe it to me to inform us of his program. I have not asked him about it either. QUESTION: Mr. President, you said that Mr. Mandela has committed himself to a peaceful solution in South Africa. Does that mean that he now officially rejects violence? DE KLERK: I do not intend to speak on behalf of Mr. Mandela this afternoon. He will be able to do so tomorrow. QUESTION: A number of people who have met with Mr. Mandela since your original meeting, have spoken about it very positively and about the chemistry that exists between you and him. I wonder if you can tell us about your impressions of him and give us some kind of idea of the exchanges that you have had. DE KLERK: The discussions really took place in a very civil atmosphere. He is a friendly man. I would like to think that I am also a friendly man. Yes, the discussions really took place in good spirit. He is an elderly, dignified man and he is an interesting man. QUESTION: Mr. President, the minister of constitutional development said that the state of emergency could be lifted within weeks. Is that a fair assessment on your part now after meeting with Mr. Mandela? DE KLERK: As it is clearly stated in my statement, the final test is the situation on the ground, and everything will depend upon the question whether we get an increase in unrest or whether we get a decrease in unrest. QUESTION: Mr. President, Mr. Mandela has made clear over the past few weeks that he was uncomfortable being released in a situation where the state of emergency was still in force and not all political prisoners had been freed. What was his reaction to you informing him of his release into those conditions? DE KLERK: Once again, I really do not want to speak on his behalf. I can only give impressions and I went to great lengths to explain why the situation is as it is with regard to the state of emergency and that partiular question you must ask him tomorrow. QUESTION: Mr. De Klerk, how are you going to release Mr. Mandela? Are you going to release him from the prison straight into freedom, or are you going to take him away? DE KLERK: That is part of the process that is being discussed by officials now. I won't be present, and I do not intend to interfere in the detail. QUESTION: You spoke of an increase or decrease in violence. What judgement or basis are you going to use for determining whether you feel there has indeed been the right climate established for doing away with the regulations? DE KLERK: Well, obviously, any government has sources of information available to it. It is official sources, reports from its security forces, its police wherever they are, factual reports which come in regularly, which are all assimilated at one central point, analyzed and studied. We deal with such things in a very scientific manner, and we know what is going on in every corner of the country. QUESTION: What I meant, sir: You know that you are going to be subjected to some considerable scrutiny. Is there some sort of norm that you have established that you can set out for us now as to what would constitute stability.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: CAPE TOWN: constitute stability.
DOC.TEXT: DE KLERK: Stability is stability. Stability is a situation where people can feel safe, where people who want to go to work can do so, where people can live a normal life without intimidation, without threat. Stability is a situation where you do not have arson in a country because of political debate and differences. Stability is a situation where you do not have deaths as a result of political strife. That is the sort of stability we are striving for. Obviously, in any country, at all times, you have crimes and we go to great lengths to draw the necessary distinctions between ordinary and politically related instability. QUESTION: Mr. President, when you talk about a fair and just preliminary to negotiations, will you go beyond the state of emergency, and discuss as well the negotiation process, the establishment of full citizenship rights for the Black people of South Africa? DE KLERK: Thank you for that question. We have just won an election stating that as our goal. That is the mandate that my party asked of the electorate and that is the mandate that we received. There is a misconception that we do not want to give full citizenship rights to all South Africans, also to black South Africans. As a matter of fact, we have already received such a mandate from the white electorate in an election in 1989. It is no longer a question whether all South Africans must get full citizenship rights. The question is how to structure it, how also to accommodate the diversity in a non-discriminatory manner, of our total population. The fact that we have minorities, but nonetheless that clear commitment is the system must give full class-A citizenships to all South Africans, irrespective of race or color. DE KLERK: Once again, I do not want to speak on his behalf. QUESTION: Mr. President, while in custody, Mr. Mandela indicated that he would act as an intermediary or facilitator between the government and the ANC. Do you expect to continue to deal with him now on that basis? DE KLERK: I follow an open-door policy and should come forward and should he be prepared to play the role of facilitator, to interest himself in promoting a climate for negotiation, should he interest himself in promoting talks, even talks about talks, yes, that open door is also open to him. QUESTION: President De Klerk, I was wondering whether the presence of the Rev. Jackson here in South Africa had anything to do with the release of Mandela? (Laughter). DE KLERK: As far as the release of Mr. Mandela is concerned, his presence is totally irrelevant. QUESTION: President, can I ask you: did Mr. Mandela give you any assurance that he would call for peace in this country? DE KLERK: I did not ask him. QUESTION: President, from your last reply, when you said that he is prepared to act as a facilitator, does that mean he has not given you his agreement to enter negotiation? DE KLERK: His willingness to act as a facilitator has been published widely and over a fairly long period now. I did not discuss it with him as such again last night. QUESTION: Mr. De Klerk, could you possibly describe Mr. Mandela's reaction when you told him he would be released tomorrrow? DE KLERK: I do not think that I would like to try to do that QUESTION: Returning to the question of the lifting of the state of emergency, the stability required, does this imply that you will wait until there is complete peace in the Natal province, and do you think that that realistically will happen within the few weeks time that some of your ministers have given as a time span for that lifting? DE KLERK: There is an element of uncertainty, obviously, with regard to everything which lies in the future. None of us can exactly say what will happen tomorrow and the day after. It is really our hope that with the steps which we have taken, that it will make a contribution and that will bring us soon to the situation where it can be considered. We review this situation almost on an ongoing basis, almost on a day-to-day basis, and we are as anxious as anybody else to have the state of emergency lifted as soon as possible. QUESTION: You said that the lifting of the state of emergency would be a matter for negotiations. With whom do you propose to negotiate? Mr. Mandela, the ANC, who? DE KLERK: No, I did not say that is matter for negotiation. I said that the question of political prisoners is a matter for negotiation. The state of emergency was imposed by the government because of a state of instability throughout our country. It will be a government decision to lift it, and the test will be whether the stability has been restored sufficiently so that we can do so. QUESTION: But you did say that you have discussed it with Mr. Mandela, didn't you? DE KLERK: Yes, obviously, because it is a matter which is being raised from many quarters as also being a stumbling block, and in that sense it was discussed. QUESTION: Mr. President, may I ask you: have you already or are you about to inform world leaders, and if so, whom? DE KLERK: I have informed our minister of foreign affairs a few hours ago and in all probability he has undertaken an exercise so that they will not just read it in the press. It is general custom, which we adhere to, and that I am sure he has done. I did not speak to anybody. QUESTION: Are you, sir, concerned at all for the safety of Nelson Mandela, and if so, how? DE KLERK: Yes, in my opening address, or rather, in another statement I indicated that, yes, I think there is reason for concern about his safety. There are all sorts of people who might threaten his life. I think radicals from the very far left might be tempted to do so, and I think there is also a risk that it might come from radicalists from the right. Many publicc figures are being threatened throughout the world almost in all countries, and with him having such a high profile, I think, yes, there is a real risk, and one must take every precaution to ensure that noghing happens to him. But when he leaves prison, then he will be moving to his own circle of friends, and in all probability, as in the case of Mr. Sisulu and the other prisoners which we released, there was no request to the state to give any assistance with regard to their security. QUESTION: Mr. President, I wonder if I may ask you to define the mandate? How do you define full constitutional rights? Is that one man, one vote? DE KLERK: Can we save that for the press conference of next week? That is the type of thing I would likee to address then. Thank you very much.

DOC.HEAD: Deputies Nab Alleged Milk Money Pincher
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy who allegedly threatened to beat up five elementary school classmates unless they forked over their milk money has been arrested and charged with felony extortion, authorities said Saturday. The boy, not identified because of his age, was arrested Thursday at Lacoochee Elementary School after the parents of one pupil told Assistant Principal Ky Grand that her son was afraid to go to school. Grand said the charges were serious enough to call in sheriff's deputies instead of dealing with the incident within the school. Upon further investigation by school officials and Pasco County sheriff's deputies, five students said the boy threatened to beat them up if they did not give him money they brought to school to buy milk and ice cream. The boy admitted taking money and was arrested Thursday on five extortion charges. He was released to the custody of his mother. He was suspended from school for three days and may face expulsion, said principal Renee Sedlack, who said the boy previously has not been a disciplinary problem.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demonstrate for Unification
With AM-Germany-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 20,000 East Germans, many carrying West German flags, demonstrated Saturday for speedy German reunification, the official East German news agency ADN said. As the demonstrators rallied in the southern city of Plauen, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said in Moscow that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had given him an unequivocal promise to respect German reunification. Kohl declared it a ``very good day for Germany.'' Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher also disclosed that they expect a reunification plan with agreement of the World War II Allies to be ready before the end of the year for presentation to a pan-European summit meeting. Calls for German reunification have increased since the ouster of the hard-line Communist leadership and the opening of East Germany's borders during the fall pro-democracy movement. Despite reforms, nearly 2,000 East Germans, most of them skilled workers, continue to leave their homeland daily, crippling an economy already troubled by strikes and absenteeism. Earlier Saturday, West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said the East German economy was in a ``sorrowful state'' and urged the East German government to release details on its financial situation. Waigel's comments came after a day after a high-ranking official in Bonn warned that East Germany is rapidly approaching insolvency. ``Things are escalating,'' Waigel said in an interview with West Berlin radio. ``The economy is in a sorrowful state. The political authority is crumbling.'' He said the Bonn government believes East Germany's foreign debt stands at $18 billion. ``If the situation has changed, the East German government must say so,'' said Waigel, a conservative who has been pushing for establishment of a common currency for the two states. Also Saturday, more than 100 East Germans protested in front of the Soviet Embassy in East Berlin against the stationing of Soviet helicopters in their country, ADN said. ADN said the demonstrators held signs saying ``Gorbi, what about disarmament?'' and ``Tanks out, helicopters in?'' The protesters, from the East German town of Prenzlau, claimed the Soviets had backed out of disarmament plans by replacing a tank unit that had been stationed at a military base there with helicopters, ADN reported. According to ADN, the demonstrators, who came from church and citizens' groups as well as from the town council, issued a statement calling for civilian use of the base. Prenzlau, a town of 22,000, is located about 50 miles north of Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Feb. 22 Launch Date for Space Shuttle Atlantis
DOC.TEXT: Space Shuttle Atlantis will lift off early on the morning of Feb. 22 on a secret military mission, NASA announced Saturday. Shuttle managers said after a two-day flight readiness review that the launch would occur between 12 a.m. and 4 a.m., the fourth after-dark liftoff in 34 shuttle missions. Feb. 22 has been the target date for some time, and the review turned up nothing to change that. ``There are no significant problems standing in the way of launch,'' said a NASA statement. Replacement of a main engine turbopump had threatened a one-day delay, but that work was completed Saturday without affecting the schedule. Because Atlantis' payload is classified, the Pentagon and NASA will not announce the precise launch time until nine minutes before blastoff to make it harder for Soviet satellites and reconnaissance ships sitting offshore to track the spaceship. However, sources close to the project said Atlantis and its crew of five military officers are to take off at 1:14 a.m. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said the shuttle's payload is a 37,300-pound satellite with a dual role to snap high-resolution reconnaissance photos and eavesdrop on military and diplomatic communications. They said the payload will be launched into a high-inclination orbit that will cover most of the Soviet Union, including northern areas not previously overflown by shuttle-launched spy satellites. The Russians have heavy concentrations of naval ships and submarines and several missile bases in the far north. The satellite, known by the code name AFP-731, was loaded into Atlantis' cargo bay early Saturday. The crew for the four-day mission is commanded by Navy Capt. John O. Creighton. The others are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and the mission specialists, Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Creighton, Hilmers and Mullane have flown on previous shuttle missions.

DOC.HEAD: Right-to-Die Group Shakes Up Amid Divorce
DOC.TEXT: Less than a year after helping his first wife take her own life so she would not die a slow, painful death from cancer, Derek Humphry married again. With his new wife, Ann, he founded the Hemlock Society, an organization that became a leader in the right-to-die movement. But after Ann W. Humphry was diagnosed with breast cancer last year, the couple became embroiled in a bitter divorce that has left Mrs. Humphry accusing her estranged husband of abandoning the society's most basic principles as well as abusing his leadership. ``It's a tragic case of a lot of dirty linen being washed in public,'' said William Batt, a director of the national organization and president of the society's upstate New York chapter. Last month, the society's board of directors restructured the organization. It voted both Humphrys off the board, appointed Derek Humphry executive director and placed Ann Humphry on sick leave. The board expressed full confidence in Derek Humphry. Board member Faye Girsh of San Diego said, ``It's his vision.'' The moves were long overdue, board members said. ``It was really a mom-and-pop organization,'' board member John Westover of Tucson, Ariz., said last week. ``It had really outgrown the situation.'' In fact, the board would like someone else to take over administrative duties so that Derek Humphry can devote himself to developing policy and spreading the society's message, Westover said The intertwined story of Derek and Ann Humphry and the Hemlock Society began when they were married 13 years ago in England. He was a British journalist. She was an American academic. In 1978 they moved to Los Angeles, where they founded the Hemlock Society in 1980 to crusade for the right to choose death, as Humphry's first wife, Jean, had done. The Humphrys moved Hemlock in 1988 to Eugene, Ore., where the national organization employs 13 people and counts 53 chapters across the United States. Ann Humphry bought a 50-acre farm in Monroe, 20 miles north of Eugene, where the couple lived until last October. Three weeks after she was diagnosed with breast cancer, Derek Humphry went on a speaking tour in New Mexico and never came home again. ``She wouldn't let me have anything to do with her cancer,'' said Humphry, 59. ``She wouldn't let me come to the hospital. She wouldn't tell me the details. She said, `You stay out of it.''' He said his wife finally changed her mind, but began to taunt him about his previous wife. ``Would I do the same for her? Did I love her as much as my first wife? .... Things were said that I could not bear. The marriage just broke to pieces in my eyes and I left her. ``It was a bad marriage for four or five years,'' he said. ``The cancer just cracked it open. The cancer just finished it off.'' Ann Humphry acknowledged that the couple had been seeing marriage counselors. She said she had been growing more distant from both her husband and the Hemlock Society in recent years and the cancer was the final straw. ``I think it was a terrible blow to him,'' she said. ``He said, `I cannot live with this misery any longer. I don't choose to live through what I lived through once.' He added that if I were dying, he would make certain that I would be looked after.'' Derek Humphry said the point was she was not dying, that the lump had been removed from her breast in time, and her physician gave her a 75 percent chance of recovery. In addition, Ann Humphry said she believed her husband has hurt the right-to-die movement. ``The Hemlock Society has in its thesis that anyone with a life-threatening illness should be provided a nurturing and supportive environment,'' she said. ``It is ironic that its leader left his wife three weeks after she was diagnosed and had surgery for her cancer. She and others, she said, brought to the board's attention what they called serious tax abuses under Humphry's leadership. She said money was transferred from the society, an educational non-profit organization, to politically active organizations, a tax-law violation. Humphry said the money was loaned to a group pushing for a right-to-die ballot initiative in California and the IRS questioned it. Humphry said there is a genuine difference of opinion over whether the transfers were legally proper. Members of the board of directors agreed. ``This is something that was done in consultation with attorneys,'' said Batt, who works as a tax policy analyst for the New York Legislature. ``This is not a case of one person blowing a whistle. It is a difference among experts.''

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Welcome Announcement of Mandela's Release
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Zambian president, EDITS to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: World leaders welcomed South Africa's announcement Saturday of Nelson Mandela's impending release from prison, and international rejoicing began to build for an event so long awaited by so many. Britain said it was time to resume contacts with the internationally isolated Pretoria government, but anti-apartheid campaigners warned against any reduction of pressure on South Africa's white-led government. President Bush praised South African President F.W. de Klerk for ``bold and imaginative leadership,'' and the Canadian government expressed delight at the announcement Mandela would be released Sunday. In Lusaka, Zambian President Kenneth Launda, whose country has been a refuge for the exiled leadership of Mandela's African National Congress, said his first reaction was to kneel down and thank God. ``Really, we must believe in the leadership of the people of South Africa to put their heads together and build on these developments,'' Kaunda said. Mandela's release will enable ANC leaders to ``begin talking across color and any other artificial barriers,'' Kaunda said. ``Those things such as police brutality we can expect from time to time, but the main thing is that the entire leadership should get together.'' Mandela has been jailed since 1962 for leading the ANC into a guerrilla campaign against the white-dominated government's policy of apartheid, which denies the black majority the right to vote. On Feb. 2, De Klerk stunned South Africans by lifting a 30-year ban on the ANC, ending bans and restrictions on dozens of opposition groups, scrapping some state-of-emergency regulations and declaring a moratorium on hangings. Hours after the announcement of Mandela's release date, the ANC's leadership announced from its headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia: ``We welcome Nelson Mandela back from all those years of imprisonment into our midst with great joy.'' ANC executive committee member James Stuart predicted Mandela would ``probably concentrate on mobilizing our people and the unity of our people,'' and will ``participate in all kinds of activities which will march foward toward the end of the apartheid system.'' ``Ireland rejoices that Nelson Mandela is free at last,'' said Charles Haughey, Irish prime minister and current president of the European Economic Community, which has been using economic sanctions to pressure Pretoria to give up apartheid. ``By his indomitable courage he has demonstrated once again that the human spirit can never be vanquished,'' Haughey said. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, current chairman of the Organization of African Unity, sent Mandela a message of congratulation, praising the ``sacrifices of the great people of South Africa'' and assuring him of Egyptian solidarity with his cause. In the Soviet Union, Moscow radio broadcast news of the announcement, then added, ``Nelson Mandela has become the world's most famous political prisoner, put in jail for the struggle against apartheid in South Africa.'' Amsterdam's central Leidseplein square was temporarily rechristened Nelson Mandela Square. In London, a jubilant crowd of about 120, some waving pictures of Mandela, celebrated in the pouring rain outside South Africa House in Trafalgar Square. In a statement released by her 10 Downing St. office, Mrs. Thatcher said, ``We believe that the steps President de Klerk has taken merit a positive, practical response.'' ``We believe it no longer makes sense to discourage new investment in South Africa _ a restraint which in our case in any event has been voluntary _ and we shall be discussing this with our EC partners,'' she said. In 1986, the EC banned imports of South African iron, steel and Kruggerand gold coins, and barred new investment in the country. It had already frozen scientific and cultural relations. Britain regards the iron, steel and coin embargoes as mandatory, but not the investment ban, and has already announced that it is no longer observing the scientific and cultural embargo. In a statement released from the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., Bush said: ``I welcome this move and view it as another significant step on the road to the non-racial, democratic South Africa which we all desire.'' Bush reiterated his intention to invite Mandela and de Klerk to the White House in separate visits, and said: ``President de Klerk has shown bold and imaginative leadership in recent days which has earned the admiration of many of us who hope for swift and peaceful evolution in South Africa.'' In London, Bob Hughes, chairman of the Anti-Apartheid Movement, said he was delighted at the news, which he called ``a tremendous victory for the people of South Africa and for the international sanctions campaign.'' Commonwealth Secretary-General Sir Shridath Ramphal said Mandela's safety must be guaranteed by the South African government and that until change there became irreversible, the Commonwealth would sustain its pressure for apartheid's end. ``It is not yet time to demobilize the international support for apartheid's victims,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Forces Seize Strategic Town in Christian War
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with Aoun forces reportedly seizing strategic town, quotes from police and possible impact of town's seizure. Moves up background on Aoun-Geagea disagreement over peace pact.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NIC1
DOC.TEXT: Troops of Gen. Michel Aoun captured a strategic town Saturday that was a stronghold of rival Christian forces and opened a new front in the war for control of Lebanon's Christian region, police said. A communique from Aoun's command said his soldiers took 34 prisoners in the attack on Kleiat, 15 miles northeast of Beirut in the mountainous province of Kesrouan. The rival Lebanese Forces militia claimed its fighters counterattacked and drove back Aoun's men. ``The battle for Kesrouan has begun,'' said a police spokesman who could not be named under standing rules. ``Kleiat's capture opens the way for Aoun's army to punch deep into the region.'' If Aoun's forces are able to oust the Lebanese Forces from Kesrouan, that would enable them to attack the important port of Jounieh from Dbaye in the south and Kesrouan in the north. Aoun fighters seized Dbaye last week. Jounieh is the largest Lebanese Forces base in the embattled Christian enclave and the militia's main harbor. There was no updated word on casualties. Before the news from Kleiat, the toll from the 12-day confrontation between Aoun's army and the Lebanese Forces militia of Samir Geagea was 433 killed and 1,684 wounded. The intra-Christian fighting is the worst in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun and Geagea both have been at odds with Syria, which maintains 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate, but Aoun has accused Geagea of trying to enforce an Arab League-brokered peace plan that he opposed. Aoun attacked the pact because it set no date for the withdrawal of the Syrian troops. Geagea's headquarters said his militiamen in Kleiat retreated Saturday ``to draw in and contain Aoun's attacking force and then counterattacked.'' ``We drove them back in a nine-hour battle. They left behind five destroyed tanks and 15 armored personnel carriers,'' said the communique. The police spokesman refused to comment on the conflicting claims. Both sides dueled with howitzers, mortars and machine guns all day in Beirut's Christian sector. Snipers prevented rescuers from retrieving bodies, and corpses were left to rot on the streets. ``Civil defense rescuers believe some of the corpses are booby-trapped and that's why the combatants want to keep them there,'' a police spokesman said. A police spokesman said three people were killed and four wounded in the shelling before it subsided into intermittent exchanges around 10 a.m. The shelling broke out when a unit of Geagea's 6,000-man militia used dynamite to blast the Daraya Bridge, northeast of Beirut, and block any possible tank attack by Aoun's 19,000 troops. Aoun's gunners shelled the militia squad as it was returning to base, and Geagea's men responded. Hundreds of civilians fled the 310-square-mile Christian enclave to safe areas in west Beirut, south, east and north Lebanon. The blasting of the Daraya Bridge came two days after Geagea's militia blocked with rocks, concrete and mines a 500-yard tunnel on the coastal highway linking Aoun's territory with Kesrouan. Aoun's command issued a communique saying Geagea's militia, by blowing up the Daraya Bridge, violated a cease-fire called two days ago. Shortly before dusk, Aoun's Radio Lebanon said Geagea's gunners were shelling the general's Defense Ministry in Yarze, east of Beirut. The police spokesman said the situation in the Christian enclave ``does not indicate that a cease-fire's going to hold.'' The Voice of Lebanon, an anti-Aoun Christian radio station that is the mouthpiece of the Phalange party, reported a mutiny among Aoun's troops as they and Geagea's militia appeared geared for another round of all-out fighting. The station broadcast a statement by Col. Paul Faris, who declared creation of the ``neutral army forces'' with headquarters in the coastal town of Amsheet, which is controlled by Geagea forces. He urged ``fellow soldiers ... to refuse Aoun's orders and immediately join the ranks of the neutral army forces. Leave Aoun's army now before it's too late.'' Addressing the 54-year-old Aoun, Faris said: ``You are a criminal general ... responsible for all the massacres being committed against your people. The least you deserve is execution by a firing squad.'' Shortly after broadcasting Faris' communique, Voice of Lebanon said it received calls from several army units declaring support for the mutiny. The reports could not be independently confirmed. Aoun's command released a statement that called Faris ``a mutineer who had joined the gunmen a while ago and is wanted by justice.'' It said ``those declaring support for Faris are prisoners captured by the gunmen in the early days of the battle.'' A military source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Faris' mutiny ``is obviously coordinated with Geagea ... to make it easier for Aoun's men to defect to a Christian army command'' rather than taking ``the tough decision'' of declaring loyalty to the Syrian-backed command of Gen. Emile Lahoud. Lahoud, who has headquarters in west Beirut, commands the 22,000 predominantly Moslem soldiers who are based in Syrian-controlled territories of Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Backing Full NATO Membership for A United Germany, Aide Says
DOC.TEXT: A senior Bush administration official said Saturday night the United States is backing nothing less than full membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a united Germany. ``Membership, membership, membership,'' said the official, countering reports that the administration had some other scheme in mind. The reports followed an assertion by Secretary of State James A. Baker III at a news conference in Moscow on Friday night that U.S. policy calls for membership or ``association'' in the western alliance for a reunited Germany. At the same news conference, Baker said he meant nothing special by using the word ``association.'' Asked about the reports, the senior U.S. official, briefing reporters on Baker's visit here under rules that barred use of his name, said only ``full membership'' is what the administration is calling for. Both Baker and the official endorsed, meanwhile, a proposal by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher that while a united Germany should be a NATO member, western trops would not move into the territory that is now East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Superpowers Announce Preliminary Chemical Arms Reduction Pact
DOC.TEXT: The superpowers on Saturday announced preliminary agreement on a U.S. plan for a 10-year phase-out of their chemical weapons stockpiles that links their total elimination to a negotiated worldwide ban. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told a news conference after three days of talks with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III that the superpowers reached accord on the draft of ``a prospective agreement of principle.'' ``We believe such an agreement could be signed during President Gorbachev's visit to the United States,'' he added. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev is to travel to Washington in June to meet with President Bush. The announcement had been expected after the lengthy talks Baker had with Shevardnadze and Gorbachev in Moscow. In a joint statement, carried by the official Soviet news agency Tass, the United States and Soviet Union pledged to work out an agreement for destruction of a ``significant part'' of their chemical arsenals. The agreed reductions would put their stocks at equally low levels while 40-nation talks on a worldwide ban continue in Geneva. When an international ban on the development, production, use and possession of chemical weapons enters into force, the United States and Soviet Union will further cut stocks to ``a very small fraction'' of current arsenals over an eight-year period, the statement said. In the following two years, remaining U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons would be destroyed, it said. The statement said all states capable of manufacturing chemical weapons must adhere to the convention, indicating that if any third country refused to join a ban the superpowers would not be obligated to liquidate their remaining stockpiles. Only the United States and Soviet Union admit to having chemical weapons, although a dozen nations, including Libya and Iraq, are thought to have production capability. The Geneva conference negotiating a global chemical weapons ban opened its 1990 session Wednesday. The conference dates to 1968. Diplomats for years have forecast an agreement soon, although progress in separate bilateral U.S.-Soviet talks that began five years ago have now spurred optimism that a treaty might be signed within a year. In December, the superpowers exchanged confidential data on the size of their arsenals. The chief Soviet negotiator at the Geneva negotiations, Sergei Batsanov, said last month there was ``no surprise,'' implying his country believes it backed up its public claim that it has no more than 50,000 tons of chemical arms. Some U.S. analysts, however, have said the Soviet arsenal is more than six times larger than that. Batsanov's former U.S. counterpart at the Geneva talks, Max Friedersdorf, said in December the Soviets have ``considerably more than 50,000 tons.'' U.S. stockpiles are estimated at 30,000 tons. In September, Bush offered to destroy 80 percent of the U.S. chemical arsenal before an international treaty is reached if Moscow follows suit. The Soviets, however, said then such reductions should be accompanied by a halt to production of new chemical weapons. That demand would put an end to the U.S. program to replace part of its obsolete stockpile with modern ``binary'' chemical weapons composed of two relatively harmless agents that become dangerous when mixed. The U.S.-Soviet statement issued Saturday said only that the international treaty should provide for a halt to production of new chemical weapons, meaning U.S. manufacture of binaries could continue until such a pact enters into force.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: next ministerial
DOC.TEXT: On Central America, the foreign minister and the secretary reaffirmed the importance of implementing all aspects of the Esquipulas Treaty and its successor agreements. The sides had a constructive discussion on the conditions for a political settlement in Afghanistan, including the need for a transition period that provides for an intra-Afghan dialogue, a broad-based government. The foreign minister and the secretary discussed the Pacific and northeast Asia. They expressed a desire to reduce tensions on the Korean Peninsula and to support a south-north dialogue, reiterated their willingness to facilitate the achievement of a comprehensive political settlement in Cambodia. The foreign minister and the secretary reaffirmed the need for an active Middle East peace process, including efforts being made to launch a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue, leading to a comprehensive political settlement in which all relevant parties participate on the basis of U.N. Security Council resolutions 242 and 338. The sides again urged a political solution to the Iran-Iraq conflict based on the full implementation of Security Council resolution 598. The foreign minister and the secretary noted with satisfaction the course of developments in Namibia aimed at establishing its full independence under democratic conditions in peace and stability. They urged the cessation of hostilities and negotiations between the parties with a view to achieving a lasting political settlement. The sides also expressed their concern with the growing threat of famine in Ethiopia and urged that the international community again come together to address this tragic humanitarian problem. Discussing the developments in Europe, the sides reaffirmed the key role being played by the CSCE process in the emergence of a new Europe. They agreed in principle on holding a summit meeting of the 35 CSCE states in 1990. The foreign minister and the secretary and their experts held a thorough and very positive discussion of human rights and humanitarian and transnational issues. Eduard Shevardnadze and James Baker agreed to hold their next meeting in Washington.
DOC.HEAD: End of AM-US-Soviet Text, 2 Takes
Bush Hails `Bold' Decision to Free Mandela; Sanctions Could Be Dropped
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 3 new grafs after 6th graf pvs: President Bush, with Baker reaction from Bulgaria; picks up 7th graf pvs: De Klerk's announcement ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush telephoned President F.W. de Klerk on Saturday to praise his planned release of imprisoned black activist Nelson Mandela and pledge ``U.S. willingness to help create a climate for negotiations'' between black and white South Africans, an aide said. De Klerk's announcement that Mandela would be set free on Sunday opens the way for lifting of U.S. sanctions against Pretoria, one administration official said. During their five-minute conversation Bush invited de Klerk to meet with him at the White House and told him he was issuing the same invitation to Mandela, said White House spokesman John Herrick. ``He also expressed his admiration for the significant initiatives anounced by the South African government in recent days, and reiterated his hope there would be continued progress toward a negotiated solution in an atmosphere of non-violence,'' Herrick said of the call Bush made from the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. Bush was joined at Camp David by Vice President Dan Quayle, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner. The four discussed changes in East-West relations and th future of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``President Bush stated U.S. willingness to help create a climate for negotiations, and his plan to continue meeting with a broad spectrum of South African leaders,'' Herrick said of the call to de Klerk. Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in Sofia, Bulgaria, where he met with government and opposition leaders, said: ``I think that's really a very significant move by the South African government. Let's hope that this is a step on the road to a Democatic nonracial government in South Africa.'' ``President de Klerk has taken a number of actions recently that we can only characterize as very very endouraging,'' he added. Baker recalled bush had said release of Mandela from prison could lead to a visit to Washington by him and DeKlerk. De Klerk's announcement that he would free Mandela and lift the national state of emergency within a few weeks would fulfill two of the five conditions set out in U.S. law for lifting the economic sanctions against the apartheid government. ``It's quite possible that within the next few weeks that four out of the five will have been fulfilled, which gives the president the authority,'' to remove the economic sanctions, said Herman J. Cohen, assistant secretary of State for African affairs. In a statement released from Camp David, Bush said, ``President de Klerk has shown bold and imaginative leadership in recent days which has earned the admiration of many of us who hope for swift and peaceful evolution in South Africa.'' Under the law passed by Congress in 1986, the president can suspend or modify the sanctions if Mandela and other political prisoners are released and Pretoria meets at least three of the other conditions: lifting the state of emergency, legalizing political participation for all parties, repealing laws that regulate where non-whites can live and work, and beginning good-faith negotiations with the black majority. If the administration determines four of the conditions have been met, Cohen said, Bush will consult with Congress on easing the sanctions. He said the Bush administration is ``actively looking at all of these details'' involved in de Klerk's pronouncements, including a review of political prisoners and whether any of them remain jailed. De Klerk has previously freed several high-profile political prisoners. He also recently lifted the ban on Mandela's African National Congress and other opposition political organizations and said he would negotiate with black leaders on a new constitution. The U.S. sanctions include a ban on importing South African steel, textiles, uranium, coal and agricultural produce. They also bar new U.S. investment in South Africa, forbid new bank loans and end U.S. landing rights for South African Airways. One administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it was likely Bush would back a partial easing of sanctions, not a complete removal, once the conditions are met. That would leave him some leverage with Pretoria to continue pressing for an end to apartheid, that country's policy of racial separation, the source said. Bush did not mention the sanctions question in his statement Saturday, but he said a week ago that he was willing to review the sanctions ``as new developments take place.'' He said at that time, ``I think when people move in the right direction, it is certainly time to review all policy.'' Once Mandela is free, the lifting of the state of emergency will be the action that ``really triggers'' administration willingness to move on the sanctions, said Cohen. However, he added, ``The president is clearly not going to make a decision without consulting Congress.'' Mandela, 71, has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of a sabotage campaign by the African National Congress. In his dramatic announcement Saturday, de Klerk said the 3{-year-old state of emergency would be lifted in a few weeks if no further unrest accompanies Mandela's release, and promised to negotiate the possible release of remaining political prisoners. Under the remaining restrictions, police can still detain suspects for up to six months without charge, ban protests, and ban journalists or others from protests or areas of unrest. Bush was vice president in the Reagan administration which fought the congressionally imposed sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Voyager 1 to Make Family Portrait of the Planets
With AM-Galileo-Venus, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Voyager 1, which joined its twin exploring the outer solar system, will snap pictures this week to make an unprecedented family portrait of most of the planets and the vast empty space between them. ``It will speak more to the mind than to the eye because of the tremendous distances. What will be impressive will be the distances,'' said Jurrie van der Woude, a spokesman at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The complete portrait will be too large to be published, but NASA may assemble the 64 eight-by-10-inch photos into a mosaic stretching 100 to 150 feet along a wall at the laboratory. Neptune, Uranus, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Earth and Venus will appear as tiny dots against a background of dark space and the constellation Eridanus. Mercury will be hidden by the sun's glare. Pluto is too distant to appear in any images. While the solar system portrait won't have scientific value, its purpose is ``really historical,'' said Bob MacMillin, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``This is not just the first time, but perhaps the only time for decades that we'll be able to take a picture of the planets from outside the solar system,'' said Voyager project scientist Edward Stone. Voyager 1, which is about 3.7 billion miles from Earth, will use its two cameras to photograph the planets and the sun between 5:15 p.m. and 9:20 p.m. PST Tuesday night. Because of other demands on NASA Deep Space Network tracking antennas, the photos won't be sent back to Earth until late March, and it will be late April until they are processed and can be assembled into a mosaic, MacMillin said. The twin Voyager spacecraft were launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., in 1977 and explored Jupiter in 1979. Voyager 2 explored Saturn in 1981, Uranus in 1986 and Neptune last August. Voyager 1 explored Saturn in 1980, then flew above the plane in which the planets orbit the sun, known as the ecliptic plane. Photographing the sun for the solar system portrait may warp the shutter blades on Voyager 1's wide-angle camera, but there are no plans to use the camera again anyway, NASA said. Voyager 1 will take the photos for the solar system portrait by looking down from a position 32 degrees above the ecliptic plane. Stone said no future missions are planned that would send a spacecraft so high above the ecliptic plane. Voyager 1 was chosen to make the photograph because it is in better position that Voyager 2. Both spacecraft are now studying electrically charged particles and magnetic fields as they fly toward interstellar space. They are expected to return at least limited measurements for another 25 to 30 years.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official Warns Lack of Grain Could Reduce Meat Supplies
DOC.TEXT: The top Soviet official in charge of food supplies has warned that meat production, already woefully inadequate, could fall further because of a lack of grain used to fatten livestock. In a speech to a meeting of Communist Party leaders this week, Vladilen V. Nikitin, head of the state committee on food, said the Soviet Union has been unable to grow the amount of grain mandated by the economic plan. Nikitin also said in remarks published in Friday's edition of the Communist Party daily Pravda that the government has been unable to buy an additional 5 million tons of grain from foreign sources needed to supply the country. That will mean less fodder for animals, he said. ``There is no grain because there are no (production) means. ... There are no other reasons,'' Pravda quoted Nikitin as saying. In some Soviet cities meat is rationed, with people receiving as little as the equivalent of two or three good-sized hot dogs per month. In remarks published Thursday, Nikitin said Soviet agricultural production represents one-third of the national income but does not receive adequate equipment. Government statistics for 1989 published last week showed that after an investment of $110 billion in agriculture last year, Soviet food production rose only 1 percent and not the 6.6 percent expected. The Soviet government had hoped the program would help it obtain additional grain more cheaply than by buying it in the West, but authorities were still forced to import nearly 40 million tons last year, 1 million more than in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Three Reported Killed in Student Unrest in Niger
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 4 grafs to correct that news agency reporting three dead Saturday. Pickup 5th pvs, `Police first...
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of students staging an anti-government protest clashed with police in the Niger capital, and official reports Saturday said three people died. The military Cabinet of President Ali Saibou convened in emergency session Saturday to discuss the student unrest. The French news agency Agence France-Presse initially said five to 10 students may have died in the confrontation Friday in Niamey. On Saturday, the Niger News Agency and AFP said police shot and killed three people and wounded 33. AFP quoted witnesses as saying about 100 armed police were sent to block a bridge between the University of Niamey and the capital's center to stop protesting university and secondary school students from reaching offices of government ministries. Police first fired tear gas at demonstrators and then charged the crowd several times. Some of them fired into the crowd, the agency quoted witnesses as saying. The university has been closed since Thursday, when hundreds of students started rallying to protest a government freeze on hiring civil servants, including university graduates. Government officials have said the students expect too much from this north-central African country that is among the poorest in the world. Students also have been demanding an end to alleged corruption in the government of Saibou, a brigadier general who was at a drought conference in neighboring Bissau during the confrontation. Niger News Agency said Saibou returned home later Friday and was meeting Saturday with his advisers and other politicians in an effort to end the unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Spill Revised Up to 394,000 Gallons as Crews Struggle Against Dirty Tide
DOC.TEXT: Miles of Southern California beaches were closed Saturday as cleanup crews tried to sop up a black tide and officials revised the size of the American Trader oil spill up to 394,000 gallons. The 12-mile-long slick stained beaches, threatened wildlife habitats and taxed crews dabbing at the onslaught with absorbent pads. Oil got through a boom across the Santa Ana River and caused damage there, the Coast Guard said, but booms guarding other inlets to ecologically sensitive wetlands areas were not breached. Twenty-six sea birds were reported to have been killed by the spill and 60 birds were under care after cleaning. Authorities warned would-be volunteers to stay away because of the toxicity of the contamination and the hazard from heavy equipment being used in the shoreline cleanup effort. ``The public can be a hazard in this process if they don't let the professionals come in and do their work,'' said Ray Picard, fire chief and civil defense director of Huntington Beach. Closed to the public were 9 miles of sand from Seal Beach south through Sunset Beach, Bolsa Chica State Beach and Huntingtion city and state beaches. Farther south, Newport Beach also warned the public off its beaches. Before lifeguards ordered spectators and volunteer cleaners to leave the shoreline Saturday morning, David Manier, 16, of La Habra and two buddies walked along Huntington Beach picking up blobs of oil. ``We come down here almost every weekend to bodyboard and stuff,'' said Manier. ``This is just really bad.'' The main body of oil lurked offshore but winds and tides have pushed fingers of the slick ashore at various points along the entire 18-mile stretch since Thursday evening, 24 hours after the tanker began leaking. The spill's estimated size was revised upward by nearly one-third to 394,000 gallons, Coast Guard Capt. Jim Card told a news conference. The slick had elongated to measure 12 miles by 3{ miles and was centered 2{ miles off the coast between Huntington Beach and Newport Beach. Some spots of oil were seen as far north as the Long Beach Harbor entrance. A fleet of skimmer boats had recovered about 900 barrels of oil by Friday night, Card said. Eight skimmers were at work and two more were due Saturday. The Coast Guard, meanwhile, continued to pump oil from the 811-foot tanker which apparently punctured itself twice on its own anchor about 4:30 p.m. Wednesday while mooring in shallow water at an offshore oil pipeline. The accident remained under investigation. The Coast Guard said drug and alcohol tests on the ship's officers, including Capt. Robert Laware, were negative. Mike Murphy, vice president of American Trading and Transportation Co., said divers inspected the hull and made a videotape on Friday. ``There are very, very sharp indents. They almost look like the fluke of an anchor might have done it,'' Murphy said. ``There's no doubt in our mind that either our anchor or something like an anchor did it. We're not exactly sure it was ours. ``However, I cannot explain the fact that I have a port anchor on the vessel damaged to the point that I have to take it off the ship and replace it.'' The 90,000 barrels of oil that did not leak from the punctured tank was transferred to a barge on Friday. Card said completion of that process allowed for the more accurate assessment of how much oil actually got out, resulting in the increase. The tanker will move from its anchorage off Huntington Beach under its own power with 460,000 barrels of oil still aboard in other holds, Murphy said.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Has Airport Up in Arms
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs last graf to CORRECT that Denver airport is not abandoned
DOC.TEXT: The operators of Washington's Dulles International Airport say a planned sequel to the action thriller ``Die Hard'' creates such a bad image of it that people may want to take off and land elsewhere. The movie ``Die Hard II: Die Harder,'' will show airport operations ``in a manner that will unquestionably undermine public confidence in the airport and in air travel,'' attorney Edward S. Faggen said in a letter last week to 20th Century Fox. The script calls for a deposed Latin American dictator-drug runner to be flown to Washington for trial. But a band of right-wing, overzealous former U.S. military officers, believing that the dictator was an American ally, decide to take over the airport and free him. One plane crashes and others are forced to circle above, running low on fuel, until Detective John McClane, played again by Bruce Willis, shootshis way to the rescue. Faggen, legal counsel to the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority, said the script ``reflects a reckless disregard for the truth or the reality of the airport and airport operations.'' The script depicts some Dulles management and employes ``in a loathsome and contemptible manner,'' Faggen added. Fox officials said the film would include a disclaimer identifying it as fiction, but Faggen said Fox should give the airport a fictitious name and remove all references to Dulles. But the company ``has no plans to change the name,'' spokesman Dennis Petroskey said. ``The Washington locale is very important to the story line.'' The film is actually filmed at Denver's Stapleton International. Fox, however, is free to take exterior shots of Dulles for the movie without permission, Faggen said.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Joyful Over Mandela Release
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Kenneth Kaunda, one of the staunchest critics of the South African government, said Saturday he hoped the release of Nelson Mandela would lead to negotiations between the government and South African black leaders. Kaunda said he looked forward to ``serious negotiations starting as quickly as possible, because I don't think we have the time to waste.'' The Zambian leader said his first reaction to news of the African National Congress leader's scheduled release Sunday was to pray. ``I knelt down and prayed. The first thing I did was to say thank God, he is great,'' said Kaunda, a lay preacher and former schoolteacher. Zambia is the external headquarters of the ANC, which until Feb. 2 was outlawed in South Africa. In the group's first official reaction to de Klerk's announcement, senior ANC official James Stuart called it ``very exciting news.'' ``We welcome Nelson Mandela back from all those years of imprisonment into our midst with great joy,'' Stuart, a member of the ANC national executive committee, told reporters. ``It is really a turning point in our history, something we and the whole world have been demanding,'' he said. Stuart said the external ANC leaders expected Mandela to visit them in Zambia ``at some point in the future'' to take up his place as ``the formost leader of our organization.'' De Klerk said that Mandela will be freed at 3 p.m. (8 a.m. EST) Sunday from the Cape Town prison farm where he has been serving a life term for plotting to overthrow the white-led government. ``We can hardly believe it. It is a little bit unreal. Now is the time for great celebrations for the ANC and for our people at home and for all those who supported us over the many years,'' said Stuart. Stuart, asked about possible ANC policy changes in the wake of Mandela's release, said the group's leaders were scheduled to hold a series of meetings in Lusaka. ``I cannot say how we are going to react in the sense of what we are going to do immediately, but we are certainly very happy,'' he said. Kaunda said the months ahead would probably be ``a very trying period'' in South Africa. ``We cannot expect things to start moving quickly and smoothly all at once. The greatest thing is that Nelson Mandela will be out of prison tomorrow. This will enable the ANC leaders to begin to get together the rest of the leadership in South Africa and begin talking across color and any other artificial barriers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Halts Production, Recalls Mineral Water in Benzene Scare
DOC.TEXT: The Perrier Group of America Inc. began removing its bottled mineral water from U.S. stores on Saturday and shut down its France-based bottling operation after finding benzene in some samples. Benzene is considered a poison, but a Food and Drug Administration spokesman said Saturday the levels detected in FDA tests of Perrier water pose ``no immediate health risk.'' ``If I had a bottle in the refrigerator, I would drink it,'' said acting FDA Commissioner James Benson. Benzene is a clear, flammable, poisonous liquid used as a solvent for fats and in making lacquers, varnishes and dyes. At high enough doses, it has been linked to cancer in animals. Ronald V. Davis, president of Greenwich-based Perrier Group of America, which distributes the bottled water in the United States, characterized the presence of benzene as a ``freak accident.'' The company believes the chemical's presence was caused by a human error in France, either in the production of the glass bottles, the bottling of the water, or its transportation, Davis said at a news conference Saturday. ``There is no reason at all it should be in our product,'' he said. ``We don't understand it.'' He said the company has ruled out sabotage and has found no evidence of benzene in the natural, underground mineral spring in Vergeze, France, where the water is drawn and bottled by a 127-year-old French company. ``We are not producing at all until we are sure we have found this needle in a haystack,'' he said. The company plans to destroy its entire U.S. inventory, about 72 million bottles, and has directed distributors to start pulling the water from stores' shelves, Davis said. The company hopes to resume production ``very, very soon,'' he said, but plans on losing two or three months' worth of sales _ about $40 million _ because of the depletion of inventory and the halt in bottling. Perrier has not detected benzene in European samples and has no plans to recall the drink from European stores, Davis said. The bubbly water, sold in distinctive green bottles, has acquired great popularity in the U.S. as a healthy, upscale soft drink. The company estimates annual U.S. sales at $150 million. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said the agency found levels of benzene in Perrier samples at two to four times the Environmental Protection Agency's standard for drinking water. The standard is 5 parts per billion, and the levels found ranged from 12 to 20 parts per billion, he said. The elevated levels were discovered by North Carolina health officials during routine testing. However, Nesbit said the FDA's health evaluation board ``concluded that there is no immediate health risk. ... People can continue drinking Perrier.'' ``These are fairly low levels and there's a negligible risk involved here,'' he said. A lifetime of drinking water with these levels of benzene would increase the risk of cancer by one in a million, which is generally recognized as negligible, he said. Nonetheless, the company felt its actions were warranted to restore consumer confidence, Davis said. ``We're in the integrity business, selling purity and quality.'' The company will offer refunds to customers and has established a toll-free number for consumer complaints or inquiries, he said. In Paris, a spokeswoman for the French health ministry confirmed that there is no contamination at the spring. Tests at Perrier's source are done regularly by the local office of the Direction Generale de la Sante. French Health Minister Claude Evin has asked Perrier to test some of the bottles and cans of water in France to make sure there is not a similar problem to the one in the United States. The company is expected to begin testing the water next week.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Initially Refused Amputation Thanks Doctors For Surgery
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose initial refusal to have a gangrenous leg amputated led to a court battle thanked doctors Saturday after they removed the infected limb, her grandson said. Doctors amputated Ruth Trabelsi's right leg just above the knee Friday night. She developed gangrene in the foot as a complication from hardening of the arteries and blood clotting. ``After the operation she said `I hope it's all over and they won't have to take off anymore,''' said Peres Trabelsi, a grandson of the 84-year-old woman. ``She thanked the doctors, but she's groggy now and has a little trouble breathing so we told her not to speak,'' he said in a telephone interview from Poriah Hospital in Tiberias. Trabelsi said doctors listed his grandmother in ``moderate'' condition. Mrs. Trabelsi initially refused to have the operation, saying she wanted ``to enter the Garden of Eden on both feet.'' Doctors said she would die without the surgery. The case went to court last week under a law that requires the state to protect people who may not be capable of making decisions for themselves. But the government dropped the case after a geriatric specialist testified that Mrs. Trabelsi was lucid and fully capable of making her own decisions. Some of the woman's 258 children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, however, continued to press the woman to have the surgery. Only on Friday did Mrs. Trabelsi consent to the amputation after a visit from Mordechai Eliahu, chief rabbi of Israel's Sephardic Jews, those of Middle East and African origin. Eliahu, who flew from Jerusalem to Tiberias by helicopter, had said that if she refused the amputation of the gangrene-infected leg, she would be violating religious law by in effect committing suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition To Tell Baker The Front Wants To Control Romania (AMs)
With AM-Romania-Timisoara
DOC.TEXT: Opposition parties said they will tell Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Sunday that an interim government running the country until May elections is merely a guise for the old Communist Party. ``It's a dictate,'' Raul Volcinski, economic adviser to the center-right Democratic Christian Union, said Saturday. The interim government _ the Council of National Unity _ is a multiparty body formed Friday. It replaced the National Salvation Front's ruling council that took power from hard-line Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December's revolution and executed him. The Front stepped aside after reversing an earlier pledge not to field its own candidates in the May 20 election. But opposition leaders say the new Council of National Unity is packed with Front supporters and former leaders of the now-defunct Communist Party. ``The Front is the second edition of the Communist Party,'' Volcinski said. A leading Ceausescu critic who quit the Front's ruling council was quoted in an interview published Saturday as saying the West should stop all economic aid to Romania pending the creation of democracy in the country. ``The revolution in favor of democracy and against communism is in great danger,'' said Doina Cornea, quoted by the French-language newspaper Tribune de Geneve in an interview at her home in the western town of Cluj. Baker, who planned a four-hour stopover in Bucharest Sunday morning en route to Canada, will be the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit Romania since the revolution. Washington welcomed the uprising but last month protested what it called the National Salvation Front's intimidation of opposition parties. Baker was to meet interim President Ion Iliescu, Premier Petre Roman, opposition leaders, students and the ethnic Hungarian priest Laszlo Toekes, whose expulsion from the western city of Timisoara sparked the revolution. The Council of National Unity held its inaugural meeting on Friday and Iliescu praised it for reaching consensus, a view backed by some political parties. But the major opposition parties said they will tell Baker that there was anything but consensus, and they accused Iliescu of using steamroller tactics to keep the Front's grip on power. The Council of Unity expanded the number of people on the body from the 180 on the Front's council. Iliescu said it would have 253 members but Romanian reporters following the proceedings, which were not open to the foreign news media, counted 259 members. Tariceanu said Iliescu ignored an agreement to limit the number of parties in the council to 30 and packed the non-party bloc of seats entirely with Front members. Other party representatives also charged that the party bloc included bogus parties created by the Front for the purpose of assuring its majority. ``It is very obvious to all the people that they tried to create the impression that the political parties are fighting for power, which is not true,'' said Calin Tariceanu, a member of the National Liberal Party's top organizing committee. ``But it was the Front who were demonstrating that they did not want to share power. They want to remain the leading force. That is obvious,'' he said. The Front's decision to field candidates in the May election sparked widespread protests by opposition parties and students who were in the forefront of the revolution. They demanded that the Front resign, arguing that it couldn't be both a referee and a player in the election. The U.S. protest on Jan. 30 followed the largest demonstrations in Bucharest since the revolution, in which pro-Front demonstrators attacked the Liberal Party headquarters and attempted to get into the National Peasant Party headquarters. Twenty-six offices of the Peasant Party around the country were attacked. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutweiler said the Front's intimidation appeared to be directed at ``legitimate organizations which are seeking a legitimate independent role in Romania's new political order.'' Democratic Christian Union Vice President Voinea Octavian charged that the Front is using the ``still intact'' mechanism of Ceausescu's hated Securitate secret police ``to intimidate and terrorize the political parties.''

DOC.HEAD: Youngsters at Day-Care Center Contract Gonorrhea
DOC.TEXT: Three small children who attended a day-care center owned by a man arrested on pornography charges have been found to have gonorrhea, sending distraught parents to a counseling center. The youngsters, ages 2 to 4, attended the Rainbow Learning Center and were among 20 children identified from thousands of nude photographs found at the home of the center's owner, John W. Shaver, police said. Police announced Friday that throat cultures done on the three children turned up the disease, which is usually transmitted through sexual contact. ``We have to find out where the infection came from,'' Fort Lauderdale police spokesman Ott Cefkin said. ``We have nothing that links Shaver or the center with those three cases. Other people have had contact with these children.'' All 20 youngsters identified from among 3,200 photos of nude children found at Shaver's home were tested for gonorrhea, as were other youngsters who attended the preschool. Results for the other children were pending Saturday or had come back negative, authorities said. Numerous worried parents not listed on the center's registry began to contact police after Shaver's arrest Jan. 28 on five felony counts of possessing child pornography in the form of magazines and other published material. Shaver, 56, has not been charged in connection with the photographs of children. The pictures do not depict sex acts or sexual poses, but show the children at play, authorities said. Police already know of more than 200 families who used the day-care center. ``We've been counseling the parents,'' said Joanne Richter, director of the Broward County Sexual Assault Treatment Center. ``Their state of mind ranges from disbelief to denial to anger and guilt that they sent their kids there.'' After the announcement of the infections, several parents contacted the treatment center to bring their children in for medical and psychological examinations or counseling, Cefkin said. ``In such an alarming situation, the parents feel better if they know what's going on,'' Ms. Richter said. Shaver ran a day-care center in Hawaii in the mid-1980s, but it was closed in 1984 amid allegations that he fondled young girls at the center. He was never charged and denied any wrongdoing. Shaver, who posted $5,000 bond on the Florida charges, denied any improper actions with children. He tried to commit suicide Feb. 2 by slashing a wrist and was undergoing treatment at a mental health center, authorities said. Although the photographs themselves are not pornographic under the law, they could lead to sexual exploitation accusations against Shaver if the evidence meets that criteria, police have said.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela's Daughter Eyes Her Father's Future Freedom
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's daughter said Saturday she is pleased her father will walk out of prison in daylight rather than under the secrecy of night. Now, she hopes trustworthy advisers will help him as he takes his first steps from imprisoned martyrdom to the down-to-earth reality of life as a black leader. ``He has to stop living now as this martyr, this god, and live as a human being,'' said Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah, a Fulbright Scholar studying anthropology. Saturday morning, just an hour after South African President F.W. de Klerk announced that Mandela would be freed unconditionally Sunday afternoon, the phone ran incessantly at his daughter's apartment near the University of Massachusetts. Mandela-Amuah, who is known as Maki and lives in this college town with her husband and three children, was elated by the news but her responsibilities as a mother took first priority. She said she would spend the day with her children at a dinosaur exhibit she had promised them. She said, however, she would be in church Sunday to ``thank God it finally happened.'' ``That will be my celebration,'' said Mandela-Amuah, whose father was jailed more than 27 years ago when she was 8 years old. Mandela-Amuah, the youngest of three children from Mandela's first marriage, said she didn't expect to visit her father before summer because until then he would likely be caught up in political matters. ``What I want is that quality time,'' said Mandela-Amuah, who says she will be getting to know her 71-year-old father for the first time. ``I am selfish in that way, but really I have to be selfish.''
