It had been rumored that Mandela would be smuggled out at night to avoid the protests of political extremists. But Mandela-Amuah said it would have been hypocritical for her father to leave prison under the protection of a regime he had battled for years. ``He can't accept their security. He has to walk out in the open,'' she said. ``It's not that I don't have fear that my father is in great danger. I am worried about that.'' Mandela, imprisoned for his role in planning the African National Congress guerilla campaign against white minority rule, will likely receive protection from ANC after his release, his daughter said. Meanwhile, at a news conference in Boston, activist Patrick Lekota said Mandela's release was a victory in the battle against apartheid in South Africa. ``Short of national liberation, Nelson's release marks total victory,'' said Lekota, a spokesman for the United Democratic Front in South Africa. ``From here we can scale the heights,'' said Lekota, who was in town to participate in an international conference on non-violent political action sponsored by The Einstein Institution. At a separate press conference later in Boston, Mandela's eldest daughter, Zenani Mandela-Dlamini, said she was excited that her father was being freed. ``This is what we've worked for all these years,'' she said, adding that there were still many problems in her country. Mandela-Dlamini, 31, a student at Boston University, was accompanied at the press conference by her husband, Thumbumuzi, and her two daughters and son. ``I'm proud of who he is,'' she said. ``I know he has a job to do outside.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Mandela Neighbors Dance and Sing, But 5 Killed 45 Injured In Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with five killed, 45 injured when police break up demonstration. Other details on celebration in Johannesburg. Pickup 13th graf pvs, `The rest...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-South Africa, Bjt
LaserPhoto JOH4
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu did a jig in the street Saturday to celebrate Nelson Mandela's imminent release and other neighbors in this black township outside Johannesburg sang and danced near the jailed leader's home. In Kathlehong, another black township southeast of Johannesburg, police said five blacks were killed and 45 injured after officers used tear gas and birdshot to disperse a crowd of anti-apartheid protesters. Police would not give further details Saturday night. he rally was held shortly after the white-dominated government announced the 71-year-old leader of the African National Congress will be freed Sunday after 27 years of imprisonment. ``Come, come, come, Mandela!'' women and children sang in Zulu outside the small brick home that Mandela's family has rented for 40 years in the old Orlando section of Soweto. Tutu, who lives a few blocks away, came out of his home laughing. ``It's a happy day,'' he said, and began to dance. Commenting that he had never before given the popular ``Viva'' black freedom salute, Tutu decided this was the time, and he shouted ``Viva!'' As he was driven away in a car, Tutu looked out the window and yelled ``Yaaaayyyyyyyyy!'' waving to a few people gathered around. In Johnannesburg late Saturday night, more than 3,000 blacks marched to celebrate Mandela's scheduled release. Some ran as police cars followed, others gathered in groups shouting ``Viva, Mandela,'' ``Welcome to our Leader.'' Women hugged Sunday editions of newspapers bearing Mandela's picture to their breasts, kissing the photograph and shrieking with delight. Cars honked their horns and people waved from the balconies of apartment buildings. A few whites gave ANC salutes and there were a few in the procession; others looked terrified, shrinking against buildings as the marchers passed. When some young blacks spat at white bystanders, other blacks stopped them. Many white motorists honked their horns seriously and some drove at high speed, sending black marchers scattering but causing no injuries. Some whites in high-rise apartments hurled bottles as a column of marchers, shadowed by police cars, reached the multiracial neighborhood of Hillbrow. No one was hit. Young blacks pantomimed firing at police with make-believe Soviet-designed AK-47 automatic rifles, the symbol of the ANC's military wing. But Tutu said one of Mandela's main tasks would be to try to bring South Africans together and obtain social justice for blacks. ``What Nelson is going to be doing is to focus all those aspirations (of the people), and we'll be able to draw people of different points of view together in bringing about this new, non-racial, non-sexist democratic South Africa,'' Tutu said. President F.W. de Klerk told a news conference in Cape Town that Mandela would be freed at the gates of Victor Verster prison on Sunday afternoon. The rest of the world heard the news before most South Africans. It was not broadcast on government-run radio and television until an hour later, and a black-oriented TV channel did not interrupt its coverage of a soccer game. But later the entire news conference was shown, and the story took up all of the evening news programs. Most of Soweto's 2.5 million people got news of Mandela's release by word of mouth. Mandela's wife, Winnie, attended a funeral earlier Saturday for Clayton Sizwe Sithole, boyfriend of her youngest daughter, Zindziwe. Sithole was found hanging in a cell at police headquarters two weeks ago after being arrested in the investigation of a year-old murder. Mrs. Mandela, wearing a khaki uniform and military cap with braiding and epaulettes in the gold, green and black colors of the African National Congress, arrived at the modern house where she has lived for several years in a separate section of Soweto called Diepkloof. A crowd of 50 women and children were already in the street around her home, but de Klerk's announcement was five minutes away. A woman who answered the phone at the old Mandela home said the Prisons Service had been calling Mrs. Mandela all day to alert her to the news. When Mrs. Mandela finally heard, she came out of her house and got into a white car, which was immediately surrounded and halted by singing, dancing neighbors. She repeatedly reached out the window of the passenger side to shake hands with well-wishers but made no comment. There was more cheering and dancing when she stopped briefly at the old Mandela home, where an ANC flag flies from the roof. Wilton Mkwayi, a member of Mandela's first guerrilla unit who was freed from a life prison term along with other ANC leaders last October, has been occupying the old Mandela home. ``We naturally feel very jovial. It is a moment that for 28 years we have waited for impatiently,'' said Popo Molefe, a leader of the United Democratic Front, the nation's largest anti-apartheid coalition, which de Klerk legalized on Feb. 2. ``His release has come as a result of the ordinary struggles taking place on the ground,'' Molefe said as he entered the Mandela home for a meeting of black leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Says He'll Be There To Greet Mandela
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD details of media coverage of Jackson's visit, INSERT one graf at end of story; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said Saturday he intends to be at the gates of the prison when Nelson Mandela walks out a free man. Jackson, on his first visit here in a decade, called President F.W. de Klerk's announcement that Mandela will be released Sunday ``a hopeful step in the right direction.'' But he added: ``He (Mandela) is out of jail, but not free; not free to move to the neighborhood of his choice, not free to send his grandchildren to the school of his choice, not free to vote, not free to run for office in his own country.'' Jackson also told a news conference that police had fired at a crowd of 2,000 people who gathered in a township to greet him, and one man was wounded. Police said a black man in possession of a South African security force rifle had fired at ``an opposing group'' and at police, and that police returned fire but the man escaped. Police made no mention of injuries, but said none of the vehicles in Jackson's entourage was hit. Jackson said his aides were trying to contact a Cabinet minister about the shooting. ``If the police, who reacted this way to 2,000 people, display the same mentality when tens of thousands of people are on the streets to welcome Mandela, what could be an occasion of great hope could be a disaster,'' said Jackson, who has run two unsuccessful campaigns for the Democratic Party's presidential nomination. Jackson praised de Klerk's ``bold and courageous acts'' but said the president must be encouraged to dismantle apartheid. He said he was worried about the powers police continue to wield under the national state of emergency, which de Klerk has said will be ended in a few weeks if political unrest does not erupt with Mandela's release. Police currently are authorized to take any action they see fit to protect law and order, and they can order gatherings to disperse within seconds. ``I would not like to think what would happen if any policeman were to use his awesome powers under the state of emergency when Mr. Mandela is on the streets or meeting people,'' Jackson said. ``It would cause the kind of disaster nobody, not even Mr. Mandela, could turn around.'' Jackson's comments and activities were heavily covered by the media at the start of his visit on Thursday and Friday. There were a couple dozen reporters at his news conference on Saturday, but his trip by then had been overshadowed by news of Mandela's release.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Right-Wingers Denounce De Klerk, Mandela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CORRECT day in lead to Saturday sted Sunday, UPDATES with 5 blacks dead in demonstration in black township. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Eugene TerreBlanche...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of extreme right-wingers yelling ``Hang Mandela!'' marched through the streets with swastika flags Saturday to demand the overthrow of President F.W. de Klerk. Members of the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, dressed in khaki uniforms and armed with whips, knives and pistols, marched to government headquarters with a tiny white coffin representing whites killed in terrorist attacks. Marchers dumped the coffin after police refused to accept it. ``Hang de Klerk!'' and ``We are ready to fight!'' the column of about 2,000 marchers yelled on their way to the Union Buildings. ``Hang Mandela!'' The march began before de Klerk made the long-awaited announcement that black leader Nelson Mandela would be freed from prison Sunday. But the news spread quickly among the demonstrators as the march progressed. Blacks throughout the country celebrated the news. Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, has been in prison for more than 27 years. Police said five blacks were killed and 45 injured after officers fired birdshot and tear gas to break up an anti-apartheid demonstration in the township of Kathlehong outside Johannesburg. Authorities provided no further details. Hundreds of police, who authorized the white march in Pretoria, stood guard along the way. Marchers scuffled with some journalists and onlookers but there were no other incidents. Police ordered blacks to leave the area to avoid confrontations. Eugene TerreBlanche, leader of the white resistance movement, told about 3,000 people at a rally before the march that de Klerk's plan to negotiate with blacks on extending some political rights to them was a betrayal of South Africa's white minority. He said the government's move would trigger a massive white backlash. ``We will launch a revolution to save our freedom,'' he told the cheering crowd. ``We won't give up a centimeter of South Africa.'' TerreBlanche said de Klerk's legalization of the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups Feb. 2 was an acceptance of terrorism. He said the president was crippling the white security forces and preparing the way for black domination. ``He's inviting the murderers of the ANC to the table for talks,'' TerreBlanche said. His supporters, including hundreds of men, women and children in the group's khaki uniforms, applauded and waved the group's swastika-style red, white and black flags. Some protesters carried Nazi swastika flags. ``No blacks'' and ``Hitler was right,'' said signs carried by marchers. Local journalists said the crowd attracted by the resistance movement was much larger than its other recent meetings in the Pretoria area. TerreBlanche tried to present 30 coins, representing the biblical 30 pieces of silver paid to Judas to betray Jesus Christ, at the president's office at the Union Buildings. A senior police officer refused to accept the money and TerreBlanche hurled it on the ground. ``Judas, come and fetch your money!'' enraged marchers yelled. Hundreds of whites watched the march through the city, many leaning out of apartment windows as the singing column passed, but most people showed no sign of sympathy or support. Asked about de Klerk's announcement that Mandela will be freed Sunday, TerreBlanche said he had no reaction. He declined to comment on his plans, beyond saying his group would call for a referendum to oust de Klerk. The group supports the continuation of white supremacist rule. Its support in the past has been confined to a few thousand members. De Klerk announced Saturday that Mandela would be released Sunday after 27 years in jail as part of plans to begin negotiations with black leaders on extending political rights to blacks. By law and custom, South Africa's apartheid system establishes a racially segregated society in which the 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: White-Supremacist Network Includes Guards, Inmates at Ohio Prison
DOC.TEXT: A white-supremacist network of up to 800 inmates also includes guards and controls prostitution, drugs and gambling at Ohio's maximum-security prison, a legislative committee official alleges. Gov. Richard Celeste on Friday ordered an immediate and comprehensive investigation of gang activity at the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility at Lucasville after the panel linked the group to the stabbings of four black inmates. Three of the inmates died of their wounds. The allegations surfaced in a letter to state Sen. Paul Pfeifer from the executive director of the Ohio Legislature's prison oversight committee. Peter Davis of the House-Senate Correctional Institutional Inspection Committee told Pfeifer the network at the prison includes guards as well as inmates, who wear tattoos of lightning bolts on their necks. They earn their lightning bolts by violently attacking other inmates, authorities said. Davis said in the letter that the white supremacist group has gained substantial power at the prison. ``Recently the gang was estimated to number between 600 and 800 inmates. The whites have reportedly gained control over drug dealings, prostitution and gambling within the facility,'' Davis said. The prison has 2,142 inmates, 940 of whom are white. In several other states, prison officials said they use a divide and conquer approach to white supremacist groups in their prisons. In California, white supremacists have assaulted guards inside and outside prisons, said Tip Kindel, a California Department of Corrections official. Kindel said the problems peaked about five years ago. To keep leaders from recruiting new members, prison officials placed many of them in isolation, he said. In Washington state, corrections officials control white-supremacist inmates by moving potentially violent ones frequently within a prison and between prisons, said Veltry Johnson of the Department of Corrections there. In Idaho, where many supremacist groups often hold retreats, such inmates spend hours in prison libraries and often sue the state prison system unsuccessfully, said Dick Vernon, the Idaho corrections director. Nick Howell of the Illinois Department of Corrections said white supremacists have not been noticed in his prisons, but those on the outside often mail hate literature to inmates.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Who Had Heart Surgery Before Birth Dies From Complications
DOC.TEXT: A 5-week-old baby who underwent heart surgery before birth died from complications Saturday after his parents and doctors decided to turn off his life-support systems, hospital officials said. Doctors at Guy's Hospital had described the two operations on the unborn child as the first successful prenatal heart surgery. But Dr. Michael Tynan, head of the surgery team, said baby Michele Vermilio's heart condition had taken a toll on his kidneys and they never improved enough to provide a proper blood supply to enable him to live without a ventilator. If the ventilator supporting his lungs had been left running, Tynan said, the baby would not have died but would have continued to suffer. ``Despite sedation and despite painkillers, he was beginning to be very distressed,'' Tynan said. Kidney dialysis treatment, which had been causing pain, was stopped on Friday. Hospital staff had continued to treat him with painkillers, medication and food in case he was able to sustain life on his own, a medical report said. Michele died within 45 minutes after the ventilator was shut off, said Tynan, professor of pediatric cardiology at the hospital. ``He died in his parents' arms. We were doing our best to ensure he did not have any unnecessary suffering,'' Tynan told a news conference. The exact cause of death was not given. He said the decision to turn off the ventilator, which assisted the child's breathing, was made by medical staff and the parents, Ann and Bernard Vermilio. Doctors said the baby suffered from a rare defect called critical aortic stenosis, a blockage of the aortic valve in which blood cannot be pumped at the right pressure. Heart failure can result. Lindsay Allan, the doctor in charge of the fetal cardiology unit, said most fetuses with the defect die in the womb and the few who survive birth do not live more than a day. She said the two operations on the fetus involved inserting a catheter, a slender tube, down a hollow needle directly into the chest wall and heart. Once in place, the tiny plastic balloon _ measuring .11 of an inch _ was inflated with a saline solution to open the heart valve, Ms. Allan said. The mother received a local anesthetic and was awake during both operations. ``There was no indication that the fetus felt anything,'' said Darryl Maxwell, director of the hospital's fetal medicine unit, who monitored the surgery with an ultrasonic scanner.

DOC.HEAD: Army Disperses Palestinian Mourners, Wounds Dozens
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers in the occupied Gaza Strip on Saturday broke up a gathering of Palestinians mourning the death of an Arab youth killed last week and wounded 21 of them, hospital and Arab reports said. They said the troops entered the home of the parents of Ayman Khalil Zakout in the Shabura neighborhood of Rafah and ordered those there to leave. A shoving match broke out between the soldiers and mourners, and troops opened fire when hundreds of neighbors started to intervene, Arab reports said. They said Palestinians had gathered to offer condolences to Zakout's parents. Zakout, 18, was fatally shot in a stone-throwing clash with troops on Feb. 7. Doctors at Nasser Hospital in Rafah said that 47 people, including a 70-year-old man shot in the left thigh, arrived at the hospital after the melee. They said that 21 of them suffered from gunshot wounds and the rest were wounded by rubber-coated metal pellets. An army spokesman said 31 wounded arrived at Nasser Hospital, but that 21 were treated and released. The spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations, said the clash had occured near Zakout's house, but that officials were still checking the circumstances. Palestinians have been waging a 27-month-long revolt against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. During that time, 655 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians. At least 181 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of cooperatin with Israel. Forty-three Israelis also have died in the violence. At least nine other Palestinians were wounded Saturday in stone-throwing clashes with soldiers, Arab reports said. In Gaza City, soldiers used tear gas to disperse about 60 members of the outlawed Palestine Communist Party as they marched through a main market to celebrate the eighth anniversary of its founding, Arab reporters said. Communists also held a similar demonstration in the occupied West Bank city of Nablus, where about 50 party members paraded through the center of town waving PLO flags and red banners, Arab reporters said. The army said one youth was wounded in an ensuing stone-throwing clash with soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk: Nelson Mandela to be Freed Sunday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with domestic news agency quoting Mandela from recent interview, INSERT 3 grafs after 11th pvs, `But in...' Pickup 12 graf pvs, `President Bush...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON3,LON5,NY19,NY20,NY97,CPN1,CPN2,JOH4,
DOC.TEXT:
Nelson Mandela, the symbol of South African blacks' struggle for equality, will become a free man Sunday after 27 years in prison for fighting white-minority rule, President F.W. de Klerk announced. De Klerk said Saturday he hoped the long-awaited release would halt decades of racial conflict and clear the way for negotiations that would extend political rights to the black majority. The release ``will bring us to the end of a long chapter,'' de Klerk told a news conference. ``There can no longer be any doubt about the government's sincerity in seeking to create a just dispensation based on negotiations.'' Six anti-apartheid activists conferred with Mandela about logistics of the release and told reporters the 71-year-old black leader, along with his family, would ride to freedom in a bulletproof Mercedes-Benz through the gates of Victor Verster prison farm outside Cape Town. De Klerk said he met with Mandela Friday night and was convinced the prisoner, jailed for helping launch the African National Congress' guerrilla campaign, was ``committed to a peaceful solution.'' The government released a photograph of the two leaders at their meeting _ the first picture of Mandela made available to the public since the 1960s. He is shown next to de Klerk, hands folded in front, a big smile on his wrinkled face. Mandela's freedom has been a longstanding demand of black leaders in South Africa, as well as governments and human rights groups abroad, and the decision drew immediate international praise. In Johannesburg and its main black township, Soweto, blacks thronged the streets in celebration. ``Our leader is coming!'' shouted an excited black youth in Johannesburg amidst a din of freedom songs and car horns. Other blacks jogged through major thoroughfares holding aloft newspapers with the huge headline: ``He's Free!'' Archbishop Desmond Tutu did a jig on the street in Soweto, Mandela's hometown, and declared, ``These are incredible days in which we are living.'' Outside the small brick home Mandela's family has rented 40 years, women and children sang in Zulu, ``Come, come, come, Mandela!'' But in Kathlehong, another township near Johannesburg, police said five blacks were killed and 45 injured after officers used tear gas and birdshot to disperse a crowd of anti-apartheid protesters. The rally began shortly before the announcement of Mandela's release. Police would give no further details. The South African Press Association, an independent domestic news agency, quoted Mandela as saying in a recent interview that he sought to promote unity between blacks and whites. ``Whites fear the reality of democracy,'' he was quoted as saying. ``We must work towards a common destiny, and that can only be achieved through a non-racial society and not one in which whites continue to demand special political treatment.'' The news agency did not specify when the interview was conducted or how it was arranged. Mandela is not known to have received any journalists as visitors. President Bush said Mandelas release would be a ``significant step'' away from apartheid. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher congratulated de Klerk for a ``wise decision'' and said the time had come to resume contacts with South Africa's isolated government. ``It's a great victory for our people,'' said James Stuart, a member of the ANC's executive committee. ``I can hardly believe it.'' But in the capital, Pretoria, hundreds of extreme right-wingers yelling ``Hang Mandela!'' marched through the streets with swastika flags to demand the overthrow of de Klerk's government. De Klerk, who stunned South Africans on Feb. 2 by lifting a 30-year ban on the ANC, said Mandela would be freed unconditionally at 3 p.m. (8 a.m. EST) Sunday at the gates of Victor Verster prison. Bulelani Ngcuka, one of the activists who met Mandela late Saturday, said police had expressed concern about his safety. ``We thanked them, but said the security of Comrade Mandela is our own affair,'' Ngcuka said. ``We will do all in our power to protect him.'' They said Mandela would make a statement to the press and give an address from the balcony of Cape Town's City Hall. At his news conference, De Klerk also said the 3{-year-old state of emergency could be lifted soon if there was no upsurge of unrest. He expressed willingness to negotiate the possible release of remaining political prisoners. Mandela, in recent talks with the government, had demanded freedom for all political prisoners and an end to the state of emergency. Mandela has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of the ANC's guerrilla campaign. Many South African blacks consider him their paramount leader, and he would be a favorite to win the presidency if blacks were allowed to vote. Under South Africa's system of apartheid, the 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, on a 12-day visit to South Africa, said he welcomed de Klerk's ``bold and courageous'' acts but urged nations to maintain pressure on the government until all segregation laws are abolished. Mandela ``is out of jail, but not free,'' he said. ``Not free to move to the neighborhood of his choice, not free to send his grandchildren to the school of his choice, not free to vote, not free to run for office in his own country.'' There was no immediate comment from Mandela's wife, Winnie, who left the family home in Soweto shortly before the announcement was made. She smiled broadly as her car drove away.
De Klerk, in his historic speech Feb. 2, lifted bans and restrictions on dozens of opposition groups, scrapped some state-of-emergency regulations, declared a moratorium on hangings, and promised to free Mandela unconditionally. De Klerk's predecessor, P.W. Botha, had offered to free Mandela in exchange for a public renunciation of violence. Mandela refused, saying the burden was on the government to legalize the ANC, scrap segregation laws and agree to political negotiations. Asked if Mandela had now repudiated violence, de Klerk said the black leader would be able to speak for himself Sunday. De Klerk, who succeeded Botha in August, has proposed negotiations with black leaders on a new constitution that would extend political rights to the disenfranchised black majority. ``The government is committed to bringing about through negotiation a new constitution which is fair and just for all the people of South Africa,'' de Klerk said. ``I hope that now that this chapter has ended, the world and more especially the people of South Africa will grasp the opportunity and play whatever supportive role can be played toward a peaceful conclusion.'' Asked whether Mandela's release, along with the earlier concessions, would bring about an end to Western sanctions against South Africa, de Klerk replied: ``We are not working against checklists. We are doing what we believe is in the best interests of South Africa.'' The government has expressed fears about Mandela's safety in light of reported death threats from right- and left-wing extremists. De Klerk said the matter of security was being discussed with Mandela's colleagues, but added: ``When he is released he becomes a free man. He doesn't owe it to me to inform me about his program.'' Mandela, quartered at a comfortable house at Victor Verster for more than a year, has been meeting regularly with a wide range of government officials and anti-apartheid activists in recent months. The government has indicated it would accept his offer to serve as mediator if talks with the ANC take place. Concessions announced by de Klerk in his speech met most of the ANC's conditions for negotiations. The organization says de Klerk still must lift the state of emergency and free all political prisoners, including those convicted of violent acts. In his Feb. 2 speech, de Klerk lifted long-term bans on the South African Communist Party and on the Pan Africanist Congress, a guerrilla movement smaller than the ANC and less open to a role for whites in the liberation struggle. A senior Pan Africanist leader, Barney Desai, on Saturday became the first long-term political exile to return to South Africa in the wake of de Klerk's announcement. Desai, 57, went into exile in 1962 while facing prosecution for defying restrictions placed on him by police.

DOC.HEAD: French Mediator Arrives in Beirut
DOC.TEXT: The head of a pro-Arab French lobbying group who helped persuade guerrillas to release two French children in 1988 arrived Saturday amid speculation he was on a new mediation mission. Lucien Bitterlin drove to Moslem west Beirut from Damascus, capital of neighboring Syria, to meet Defense Minister Albert Mansour, Information Minister Edmond Rizk and army commander Gen. Emile Lahoud at a beachside hotel. Bitterlin, a former Gaullist member of Parliament who leads the Franco-Arab Solidarity Association, refused to talk to reporters about why he was in Beirut. But his arrival raised speculation that he was seeking to secure the release of French and Belgian captives held by a radical Palestinian guerrilla group led by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. Bitterlin negotiated the Dec. 29, 1988, release of Marie-Laure Valente, then age 7, and her sister, Virginie, then age 6, from 13 months of the captivity with Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council faction. The Libyan-backed guerrillas still are holding the children's mother, Jacqueline Valente, and a baby daughter born in captivity, as well as five Belgians. They were taken captive Nov. 8, 1987, when the Silco, an old sardine trawler, was seized off the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip by Abu Nidal's guerrillas. There have been reports that the boat was in fact seized off Libya, adding to the mystery that has surrounded the plight of the captives since they disappeared. The Abu Nidal group claims the adults are agents of Mossad, Israel's intelligence service, and have made ``valuable'' confessions. The girls' freedom was widely viewed as an effort by Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi to boost his image at a time when the U.S. government, alleging Libya was building a chemical weapons plant, threatened to launch a military strike. Gadhafi called for the girls' release during Christmas 1988. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council has been blamed for scores of terrorist acts, including the December 1985 attacks on Rome and Vienna airports that killed more than 20 people, the September 1986 attack on an Istanbul synagogue that killed 21 worshipers and the 1983 mid-air bombing of a Gulf Air jetliner that killed all 122 people aboard. The case is considered unrelated to the 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon by pro-Iranian factions. They include eight Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped on March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Irate Parliamentarian Brandishes Knife in Parliament, Then Quits
DOC.TEXT: A lawmaker angry over what he called official corruption brandished a big knife during a session of the People's Assembly on Saturday, then said he was quitting and stormed out. The Middle East News Agency said no one was hurt. It identified the deputy as Ahmed Shetya of President Hosni Mubarak's majority National Democratic Party. Rhetorically addressing the absent Mubarak, Shetya demanded that all forms of corruption be fought, then took out ``a big knife'' and started waving it about, the government-run agency said. He ignored pleas by parliament speaker Rifaat el-Mahgoub to calm down and put away the weapon. Then he shouted out his resignation and charged from the session hall. Mahgoub ordered Shetya's speech struck from the session's record on grounds the lawmaker violated People's Assembly rules requiring members to address only their colleagues or the speaker. Middle East News Agency said it was the first time a member had brandished a knife during a session of the 458-member assembly. Last year, then-Interior Minister Zaki Badr got into a fistfight when an opposition member, walking out on the minister during a particularly rambunctious speech, tried to deck him. A senior member of the National Democratic Party, Kamal el-Shazly, told the news agency that the party is ``against corruption anywhere'' and that Shetya gave no examples of what raised his ire. He said National Democratic parliamentarians have a right to their opinions, even if they disagree with party leaders, and that Shetya would not be punished. Also, el-Shazly said, Shetya's announcement of his resignation was invalid because he had not followed regulations for quitting.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Says Gorbachev Gives Green Light to Reunified Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `The official...' to UPDATE with Kohl saying reunification planning should include Allies and could be presented at summit at end of year, existing boundaries to be respected. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Kohl was...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB6, MOS22
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Saturday that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised to respect German reunification, and he declared it a ``very good day for Germany.'' Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher also disclosed that they expect a reunification plan with agreement of the four victorious World War II Allies to be ready this year to present to a pan-European summit meeting. At a news conference following 2{-hours of talks with Gorbachev, Kohl gave a glowing assessment of relations with the Soviet Union and the Kremlin's attitude toward the accelerating developments between East and West Germany. Kohl said he acknowledged in his talk with Gorbachev that de facto reunification is occurring faster than anyone expected and said the two Germanies along with the Allies must work out a program for controlling it. Gorbachev agreed that the decision on reunification ``is the sole right of the German people,'' including the time frame and the method, Kohl said. The official Soviet news agency Tass carried a report on the Gorbachev-Kohl meeting that supported Kohl's assessment. Kohl said the World War II Allies _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ should be consulted in reunification planning. ``This should happen between the two (German) governments, but not behind the backs of the four powers,'' the chancellor said. ``At the end of this year there would be an opportunity within a summit-level European conference to discuss and announce these results,'' Kohl said. The Soviets had previously suggested such a meeting. ``General Secretary Gorbachev told me unequivocally that the Soviet Union will respect the decision of Germans to live in one state,'' Kohl said. ``This is a very good day for Germany and a happy day for me personally.'' Kohl and Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov indicated that a clear promise to respect the current boundaries outlining East Germany and West Germany also would be contained in a reunification plan. Kohl was received in the Kremlin for an evening of negotiations with Gorbachev, who is trying to cut Soviet losses from the democratic revolution that has drawn East Germany away from the Warsaw Pact. Gorbachev's acknowledgment nearly two weeks ago that German unification was inevitable set off a chain reaction of events that have stepped up the movement toward a single Germany. Tass commented in a report on the Kohl-Gorbachev meeting that a new political situation has evolved in central Europe and ``the two German states determine its nature in many respects.'' The Soviets face potentially major losses in military and economic cooperation if East Germany joins with the rich West German nation, now part of the NATO alliance. Kohl, on a two-week diplomatic sweep to forge a unity plan acceptable to both East and West, brought with him an offer of $132 million in aid for Soviet food purchases, apparently to demonstrate that Germany will help restore the economic losses from redirected East German trade. East Germany has suffered a severe economic decline in recent months as an exodus to West Germany increasingly claims its best workers and precludes independent efforts at recovery. As many as 3,000 East Germans flee the uncertainty in their homeland each day, and some West German officials fear imminent collapse. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told reporters before the West German officials arrived that the Kremlin sought assurances that a reunited Germany would recognize current borders and never rise as a threat to its European neighbors. Both West Germany and East Germany are bound by treaties to respect the current borders of Europe, but a united Germany is not committed to those terms. Conservatives in West Germany have suggested that reunification should be sought within the 1937 borders, which include areas in the Soviet Union as well as nearly a third of present-day Poland. Shevardnadze called the border issue the ``most relevant issue'' to be resolved in the reunification process. Shevardnadze and Genscher held their own talks before joining Gorbachev and Kohl. The Soviets also have pressed for a neutral Germany in the event the two states are united _ a condition rejected by Bonn as well as NATO. While Soviet approval and that of the other victor powers would be needed to transfer control of Berlin to a united Germany, the Kremlin has little clout in determining the political shape of the reunited state. Last year's pro-democracy uprisings throughout Eastern Europe have weakened the economic and defense bonds with the once-dominant Soviet Union, and the potential loss of East Germany would deal the Kremlin its most harmful blow. Two-thirds of the Soviets' 575,000 European-based troops are deployed in East Germany, which is also the most important allied trading partner for the economically troubled Soviets. Kohl returns to Bonn for meetings with East German Premier Hans Modrow on Tuesday and Wednesday, when the West Germans' plans for economic integration with East Germany will again be the primary topic of discussion. Kohl will see French President Francois Mitterrand after his talks with Modrow, then travel to Camp David to meet with President Bush. East Germans on March 18 vote in their first-ever free elections, and Kohl has said he will negotiate the details of reunification only with the new, elected leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Asks Soviet Union to Halt Jewish Emigration to Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Kuwait's emir and Oman's sultan meeting to discuss emigration, ADD 5 grafs at end of story; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Jordan has asked the Soviet Union to halt Jewish emigration to Israel until the Palestinian issue is resolved, Prime Minister Mudar Badran said Saturday. Badran, speaking to The Associated Press during a break in a Parliament session, said Jordan ``made it clear that if this immigration was to be to the Israeli-occupied territories, it means that we started practical steps toward crushing all future peace chances.'' He did not say how the Jordanian request to the Soviet Union was made. Israeli officials have said they expect 300,000 Soviet Jews to immigrate to Israel over the next few years. Israel's prime minister, Yitzhak Shamir, aroused anger in Arab countries two weeks ago when he said Israel should hold onto the West Bank and Gaza Strip to handle an influx of immigrants. Palestinians are fighting for their own state in the territories, which Israel captured from Egypt and Jordan in the 1967 Middle East War. Badran praised a recent Soviet proposal to discuss such emigration before the U.N. Security Council. ``We welcome such a move,'' he said. But he criticized Israeli efforts to open direct flights from the Soviet Union to Israel _ a plan that has been stalled due to the controversy over immigration to the occupied territories. ``This is a roadblock in the way of peace. The whole idea of the Jewish exodus is a roadblock ... and it will not achieve any steps toward a settlement,'' Badran said. The premier repeated a call for an Arab delegation to tour the United States, the Soviet Union and East European countries ``to explain the dangers of the Soviet Jewish exodus for the Middle East peace process.'' Information Minister Ibrahim Izzeddine said Jordan should urge the United States to ``announce that Israeli settlements would not be set up in the occupied territories and to cut all funds to Israel if it (Israel) wanted to finance those settlements there.'' Israel has appealed for foreign donations to help finance immigrant settlement. But U.S. officials have said no American government funds can be used for settlements in the territories. About half of Jordan's 3.1 million people come from Palestinian families who fled their homes during Arab-Israeli wars. Jordanian officials say they fear Israel will again expel hundreds of thousands of Palestinians from the occupied territories to make way for the immigrants. In Oman, the emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, arrived in Muscat on Saturday for three days of consultations with Oman's Sultan Qaboos. Official sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel was one of the top issues for their talks. Qaboos is the chairman of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, which also includes Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. Jaber is the chairman of the 46-member Organization of Islamic Conference, an umbrella organization for the world's estimated 1 billion Moslems. In a recent message, he castigated the Soviet Union and the United States for allowing the Jewish immigration to Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Police Briefly Arrest Six During Demonstration After Mass
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Police on Saturday dispersed an anti-government demonstration and briefly held five protesters and a journalist following a Mass celebrating the recent release of political prisoners. The military government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril on Wednesday declared a general amnesty, released 19 political prisoners and reiterated promises to hold elections scheduled for October. About 100 protesters chanting ``Down with Avril!'' began to demonstrate at noon after attending the special Mass, celebrated at the capital's Christ-Roi Church. They were dispersed about a half-mile from the church. The six people who were arrested were released three hours later, said independent Radio Haiti Inter. One of the arrested protesters was severely beaten before being taken to police headquarters, it said. No other injuries were reported. Willy Paul, a journalist for Radio Cacique, was arrested in a house where he had taken refuge when police began breaking up the protest, the station's director, Patrick Delansheer, told The Associated Press. ``Willy was only covering the event, he was not a participant. But the number of assaults on our station and personnel are countless,'' Delansheer said. In early January, unidentified gunmen assassinated popular Radio Cacique satirist Jean-Andre Destin, an outspoken critic of Avril. The Mass was attended by about 500 people, including many of those released Wednesday. One of them, Evans Paul, who according to witnesses was severely beaten while in jail, demanded his ``torturers'' be tried. ``After I lost consciousness, they brought me around by sticking an ignited lighter up my nostril,'' Paul, leaning on a crutch, said of his treatment by Presidential Guardsmen on the day of his arrest in November. The amnesty came a week after Avril lifted a nine-day state of siege declared after an army colonel was assassinated. During the crackdown more than 50 activists were arrested, beaten, and later released, activists and witnesses said. Seven prominent leaders were also forced into exile, but Avril later said they could return. Most have refused, saying free elections are impossible under Avril.

DOC.HEAD: Mother of Dead Twins Say Trouble Their Way of Life
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old told his twin brother that they would not be taken alive during a standoff in which they held a sheriff hostage in a courthouse before they died in a murder-suicide. In a tape recording made by one of the brothers during the last few minutes of the standoff and played by authorities at a news conference Saturday, Brad Jordan is heard making the comment to his brother, Chad. ``They can come in and barge in or whatever they want. I'm going to pull that trigger before anybody gets a chance,'' Brad Jordan said. His words were followed by screams and the sound of two gunshots. At one point, the twins had demanded an oxygen tank and tried to use it to create a diversion to help them escape, County Prosecutor James Mayer said. ``The purpose for the oxygen tank (was) they wanted to fashion a homemade bomb out of a tank that the emergency squad brought along with them,'' he said. ``I guess it was their intention to throw that out in the hall and distract the officers in the hall and try to shoot their way out of jail.'' In a separate interview Saturday, the twins' mother said they had been in and out of trouble all their lives. Sandra Teeters spoke with her sons by telephone during their seven-hour standoff Friday at the Richland County Courthouse, where the two had been taken for questioning about a string of recent burglaries. ``All they said to me was they wanted out. They said they either wanted freedom or they were going out in body bags,'' she said in an interview. Sheriff's Deputy Deb Strine was questioning the twins, Chad and Brad Jordan, when they overpowered her, took her 9mm pistol, locked themselves in a suite of offices and held her hostage. Sheriff Dale Shetler later exchanged himself for Ms. Strine. The standoff ended when Brad Jordan killed his brother, then turned the weapon on himself. Shetler was uninjured. Mrs. Teeters said the twins, the youngest of her seven children, had been problems since they were in kindergarten. ``It was just little things. They kicked their teachers. They actually got put out of kindergarten,'' she said. ``It just kept going that way. Mostly, though, they were just hyper and never really hurt anyone. They always wanted attention.'' The brothers were charged in a recent string of burglaries in north-central and northeast Ohio. They were arrested in January after a clerk at a convenience store triggered a silent alarm during a robbery. Authorities said the burglaries began after the twins were released last fall from juvenile custody. Mrs. Teeters said she had sought professional help for the twins and had nothing to show for it but doctor bills. ``What all the doctors have told me. ... They just pass it off as them being premature babies. You figure it out,'' she said. Mrs. Teeters said the county Children Services Board took custody of the twins when they were 13 or 14, mostly because they were runaways, and placed them in a succession of mental and juvenile-detention centers.

DOC.HEAD: Capitol Hill Hails Release of Mandela and Urges Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 new grafs after 18th graf pvs, ````Just because ... to UPDATE with Lewis quotes; pick up 19th graf pvs: ``Randall Robinson ...
DOC.TEXT: Senators of both parties on Saturday hailed the plan to free black leader Nelson Mandela from a South African prison and called on both sides in that strife-torn nation to begin meaningful negotiations. ``It's the right move,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said. ``Now comes the real test for South Africa _ will there be peace as meaningful negotiations move forward? Let's hope so.'' The comment came in a statement released by Dole's office after South African President F.W. de Klerk announced that the African National Congress leader would be freed Sunday after 27 years. De Klerk also said the state of emergency under which freedoms have been suspended in South Africa could be lifted within weeks if conditions of stability prevail across the country following Mandela's release. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., chief Senate sponsor of legislation to impose sanctions on South Africa, said in a statement that ``freedom for Nelson Mandela means that freedom is closer for all the people of South Africa.'' ``His unjust imprisonment has long been the symbol of the cruelty and injustice of the racist system of apartheid.'' Kennedy said. He expressed hope that ``today's historic development marks the beginning of a genuine commitment by President de Klerk and his government to dismantle all aspects of apartheid as soon as possible.'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said in a telephone interview that the release of Mandela along with de Klerk's other remarks were ``welcome and significant.'' ``It is significant because without this there could be no real negotiations and when you couple this with President de Klerk's statement that within a few weeks he's going to completely lift the state of emergency, you have the conditions for a successful resolution of all this,'' he said. Sanctions against South Africa imposed by the United States and European countries were credited in large part for the change in course on the part of the South African government. The U.S. sanctions, imposed in 1986, barred new American investment in South Africa, including bank loans to the government; prohibited the import of South African iron, steel, coal, uranium and agricultural products, including sugar; prevented the United States from exporting computers to South Africa; banned all nuclear trade; and halted landings by South African Airways. The chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., said that the United States ``should continue to use the moral and economic lever of even more stringent sanctions as a vehicle for helping to accelerate and expedite the end of apartheid in a nonviolent context.'' ``While I welcome the release of Nelson Mandela from almost three decades of imprisonment for his political beliefs, I am concerned that no mention has been made about the release of more than 2,000 other black South Africans still in prison because of their struggle to end apartheid,'' Dellums said. Rep. Connie Morella, R-Md., who recently traveled to South Africa, issued a statement calling the release of Mandela ``a major step forward for President de Klerk'' and ``one indication that the winds of democracy that have swept across Europe may be reaching South Africa.'' ``However, before sanctions are relaxed or eliminated, several additional steps must be taken,'' she said. ``These include release of the many remaining political prisoners, lifting of the state of emergency and removal of troops from the townships.'' New York Mayor David N. Dinkins said Mandela ``could have been released a long time ago if he had compromised his principles.'' ``He is an inspiration to all those seeking freedom who will not compromise and I look forward to his unconditional release and the day all South Africans will be free,'' Dinkins said. ``Just because we freed one man doesn't mean we freed an entire nation,'' said Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., the House majority whip and author of legislation imposing U.S. sanctions against South Africa. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., said Mandela's release marked ``a significant step'' toward peaceful political change in the country. However, Lewis, a former activist in the U.S. civil rights movement, also urged political leaders here to ``continue to apply pressure on the South Africa government in the form of economic sanctions.'' Randall Robinson, leader of the Washington-based anti-apartheid group TransAfrica, said pressure from the United States and Europe produced the release of Mandela. He described it as a ``tiny step.'' ``Political prisoners must still be released, parliament must repeal apartheid laws and until these things are done it is too early to evaluate the good faith of President de Klerk,'' he said. ``This is only the release of one great man,'' he said. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. and a leading conservative, was not planning a comment on the development, an aide said. Dole was the only Republican with a comment despite calls to spokesmen for several prominent GOP members of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Report Accuses Iraq of Brutal Human Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group said in a report published Sunday that Iraq uses torture and execution to silence the opposition, and it called on the United States to impose sanctions to end the alleged practices. Middle East Watch, a branch of the New York-based Human Rights Watch, said Iraqis face ``forced relocation and deportation, arbitrary arrest and detention, torture, disappearance and summary and political execution.'' ``There is no meaningful legal recourse in Iraq against these abuses,'' it said. ``Large numbers of persons have unquestionably died under torture in Iraq over the past two decades,'' Middle East Watch said. It did not give specific figures. President Saddam Hussein was quoted last month by visiting Arab legislators as saying that Iraq soon will have a new constitution that will provide for greater press freedom and allow the formation of new political parties. Middle East Watch said its report is based on interviews with Iraqis, government and intelligence officials, scholars, journalists and other reports. It said its investigators were not allowed to visit Iraq. The investigators said that an extraordinary cult of personality around Saddam is part of the repressive system. Saddam is president of the all-powerful Revolutionary Command Council and secretary-general of the ruling Baath Socialist Party, as well as president and prime minister. ``According to emigre testimony, even spilling coffee on the picture of Saddam Hussein that appears daily on the front page of the newspapers has been known to lead to arrest and interrogation,'' the report said. It repeated charges _ confirmed by the United Nations and the United States _ that Iraq used chemical weapons against its rebellious Kurdish population in 1988. Iraq also razed thousands of villages to relocate Kurds and create a 19-mile-wide buffer zone along 750 miles of border with Iran and Turkey, the report noted. At least 500,000 of Iraq's 3.5 million Kurds were forcibly dislocated, it said. The report accused presidents Bush and Ronald Reagan of putting ``the nurturing of newly friendly relations with Saddam Hussein's government well ahead of the violent and repressive nature of his regime.'' Washington is reluctant to risk a break with Baghdad because of ``Iraq's enormous oil wealth ... and the prospect of lucrative trade,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Emerging Chemical Weapons Accord Caps Talks in Moscow Amid Political Turmoil
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 32nd graf, ``Then, meeting xxx to CORRECT by deleting reference to Ceauscecu years in connection with Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT:
An emerging chemical weapons accord and significant progress on arms control marked a mostly successful marathon negotiating mission here by Secretary of State James A. Baker III that wound up Saturday with an unprecedented live debate with Soviet legislators. The net result before Baker flew off to Sofia for talks with government and opposition forces in Bulgaria, an East European country in a rocky transition from hard line communism, is that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev can anticipate signing possibly two accords to curb chemical and nuclear weapons when they meet at the summit in Washington in June. In an exceptionally glowing joint statement issued before Baker's departure, the superpowers stressed that while ``certain significant differences'' remain between them, the relationship ``is increasingly marked by understanding, cooperation and the search for mutual advantage.'' The evidence was striking during the four days of talks Baker held with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and a long session Friday with Gorbachev, who was still savoring his historic victory within the Communist Party. At Gorbachev's behest, the Central Committee agreed to revoke the party's monopoly on political power and set the stage for political competition that might have Gorbachev running for re-election as president. Surprisingly, Gorbachev told reporters ``let's wait and see'' when they asked whether he would make such a race as a communist. The most significant result of the negotiations was an unexpected breakthrough on sea-launched cruise missiles, the most difficult in a handful of knotty problems standing in the way of a treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 percent to 50 percent. Baker and the Soviets agreed to take the cruise missiles out of the strategic weapons treaty that the two sides hope to sign at the June summit meeting. Instead, the cruise missiles will be dealt with in a separate side statement that evidently will not be submitted along with the treaty to the Senate for ratification. For the first time, Baker openly acknowledged there is no sure way to verify how many of the weapons carried by submarines and surface fighting ships the other side has on board. He did not disclose what the statements would contain, but separating the issue from the treaty is likely to improve the prospects for a June signing ceremony at the White House. After years of hand-wringing and stop-start negotiating efforts, meanwhile, Baker and the Soviets worked out a formula for destroying U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons stocks. The emerging agreement, also slated for a summit signing, provides for substantial reductions over eight years in stocks of U.S. and Soviet poison gas, to be followed by the elimination of all chemical weapons _ provided that dozens of other nations negotiating in Geneva agree to abolish their stockpiles as well. The outcome was a diplomatic triumph for the Bush administration. When the president advanced his proposal last year, the Soviets questioned the U.S. determination to retain 2 percent of the deadly weapons until all nations capable of producing them signed the international accord. The joint statement indicated the Soviets had accepted Bush's formula. There also was marked progress toward a third arms control agreement. Gorbachev countered Bush's State of the Union proposal for a ceiling of 195,000 U.S. and Soviet Troops in Central Europe with a suggestion that the ceiling be extended to superpower forces on foreign soil throughout Europe. This would mean withdrawing the 30,000 American soldiers that Bush's initiative would leave in Britain, Greece, Italy, Spain and Turkey. Alternatively, Gorbachev said, he would go along with Bush's overall European ceiling of 225,000 troops. This would give the Soviets leeway to have 225,000 soldiers in Central Europe, where most of the Red Army is based. Baker called Gorbachev's approach ``very close to the president's proposal,'' but delayed a response until he meets with the foreign ministers of the 15 North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies in Ottawa, Canada, on Monday and Tuesday. Even on a technical level, the U.S. Arms control agenda moved ahead. Agreement was reached for a full disclosure of data from strategic missile tests and to set a ceiling on U.S. and Soviet land-based mobile missiles that will be kept in storage under the emerging strategic weapons limitation treaty. Also, the two sides decided on limiting the cruise missiles carried by their bombers, but could not agree on how to restrict the range of the missiles carried on the bombers. On the other hand, Baker clashed with the Soviets over the ongoing delivery of late-model MiG-29 fighter bombers to Cuba. He acknowledged he could not persuade Gorbachev and Shevardnadze to keep the weapons out of President Fidel Castro's hands. Baker concluded his visit with a 90-minute appearance before the International Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet. He is the first U.S. official to appear before the legislative body, an event he attributed to Gorbachev's policy of openness.
Baker then flew to Sofia for separate meetings with government and opposition leaders. He has criticized the country for the slow pace of its reform, but Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov told reporters ``We are prepared to accept, without any hesitation, the wishes of the people.'' Lukanov appealed an expansion of U.S. trade, which now consists primarily of Bulgaria shipping wine and tobacco to the United States in exchange for grain . Lukanov said the government was ``open for a dialogue with all political forces, I mean it.'' Baker met first with the government leaders and urged them to conduct a ``free and fair'' election, a senior U.S. official said. He also stressed the importance of not forcing the assimilation of ethnic Turks, who past regimes were charged compelling to adopt Bulgarian names and to abandon their cultural and Moslem religious practices. The official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said Baker stressed that ``the credibility of the government depends'' on how the elections are carried out. Then, meeting with 17 members of the Union of Democratic Forces, an opposition coalition, Baker heard stories of political imprisonment in prior years and difficulty in preparing for the election because of newsprint shortages and problems in getting organizing throughout the country. ``You can win if you stay united.'' Baker said. He told reporters later the administration was ``reserving judgment'' in the contest. On Sunday, Baker flies to Bucharest for a slightly longer than four-hour visit to the Romanian capital. In his appearance before the Soviet legislators, Baker spoke from a podium with a marble bust of Lenin peering over his shoulder and borrowed the title of the Arthur Koestler novel in recalling the ``Darkness at Noon'' that preceded Gorbachev's rise to power in 1985. ``Today, we see reason return,'' Baker said. ``Today, I come before the founding fathers of a new Soviet Union ... a new Soviet Union you are building.'' But he then lectured the Soviets against spending badly needed resources supporting Marxist governments in Cuba, Nicaragua, Angola and Cambodia. Baker contrasted that activity with Gorbachev's policy of non-interference in Europe, where the Soviet leader's actions ``have played a vital role in supporting the creation of legitimate governments.'' On the other hand, Baker said, ``We remain especially disturbed by the military shipments your government continues to send to those seeking military solutions to conflicts in regions vital to us.'' He added: ``This is even less comprehensible when it happens at a time when your people clearly need those scarce resources put to good use at home.'' Several of the legislators responded in a question-and-answer session with attacks on the Bush administration's refusal to engage in naval disarmament talks and to halt nuclear weapons tests. They also criticized the invasion of Panama. Gen. Sergei Akhromeyev, Gorbachev's military adviser, questioned the modest reductions in U.S. military spending in contrast to what he said was a 14 percent slash in Soviet spending, and he said the United States had not dismantled dozens of military bases that have surrounded the Soviet Union for 45 years. Baker defended the Panama invasion as a unique U.S. use of force to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, whom Baker called a ``thug.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead as Storms Rake Georgia, Carolinas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with California traffic accidents attributed to fog, and with additional power outages. Picks up 13th graf pvs: `At least ... .' ADDS 2 grafs with conditions elsewhere in nation. No pick up. This STANDS for AM-Weatherpage Weather.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TUS1,2
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms slashed through parts of the Southeast with tornadoes and high winds overnight and early Saturday, killing four people, injuring dozens, knocking out power to thousands and damaging buildings and automobiles. In the Atlanta area, two people died Saturday morning when trees fell into their bedrooms, and a woman in north-central Louisiana was killed Friday night when a wind gust flung her mobile home 30 feet, authorities said. ``We had a band of severe storms that developed over northeast Texas and spread eastward during the afternoon,'' said Ernest Ethridge of the National Weather Service. ``We've had rainfall across the area of 4 to 14 inches.'' Meanwhile, dense fog may have contributed to two serious automobile accidents, including a head-on collision near Palo Alto, Calif., leaving left four people injured, three severely, the California Highway Patrol said. The thunderstorm line, moving east overnight, brought reports of tornado touchdowns in Louisiana, Georgia, Florida and the Carolinas, and high winds at one point knocked out power to 112,000 utility customers in Alabama and 300,000 in Georgia. Ethridge said winds up to 50 mph knocked down trees, and pea- to golfball-size hail knocked out windows in buildings and cars in northern Louisiana. In Calhoun, La., Shirley Robinson, 47, died and her 5-year-old grandson Darrell Robinson suffered minor injuries Friday night when the gust flipped her trailer home almost 30 feet, Ouachita Parish sheriff's deputies said. The storm knocked out power to about 10,000 Louisiana Power & Light Co. customers, and the blackout continued into Saturday morning for about 2,100 in Sterlington, said LP&L district manager Bill Turnbough. Georgia authorities said Elizabeth Stevens, 72, of Norcross died when a 3-foot-thick pine tree fell into her bedroom, and Mantrell Crowley, a 10-year-old boy was killed by a tree that fell on his bedroom in southwest Atlanta. In Henry County, south of Atlanta, Thomas A. Henderson, 69, was killed shortly after 6 a.m. when he was crushed by a tree as he stood near his mailbox, according to county Coroner Ronnie Stewart. By midafternoon, repair crews had restored power to 200,000 customers in metropolitan Atlanta, but isolated areas could be blacked out until Sunday, said Georgia Power Co. spokesman Trip Cagle. Alabama Power Co. estimated 112,000 homes and business without electricity in the southern two-thirds of the state, and called in repair crews from Mississippi and Florida, said company spokesman Mike Casey. The worst outages were in Montgomery, where 27,500 were out, and in the Birmingham area, where 25,000 were in the dark. The company reported 16,000 customers without power in the Anniston, Talladega and Sylacauga area, plus 3,250 in the Phenix City area. At least 24 people were injured, two of them seriously, in Alabama's Talladega County, and Sheriff Jerry Studdard said at least 15 mobile homes were demolished. National Guard troops cleared fallen trees that closed U.S. 280. The storms brought gusts of more than 80 mph in Atlanta and Macon, with tornadoes damaging structures in Columbus, Americus and other parts of northeastern Georgia. Columbus police Maj. Ross McCain said tornadoes touched down in the central and east portions of that city, inflicting substantial damage to buildings, but no injuries were reported. In Americus, authorities said a tornado touched down about 6:30 a.m., ripping the roof off a convenience store and flinging it 150 yards to land atop a house, where a man sleeping inside was injured slightly. ``I was getting up to go to work when the rain started and I looked out the window and saw the tornado,'' said Thomas Griffin, a resident. ``Then I saw the store when it started falling apart.'' In Douglas County, west of Atlanta, a wind storm slammed into a trailer park north of Interstate 20, overturning at least two mobile homes and triggering three fires, said Assistant Fire Chief Stewart Haas. Guy West, chief deputy sheriff in Upson County in west central Georgia, said emergency workers rescued a woman and child who were trapped in their mobile home after it was overturned by high wind about 6 a.m. In Gwinnett County, two large stores sustained serious damage but police were reporting no injuries. The storm line advanced into the Carolinas, bringing tornadoes and slashing winds early Saturday to western North Carolina and northwestern South Carolina, where two people received minor injuries. At least one tornado touched down in western North Carolina's Cleveland County, said sheriff's deputy Mike Branch. ``Several mobile homes were destroyed, also some houses with carports blown off and lots of trees were blown down onto the houses. There's also a lot of barns and outhouses that were destroyed,'' Branch said. A twister also touched down Saturday in the Florida Panhandle city of Milton, damaging 50 to 60 homes, but causing no injuries, officials said. Mississippi authorities said winds gusting up to 60 mph late Friday and early Saturday blew out windows and ripped off roofs in central and southeast parts of the state, but there were no injuries reported. Rainshowers which pelted the Northeast earlier Saturday moved out to sea by nightfall, while snow in northern Maine diminished to flurries. Heavy rain in the northern Pacific Coast region also began to to dissipate, as winds gusted in parts of the Northwest. A high wind warning was in effect for some of the higher elevations of southeastern Wyoming Saturday night, and through Sunday for along the front range of the Rockies in Montana.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Democrats Without U.S. Senate Contender
DOC.TEXT: Virginia Democratic leaders said Saturday they have no candidate to oppose U.S. Sen. John W. Warner after they spurned a supporter of political extremist Lyndon LaRouche who offered to run as a Democrat. Paul Goldman, chairman of the state Democratic Party and a close adviser to Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, said no Democrat has expressed an interest in running against Warner and the party will not hold a state convention this year unless someone steps forward by March 15. Warner, 62, is in his second term and is the highest ranking Republican on the powerful Armed Services Committee. ``No one says he's doing a fine job,'' Goldman said after about 100 Democratic leaders gathered at the Marriott Hotel for a Democratic State Central Committee meeting. ``I'd love to have a candidate to run against him.'' The meeting was interrupted briefly by several supporters of LaRouche, a former fringe presidential candidate sentenced to 15 years in prison for conspiracy and mail fraud. Nancy Spannaus, a LaRouche supporter who wants to run against Warner as a Democrat, was prevented from speaking at the meeting. ``I have a Democratic program,'' Ms. Spannaus said as party regulars shouted ``no'' and ``get her out of here.'' Alan Ogden, a LaRouche activist, accused the Democrats of tacitly supporting Warner and President Bush by refusing to run a candidate. ``This is not the Communist Party,'' Ogden shouted. Ogden was escorted from the meeting by hotel employees. State Central Committee members adopted rules that would make it virtually impossible for Ms. Spannaus to win the Democratic nomination. Under the rules, any candidate who wants to run must win the support of 20 percent of the delegates picked at local caucus meetings for a convention to be held. Caucuses are to be held in the spring. Goldman said a convention would be held June 9 if a credible candidate steps forward. ``We're not going to foreclose anything at this juncture,'' he said. Goldman said ``a strong current of pragmatism'' among party members has made them reluctant to run a token candidate against Warner. ``If someone just wants to run for the exercise, they ought to enter their local marathon,'' he said. ``That's the sentiment I'm finding.'' It would be the first time this century that state Democrats have not run a Senate candidate. Last year, the party swept the top three state offices in an election that made Wilder the nation's first elected black governor. The Democrats' strongest candidate would have been former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles, but he said last year he did not want to run. Warner announced his re-election bid Monday. He said Saturday he plans to campaign regardless of Democratic plans. ``If the Democratic Party elects not to endorse a candidate, I will accept that decision with humility,'' Warner said.

DOC.HEAD: Sit-Ins Continue at Selma Schools, Protesters March to Mayor's House
DOC.TEXT: About 600 blacks marched to the mayor's house Saturday and demonstrators continued sit-ins at Selma High School and City Hall to protest alleged police brutality and a black school superintendent's dismissal. Protesters had planned to walk from a Selma church to the Edmund Pettus Bridge, a landmark in the civil rights movement of 25 years ago, but organizers postponed that walk until Sunday. The protests have kept all of Selma schools closed since Wednesday. Sit-ins have been held at the high school and City Hall since Thursday. City attorneys Friday asked U.S. District Judge Charles Butler of Mobile to issue a temporary restraining order against the sit-ins. Butler scheduled a telephone conference with attorneys for Monday, when schools were scheduled to reopen. The protesters' lawyer, J.L. Chestnut, said the judge ``told me he recognized constitutional rights to exercise free speech and was reluctant for the federal courts to step in but that he was also duty-bound to deal with any excesses.'' Protesters said they would not give up. Marchers were led to Mayor Joe Smitherman's home by the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. The marchers prayed for the white mayor, whose tenure stretches back to 1965. Smitherman did not appear for marchers, who walked on to the home of a black county commissioner and a shopping center. Police made no arrests during the march or Saturday's round of sit-ins. ``We are wrapped in a sacred flag of history today,'' Lowery said at the start of the march. The racial turmoil began when six white members of the school board voted last week against extending the contract of Norward Roussell, the city's first black superintendent. That ignited protests leading to the closing of two schools Tuesday and all 11 of Selma's public schools Wednesday. Roussell was reinstated after the initial protests. But students and other protesters want the school board to extend his contract, which expires this year. Four blacks protesting the dismissal of Roussell were arrested Monday during a melee at Smitherman's office. Rose Sanders, a Selma attorney, said she was the victim of police brutality during the melee. A preliminary city report said allegations of police brutality at the protest were unfounded. Lowery told marchers Saturday: ``The issue here, while we have to deal with police brutality ... is unequal education. We must bring down the walls of unequal education in the `90s as we brought down the walls of disenfranchisement in the `60s.''

DOC.HEAD: Landowner Convicted of Killing Farm Workers' Leader
DOC.TEXT: A wealthy landowner was convicted and sentenced to 30 years in prison Saturday for killing a farm workers' leader he blamed for disputes over his property in a southern state. The Chiapas state court said in a statement that Roberto Zenteno Rojas was guilty of the December 1988 shooting of Sebastian Perez Nunez, a former state legislator who led the Independent Center of Agricultural Workers and Campesinos. Zenteno blamed Perez Nunez for disputes over his land. Peasants had been occupying 120 acres of Zenteno's 740-acre ranch since August 1988, demanding it be turned over to them. Under Mexico's agrarian reform law, which has given land to millions of landless peasants, the government may take over land holdings that are larger than legal limits or left idle and turn them into ejidos, a type of communal farm. Personal disputes and vendettas over land rights are common in Chiapas, Mexico's southernmost state bordering Guatemala, where hundreds of peasants have been killed in recent years over such disputes. Witnesses said Zenteno shot Perez Nunez 13 times on Dec. 29, 1988, as he waited in a pickup truck to buy gas. The driver, Julio Cesar Morales, also was wounded, but his wife and Perez Nunez's wife, Manuela, were unhurt. Zenteno fled after the shooting but surrendered to authorities on Aug. 30, 1989. Marcelino Nunez, Perez Nunez's successor in the worker's organization, said after the conviction that his organization trusted the criminal justice system, but that he was skill skeptical about the government's commitment to carrying out land reform. ``Roberto Zenteno had a lot of money, not only him, but all of the big landowners who came to his defense,'' Nunez said. Perez Nunez' widow and the family of Zenteno could not be reached immediately for comment on the conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Failed Gubernatorial Candidate Courter Changes Position on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. James Courter, a longtime abortion opponent who lost the New Jersey governor's race last year, has changed his mind and supports a woman's right to abortion, a spokesman said Saturday. ``As excruciating as it is for an individual that's trying to make up her mind, that's how excrutiating it was for him,'' said Bob Friant, a legislative aide. ``It's not easy to stand up and say, `Hey, I'm changing my mind.''' Courter, who was soundly defeated by Gov. Jim Florio in the November election, began the campaign assuring voters he would ``continue my pro-life'' efforts and oppose abortion except in the case of rape, incest or a threat to the mother's life. Later, as it became apparent New Jerseyites widely favored a pro-choice position, he softened his stance and said he would do nothing to restrict women's right to abortions. The day after his loss to Florio, Courter said he would reconsider his position on abortion. ``He is now stating he will vote pro-choice on all relevant legislation,'' Friant said.
