Although Courter remains personally opposed to abortion, Friant said, he has concluded government should not make personal, moral or religious decisions for people. ``When he was running for governor he was exposed to a lot of individuals ... who asked him to reconsider his position and made some very persuasive arguments,'' Friant said. ``He began to realize that perhaps this is not a decision that government should impose on women.'' ``We're glad to be able to count him in the pro-choice side,'' said Fran Avallone, state coordinator of Right to Choose. ``I think the election in New Jersey made it clear to a lot of people that the pro-choice position is the majority position.'' Emma Byrne, Florio's spokeswoman, said the governor had no comment on the report. Richard Traynor, president of the New Jersey Right to Life Committee, said Courter's new position was consistent with his ``back-peddling'' during the campaign. The committee initially backed Courter but withdrew its support. Courter, who represents the 12th Congressional District, is running for re-election but doubts abortion will be a major issue in the campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed, Three Wounded In New Mexico Bowling Alley Shooting Spree
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with descriptions of suspects, details about roadblocks and hunt for men, ages of survivors and reasons for withholding their identity; to CORRECT youngest victim's age to 2, sted 3, and to CORRECT that it was little girl who was found alive. Picks up 8th graf pvs: `The police ...' ^By SUZANNE GAMBOA
DOC.TEXT: Robbers shot seven people in a bowling alley office Saturday, killing a man, his two young daughters, and another girl before setting a fire to try to cover up the crime, police said. ``What we have here is a very vicious crime, the assassination of kids,'' said Las Cruces police Capt. Fred Rubio. ``A whole family was assassinated.'' The three survivors and residents living near the Las Cruces Bowl lanes gave police a description of two men believed to have committed the robbery and shootings. Rubio said officers were looking for two Hispanic men, one described as about 5-foot-11 with short, kinky hair and in his 30s; the other as 5-foot-6, dark, heavyset and in his late 40s or early 50s. Officers were manning 10 roadblocks into and out of this city of about 55,000 people, located 45 miles north of the Mexico border. A helicopter was being used and 80 percent of the police department's criminal investigation staff was working on the case, Rubio said. Rubio identified the dead as Steve Turan, a bowling alley worker believed to be in his 30s, and daughters Paula Turan, 7, and Victoria Turan, 2, and another girl, Amy Houser, 13. He said Victoria was alive when the victims were found, but was pronounced dead on arrival at Memorial General Hospital. The three survivors were taken to the hospital where they were in critical condition, Rubio said. He refused to release their names, citing security reasons and concern for their safety. He said one was 12, one was 30 and the third was in his or her 30s. The police captain said a fire was reported at the bowling alley at 8:33 a.m., a half-hour after it opened. Firefighters found the seven victims in the office. ``According to our preliminary investigation, they were rounded up and taken into that particular office,'' Rubio said. ``They were concentrated in one area and shot in one area.'' The robbers then started a fire in the office. ``It appears it was to cover up the crime scene,'' he said. Rubio said the apparent motive was robbery, ``and apparently they decided to rid themselves of any witnesses.'' ``You're talking about a 3-year-old. What could a 3-year-old testify to? This is why I say it's the worst,'' he said. Police did not disclose the amount of money taken, but Rubio said: ``What makes it even worse, is not only the amount of people who were shot for the amount of money taken ... if you start adding up all these ages you're going to come up with 100 years of life that was just gone by some ignorant people that did this.'' Authorities said junior league games for youngsters had been scheduled to start at the bowling alley at 9 a.m.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Troops Enter Thailand While Attacking Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Burmese troops crossed into Thailand while launching intense attacks on a rebel camp inside Burma and nine soldiers were killed, Thai border patrol police said Saturday. The Burmese have failed to capture the Karen rebels' base, Kaw Moo Ra, after four days of stepped up fighting that has included intense mortar and rocket barrages, said police officers who requested anonymity. The Karen are among a dozen ethnic minorities fighting Burma's military government for greater autonomy. In recent months, Burmese troops have overrun a string of Karen bases along the frontier. About 200 Burmese troops crossed the Moei River, which marks the frontier, and entered Wang Kaew village Friday to attack Kaw Moo Ra from the Thai side of the border, according to the police in nearby Mae Sot, 250 miles northwest of the capital, Bangkok, and 140 miles east of the Burmese capital, Rangoon. The Burmese withdrew from the village Saturday after warnings from the Thai military in the area. They left the bodies of nine of their soldiers. Thai police said they took into custody one wounded Burmese military officer. About 500 ethnic Karen civilians have fled into Thailand from the besieged rebel base. Fighting between Burmese troops and another rebel group of the Mon ethnic minority was reported continuing around Three Pagoda Pass, which Burma's troops overran late last week. Several thousand civilians from that border town also have fled into Thai territory. The government of Gen. Saw Maung put down a nationwide pro-democracy uprising nearly two years ago, killing hundreds of people. The resistance forces now include students who sought refuge in rebel camps following the crackdown. The Karens, one of the largest of the diverse ethnic groups fighting the Burmese government, have resisted the integration of their Karen state into the Union of Burma since Rangoon gained independence from Britain in 1948.

DOC.HEAD: Sightseeing Helicopter Crashes, Survivors Pulled From East River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-5, `Eight people ...' to UPDATE with 10 more people taken to hospital, their conditions. Pick up 6th graf, `Police said ...' INSERTS 2 grafs after 14th, `The National ...' to UPDATE with hometowns of pilot and passengers; SUBS 15th graf, `It was ...' to CORRECT Japanese businessman killed in 1988 crash, sted three years earlier.
DOC.TEXT: A sightseeing helicopter carrying four tourists and a pilot went down Saturday afternoon in the East River, bursting into flames after it crashed into the water near a helipad, police and witnesses said. Police divers and a rescuer in a yellow life raft went out to save the passengers and pilot, with some of the survivors holding onto a board extended by the boater until help arrived, witnesses said. Eighteen people were taken to the hospital, including a 14-year-old boy on the helicopter who was in critical condition after his heart stopped, said Lt. Joseph Apuzzo of Emergency Medical Services. Thirteen of the injured were rescuers who suffered exposure. The other crash survivors also suffered exposure, said hospital spokesman John Clark. All but the boy were expected to be released, he said. Police said the helicopter was taking off at the time of the accident about 3:15 p.m. Witnesses said the Bell Jet Ranger 206-L helicopter burst into flames after impact near the Manhattan helipad, though police said flames were visible before the helicopter touched water. After the people were pulled from the river, the copter turned upside down and sank and the flames quickly went out. ``When it hit the water, it blew up,'' said Adam Deutsch, 12, one of several children attending a bar mitzvah at the Water Club restaurant who saw the crash from about 60 feet away. ``Three or four people were trying to hang onto the helicopter.'' The restaurant is on the shore of the East River about two blocks south of the crash scene. ``We saw it take off. It started skidding on the water like it was ice skating,'' said 12-year-old Brooke Herman. ``The helicopter just crashed into the water.'' Six firefighters and two police officers were treated at the scene for exposure, Apuzzo said. Rescue efforts were aided by relatively calm water, although the National Weather Service said water temperatures were likely in the low 40s. Helicopters and an assortment of boats were brought in to pull people from the water. The helicopter was owned by Island Helicopter Corp., Deputy Police Chief Ron Johnson said. A woman who answered the telephone at Island Helicopter's office confirmed that the copter was one of Island's and said it had been taking off for a sightseeing trip around Manhattan when it crashed. The National Transportation Safety Board was investigating the crash, said Kathleen Bergen, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. She said the FAA was speaking for the NTSB under a local agreement. Police said the critically injured boy was from Long Island and his father, who also was on the helicopter, lived in New Jersey. The other two passengers on the helicopter were visitors from France and the pilot lives on Long Island resident, police said. It was the third time in the last five years that an Island helicopter coming into the East Side helipad had gone into the river. A May 2, 1988, crash of another sightseeing helicopter killed a Japanese businessman; three years earlier, a West German man died when a copter with eight people aboard went down. The accident occurred just two blocks from a helipad on the East River where sightseeing copters and a shuttle to Kennedy International Airport are based.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Executive of American Medical Association Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The chief executive of the American Medical Association resigned a year before he planned to retire amid revelations about money-losing deals involving AMA investments and two top staff members. ``I am convinced that the AMA should focus on the future now and not wait until I go as planned,'' Dr. James H. Sammons said in a news release the AMA issued Saturday. Sammons, 62, who is credited with guiding the association through hard financial times over 15 years, had his fiscal discretion curtailed two months ago by AMA trustees, who praised him on his departure. The board of trustees said at its interim annual meeting in Honolulu that Sammons had failed to follow routine fiscal policies in approving deals between himself and two staff members. In one deal, approved by Sammons in 1987, the AMA used pension-fund investments to reimburse one of the staffers $353,000 for his losses in the stock market crash. The officer resigned and has since paid back the money. Sammons turned in his resignation Friday, the AMA statement said. In another deal, approved by Sammons in 1989, the AMA lost $65,000 in a foreclosure settlement on a $267,710 loan it had given one of Sammons' assistants to buy a condominium. The deals were brought to light last fall by the Sun Times of Chicago, which published more details last week. The newspaper reported that the AMA lost $45,000 in the 1984 purchase of Sammons' suburban home and sale of the home a year later. The newspaper also described a similar deal in 1980 in which the AMA bought a home owned by Sammons' top deputy and later sold it at a loss of $23,000. The Washington State Medical Association subsequently called for Sammons to step aside during an investigation of AMA finances, which the board initiated in October. The Illinois State Medical Society made an official call for such a probe, and two other AMA affiliates asked that Sammons' powers be limited. AMA trustee Dr. Joseph Painter said Sammons increased the AMA's assets from $25 million to $193 million, helped increase membership by 100,000 to more than 270,000 and expansion the association's activities in such areas as medical publishing, education, science and disease prevention. The board Saturday named Dr. James S. Todd acting executive vice president to replace Sammons. Todd, a former chairman of the AMA board, has been the organization's senior deputy vice president for five years.

DOC.HEAD: Man Suffering From Amnesia Identified as Former Serviceman
DOC.TEXT: A man who didn't remember his past when found wandering in a parking lot by police four month ago was identified Saturday by people who said they were kin. They found him through a television news report. The man was identified by the people as Melvin Wolf, a 53-year-old former serviceman who had been living with his sister in Texas until August. ``There's no doubt that he's Melvin Wolf,'' said the sister, Donna Caskey of Angleton, Texas, after the meeting. ``The doctor said his memory will probably come back gradually.'' In October, the man was found with no identification and became known as John Doe. A therapist put him through hypnosis, which helped him remember pieces of his past, including a U.S. Army serial number. The number belongs to Melvin Wolf. Mrs. Caskey, her husband, Charlie, and their son, James, met the man and his therapist, Rick Selig, at the Topeka Psychiatric Clinic. She and other relatives had talked to him by telephone on Friday without spurring any recollections of his past, and Saturday's meeting again left him unable to remember. They called him Melvin, and said, ``Don't you remember me?'' They showed him various pictures and other family mementoes, and although Wolf said a few things seemed familiar, he was still unable to recall who he was. ``It's a little confusing to him,'' said James Caskey, 30. ``He said there's no doubt there's some connection with all the pictures and the things we've been telling him. But he doesn't know us.'' Saturday's reunion came after other relatives in Wisconsin had seen a story about him. Selig had developed information that there might be a Wisconsin connection, and reporter Russ Ptacek of Topeka's WIBW-TV called TV in that state on Thursday to encourage them to use a story he had done about the case. Ptacek said that minutes after his story was aired on WITI-TV in Milwaukee Thursday night, two people living in Wisconsin independently called the station and said they were relatives. Ptacek then called Selig and police to tell them of the developments. Topeka police said Saturday they were still investigating the case. They were still waiting on a fingerprint check. In recent sessions, Selig had Doe draw things under hypnosis, including a detailed sketch of what appeared to be a map. It had no meaning to anyone until Saturday, when Mrs. Caskey looked at it and said it was the layout of the farm in Wisconsin where she said they grew up. Mrs. Caskey said that Wolf had lived with her and her family in Angleton, where she said he owned an electronics repair store. She said he left home last Aug. 20 on a business trip to Washington, D.C., and never returned. Selig, a clinical social worker, said the man was diagnosed as suffering from psychogenic amnesia _ a total memory loss that he said can result from some ``extraordinarily stressful event.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Gordon and Stivender obituaries. No AMs separates have moved.
DOC.TEXT: James F. Gordon, a former federal judge who drafted a busing plan to desegregate Louisville schools 15 years ago, died Friday at age 71 of complications following lung surgery. A resident of Venice, Fla., for the last three years, Gordon died at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. Gordon became a senior judge with a reduced caseload in July 1976 and retired in January 1984, after 18 years on the bench. In 1973, as a U.S. district judge, Gordon dismissed a lawsuit against Jefferson County public schools by a coalition of civil-rights groups. But after an appeals court reversed his ruling and ordered that busing begin in September 1975, Gordon drafted a plan he later called the best in the country. He eventually said he had concluded that busing had helped blacks and whites know one another better.

David Stivender, chorus master of the Metropolitan Opera since 1973, died Friday in Pittsburgh of congestive heart failure at age 56. He had been a member of the Met's conducting staff since 1978. His responsibilities included preparing the chorus for a season that usually includes two dozen operas. He also selected singers from the approximately 300 who auditioned each year. Born in Milwaukee, he began studying the piano and became interested in opera at age 12. He studied composition at Northwestern University, and joined the Opera Arts Workshop in Atlanta in 1957. He became an assistant conductor at the Lyric Opera of Chicago in 1960 and conducted at the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, in 1963 and 1964. He wrote ``Mascagni,'' a 1988 book based on the composer's dictated memoirs and other writings, presented in autobiographical form.

William J. Truesdale, a retired vice president of the Greenville News-Piedmont Co., died at home Thursday at age 79. He joined the company's advertising department in 1942 and was made retail advertising manager five years later. He became advertising director in 1953, and in 1969 was named a vice president of the company, which publishes The Greenville News and Greenville Piedmont. Born in Elgin, Tuesdale was a former resident of Columbia, where he was associated with The State newspaper. He is survived by a daughter and son-in-law, two grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

Former President Reagan will give a videotaped deposition for John Poindexter's trial in his first in-depth questioning on the Iran-Contra affair since his two interviews with the Tower Commission. In those interviews conducted three years ago by the Reagan-appointed commission, Reagan said he couldn't remember when he had approved arms sales to Iran. Reagan on Friday consented to a videotaped deposition in which Poindexter's lawyers will ask him 154 questions, plus follow-up questions. The subject areas will include Reagan's knowledge of Oliver North's activities on behalf of the Contras and whether Reagan authorized written responses to Congress relating to the Nicaraguan rebels. Poindexter now faces felony charges in connection with those responses to Congress.

Sixteen days before the presidential election, the leftist government honored a pledge and freed nearly 1,000 Contra guerrillas and the last 39 jailed members of former President Anastasio Somoza's National Guard. President Daniel Ortega, who is running for re-election, proposed the pardon earlier this month. The pardon _ and the release Friday _ deprived his major opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, of a campaign issue for the Feb. 25 election. The release was witnessed by diplomats, four Contra commanders who have laid down their arms, international election observers and church and Red Cross representatives. The Sandinista government made the most of the ceremony, taking several busloads of reporters to the Juan Navarro Central Penitentiary, where the inmates stood in lines in front of the assembled dignitaries.

The resignation of a key official in President Bush's beleaguered savings-and-loan bureaucracy is worsening fears the government may be botching the selling of failed thrifts and their repossessed real estate. Daniel P. Kearney, chief staff officer of the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board, quit Friday after complaining the board wasn't giving him the authority he needed to do his job. The resignation is ``more evidence of the growing disarray in the Bush administration,'' said Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee. He predicted delay in dealing with failed S&Ls would increase the taxpayer cost of the bailout. Economist Paul Getman of Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said bureaucratic infighting is also heightening concern that a surplus of government-owned real estate will depress property prices in some areas.

The acquittal of reputed mob boss John Gotti on charges he ordered the shooting of a union official brought cheers in court and a celebration in the Queens neighborhood where the ``Dapper Don'' is king. Gotti, whom authorities say has been America's No. 1 organized crime boss since December 1985, won his third victory over government prosecutors Friday when a jury found him innocent of assault and conspiracy. His co-defendant, Anthony Guerrieri, was also acquitted. Gotti's supporters applauded loudly as the verdict was read, provoking Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin to threaten them with 30 days in jail if they didn't stop. After leaving court, he arrived at a favorite hangout in Manhattan's Little Italy and was cheered wildly by people waiting for him on the street. Near another Gotti hangout, the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club in the borough of Queens, residents decorated homes and stores with balloons and signs congratulating Gotti on his acquittal.

NASA's Galileo spacecraft snapped photographs of Venus today after zooming around the planet in a ``celestial billiard shot'' that sent the robot explorer toward its 1995 encounter with Jupiter. ``We have clearly achieved the sole objective of going to Venus: a trajectory that will help us ultimately reach Jupiter,'' said Bill O'Neil, Galileo science and mission design manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion laboratory. ``All systems have been operating perfectly.'' The 2.8-ton spacecraft made its closest approach to Venus at 9:59 p.m. PST Friday, passing 10,028 miles above the furnace-like surface of the second planet from the sun, O'Neil said. Galileo's camera snapped pictures of the planet to study wind and cloud patterns and search for lightning that might indicate the presence of volcanoes erupting beneath the clouds.
